28:41 - The data set has been around for about 10 years.
28:44 - Now, the reason you should verify these things as you're performing this analysis.
28:47 - And the reason you should perform this analysis in the first place is to understand if the distribution of the data that you have.
28:57 - Matches the distribution of the population itself, right?
29:01 - If your data contains 90% smokers, but in the general population, there are only about 10% smokers.
29:09 - Then any analysis that you do, or any model that you build will be wrong because it will be built under the assumption that 90% of the inputs that are coming to the model are going to have yes in smokers.
29:20 - So that's why wherever you're building a model, make sure that the distributions of each column match the distributions of the populations where the model will be applied.

38:18 - Okay.
But there is some sort of a trend here, a very weak trend, but a trend nevertheless.
38:25 - So as you can tell from the analysis, the values in some columns are more closely related to the values and charges compared to other columns.
38:32 - For example, age and charges seem to grow together and BMI and charges don't.
38:39 - So the relationship between two columns on whether they grow together or not is often expressed numerically using a measure called a correlation coefficient.
38:54 - And there's a certain formula for it and there's a certain meaning it has.
38:57 - But first, let's just see how to compute the correlation coefficient.
39:01 - The correlation coefficient can be computed using the.corr or.corr method of a pandas series.
39:07 - So if we say medical DF dot charges dot core medical DF dot age.
39:11 - So we want to compute the correlation between charges and age, and it seems like the correlation is 0.29.
39:18 - Okay.
39:18 - And we'll see what that means in just a second.
39:21 - And then if you want to compute the correlation between the medical charges and the BMI, it seems like the correlation here is 0.19.
39:31 - So there's definitely a higher correlation between age and charges than there is between BMI and charges.
39:39 - And maybe let's also compare children.
39:43 - So with children, there seems to be an even lower correlation than the BMI.
39:47 - Okay.
39:49 - So that's how you compute correlation between columns.
39:52 - And you can also compute correlation for categorical columns.
39:55 - It won't work directly.
39:57 - At least I believe it won't.
40:00 - Medical DF dot smoker, it won't work directly because you need numeric data to compute the correlation.
40:07 - So what do you need to first do is convert your categorical data into numeric data.
40:14 - So here's what I'm going to do.
40:16 - I am going to create a new series called smoker numeric.
40:22 - And how are we going to do that?
40:23 - We're going to take medical DF dot smoker and we can call dot map on it.
40:28 - So dot map takes either a function or a dictionary and it applies it to every value.
40:35 - So here we've supplied a dictionary, no dictionary, which converts no into zero and yes into one.
40:41 - So when you call medical DF dot smoker dot map smoker values, then wherever you have a no, that's going to convert to zero.
40:49 - Wherever you have a yes, that's going to convert to one.
40:53 - So this is a very useful technique.
40:55 - Whenever you want to quickly convert some categories into numbers, let's, and let's compare that.
40:59 - Let's see medical DF not smoker.
41:05 - So you have, yes, no, no, no.
41:07 - And you have one zero zero zero.
41:09 - Now, once it is converted into a number, you can then compute the correlation.
41:13 - So you see medical DF dot charges, not correlation smoker numeric.
41:18 - And that has a coalition of 0.787.
41:21 - So now you can start to see the train 0.787 for smoker.
41:24 - Probably the highest correlation.
41:26 - Then you have with age 0.299.
41:28 - Then you have with charges 0.19.
41:30 - And then you have with children 0.06.
41:33 - And then there are some other categorical columns as well.
41:36 - So we're not just, we're not done yet.
41:38 - So here's how the correlation coefficient is interpreted.
41:41 - It indicates two things.
41:42 - It indicates strength and it indicates the direction.
41:46 - So the greater the absolute value of the correlation coefficient, the stronger is the relationship.
41:51 - Which means that if you have an extreme value like minus one or one and one is pretty much the highest value that you can get, you cannot get something higher than one or lower than minus one.
42:02 - That indicates a perfectly linear relationship where a change in one variable is accompanied by a perfect consistent change in the other variable.
42:12 - Which means essentially that these points lie on a line and there's a geometric interpretation here.
42:16 - So if you have X and Y, let's say age and charges, and you saw this kind of a graph, that would mean perfect correlation, correlation of one.
42:24 - This would be positive correlation.
42:26 - And if you had a chart like this, where it was a line, but one increase in one led to decrease in the other, that would be a perfect negative correlation close to minus one.
42:36 - But you generally have something in between.
42:38 - You have strong positive correlation where these points are distributed around the line or a weak positive correlation where there is a weak trend of some kind or no correlation at all where points are all over the place.
42:51 - Or you can have a weak negative or strong negative correlation, right?
42:55 - So that's the direction, the sign of the correlation coefficients represents the direction of the relationship.
43:00 - If it's positive, then you have an increasing relationship.
43:02 - If it's negative, then you have a decreasing relationship.
43:05 - If the correlation coefficient is very close to zero, then you have practically no correlation.
43:11 - Okay.
43:12 - And the correlation coefficient has a formula and you can check out this formula.
43:16 - This is simply the sum of XI minus the mean of X, YI minus the mean of Y added up divided by a square root of some other quantity.
43:27 - I'll let you figure out what this formula means because it's not very important.
43:31 - It's simply a question of carefully looking at each of the terms and listing out what it means, but this is the more important interpretation that you should have.
43:40 - When you see correlations, you see plus one.
43:43 - This is what you see.
43:44 - You see something, let's say greater than 0.5, greater than 0.7.
43:47 - This is what you should imagine less than 0.5.
43:49 - This is what you should imagine close to zero is this and less than zero.
43:53 - These are the pictures you should have in mind.
43:56 - Okay.
43:57 - And if you really want to learn the mathematical definition and the geometric interpretation, I have linked to a video here.
44:03 - But this picture pretty much summarizes everything we need to know.
44:08 - Okay.
44:09 - Now, the pandas data frames also provide a CORR method to compute the correlation coefficients between all pairs of numeric columns.
44:17 - So if I just call medical DF.
44:19 - CORR that's going to compute the correlation between age BMI children charges, which are the numeric columns with the other numeric columns.
44:28 - You can see age and age.
44:29 - So age has a perfect correlation with itself.
44:32 - If you plot age with age and you can do that, you can do something like this.
44:37 - PX dot scatter you have medical DF X equals age and Y equals age.
44:51 - You see that there's obviously a perfect correlation.
44:53 - It's a straight line.
44:55 - So age has a perfect correlation, but what we're interested in is the correlation of charges with the other columns.
45:02 - You can see that age has a correlation of 0.299 with charges.
45:05 - BMI has a weaker correlation of 0.198 and children has an even weaker correlation of 0.067.
45:11 - Okay.
45:12 - And finally charges with charges obviously has a correlation of one.
45:15 - Now, this is normally displayed using a heat map because it's difficult to look at all these numbers and figure things out.
45:22 - So you can just show a heat map like this.
45:24 - This is called a correlation matrix.
45:26 - I've simply passed it into SNS dot heat map from seaborn.
45:31 - And this also adds some color and helps you visualize that seems like agent charges have a high correlation.
45:37 - Okay.
45:39 - So that's the correlation matrix.
45:41 - And one last thing I want to mention is the correlation versus causation policy.
45:45 - Note that a high correlation cannot be used to interpret a cause effect relationship between features.
45:51 - Two features X and Y can be correlated if X causes Y or if Y causes X.
45:58 - You can see that in the formula.
46:00 - If you replace X with Y and Y with X, nothing changes.
46:03 - It's the same formula.
46:04 - If you flip the axis here, nothing changes the relationship remains the same.
46:09 - So it does not give you a direction to interpret causation in.
46:13 - Okay.
46:14 - That's very important.
46:15 - X could cause Y or Y could cause X or it's possible that both are caused independently by some other factor Z.
46:22 - And the correlation will no longer hold true.
46:24 - If one of those cause effect relationships is broken, like if Z causes X and Z causes Y.
46:29 - But if you fix or change whatever effect Z has on Y, then X and Y will no longer be correlated.
46:36 - So that's why I do not interpret cause effect relationships from correlations.
46:40 - It's easy and a lot of people do it, even though it seems obvious, a lot of people do it, but it's wrong.
46:46 - Just to give you an example, for example, if you let's say created a scatter plot between race and income,
46:55 - you would find that maybe a certain race has lower income and a certain race has higher income.
47:00 - And if you want to create a cause effect relationship there, you could say that income is a function of race,
47:06 - that if you belong to a certain race, you will learn less.
47:08 - And then you may read more information into that.
47:11 - And that is because of such and such reasons, et cetera.
47:13 - But it's possible that this is because of something else entirely.
47:18 - For example, racism, systemic racism that may have caused incomes to be lower for a particular race.
47:25 - And once you fix that, and maybe if you control for that, if you see people who have not been subjected
47:31 - for several generations to racism, you might find that you no longer have the same correlation.
47:37 - So try not to read too much into these graphs.
47:40 - Always be careful because it's a very natural human tendency to create these interpretations.
47:46 - And when it becomes even more magnified is when these into these correlations are captured in automated systems.
47:54 - Computers cannot differentiate between correlation and causation.
47:57 - And decisions based on an automated system can often have major consequences on society.
48:03 - So it's important to study why automated systems lead to a given result.
48:08 - And again, another example of this, you may have heard about this facial recognition technology developed by Amazon
48:14 - is being used in law enforcement.
48:17 - And it just so happens that because of the correct, because of the current distribution of people who are incarcerated,
48:26 - a certain race has a higher representation in the incarcerated population.
48:30 - And so the model is more likely to predict a person with a certain race is a criminal or detect them as a criminal.
48:39 - And so more people are likely to be incarcerated from the same race.
48:42 - So it can actually aggravate the problems, the problems we have in our human systems.
48:47 - And that is why it's very important to be mindful of why we're getting a certain result out of a system that we create
48:53 - and realize that determining cause effect relationships requires human insight.
48:57 - We shouldn't blindly trust computer systems.
48:59 - Okay.
49:00 - So that's just my small note about correlation and causation that you should keep in mind.
49:09 - Okay.
49:10 - So that's our exploratory data analysis.
49:13 - We've done a lot of analysis.
49:15 - We spent half the lecture just doing analysis, but it's important.
49:18 - Once you, this is a more important piece of machine learning, really,
49:22 - which is before you get to the actual machine learning.
49:26 - And then the machine learning part becomes fairly straightforward after that.

51:29 - Okay.
51:30 - That's how prediction works.
51:31 - Once you get the line, you use the line to make predictions.
51:35 - And a line on the X and Y coordinates has a formula like this.
51:39 - A line has a formula Y equals W X plus B.
51:42 - So as you make changes to the value of X, the value of Y changes
51:48 - and it is determined by two factors.
51:50 - So the number W is called the slope and the number B is called the intercept.
51:55 - Okay.
51:56 - So what you do is you pick a value for W.
51:57 - Let's say you pick that W has the value hundred and you pick a value for B and
52:02 - you say B has the value 50.
52:05 - And as you change the value of X, the value of Y changes.
52:08 - And that is what draws a line on the 2d plane, basic geometry, something you
52:13 - would have seen in high school and W is called a slope because it determines how
52:18 - much change you will see in Y when you make some change in X.
52:22 - So the rate of change of Y with respect to the change in X is W and B is called
52:27 - the intercept because B is the value of Y when you set X equals zero.
52:31 - So X equals zero means this.
52:32 - So that means B is the point at which the line intersects with the Y axis and
52:37 - that is called the intercept.
52:40 - So in the above case, in this graph, the X axis represents age and
52:46 - the Y axis represents charges.
52:49 - So what we're trying to say essentially is that we're assuming that charges and
52:55 - each have the following relationship.
52:56 - We are saying that the charges is some number W multiplied by
53:01 - H plus some number B and we will then try and figure out a W and B to get
53:07 - the line that best fits the data.
53:09 - Now, obviously this is not a perfect relationship.
53:11 - Medical charges depend on a lot more than age, as we've already seen, and maybe
53:15 - you can't even predict medical charges exactly because there's a lot of
53:18 - uncertainty, but there's a certain trend we are trying to capture because some
53:23 - information will be more useful than no information, at least knowing that a
53:28 - person at a higher age, we should probably be charged a higher premium is
53:32 - useful information that we'd like to draw.
53:35 - Okay.
53:36 - So here we have charges equals some number W plus B.
53:40 - Now this number W is also called a weight sometimes.
53:44 - And then this number B is called a bias.
53:46 - So they're called slope and intercept in geometry, but they're often called
53:49 - weight and bias in statistics and machine learning.
53:52 - In any case, this is a relationship that we are assuming.
53:56 - Okay.
53:57 - So this technique is called linear regression and we call this equation
54:02 - a linear regression model because it is modeling the relationship between age
54:06 - and charges you're setting forward hypothesis that the charges is some
54:11 - weight W multiplied with H plus some number B.
54:16 - So this is our model.
54:17 - This literally this equation is our model and then the numbers
54:21 - W and B are called the parameters or the weights of the model.
54:25 - So the model has a structure or an equation and the model has some parameters.
54:30 - As you change these parameters, you will still have a line.
54:33 - The structure will be maintained, but the line will move around.
54:36 - So the model will give different predictions when you input a certain age,
54:40 - it will give a different output for charges as you change the values of W and B.
54:46 - Finally, the values in the age column of the data set are called the inputs to
54:51 - the model and the values in the charges column are called the targets.
54:56 - So we assume that when we multiply the inputs with this number W and add B,
55:00 - we are going to get something close to charges and we want to get as close as
55:04 - possible. So that's our linear regression model.
55:08 - It's called linear regression because it's a line and we're trying to fit the line.
55:11 - So we're trying to make sure that the line fits as closely as possible.
55:14 - With the points now, this equation is well and good, but we would like to express it
55:20 - in a way that we can compute, which is using code.
55:23 - So we can turn this equation into a function.
55:27 - So let's define a helper function, estimate charges, which takes an age.
55:31 - It takes a value of W it takes a value of B and it multiplies the weight with age
55:37 - and gives us and adds the B bias and gives us a result, which is an estimate.
55:43 - For the charges.
55:46 - So this function estimate charges is our very first model, our first machine
55:51 - learning model, and we'll define machine learning in just a second.

62:33 - then if you need to increase the slope, increase W, if you need to decrease the slope, decrease W.
62:38 - So you already have a strategy in place.
62:40 - That you can apply each time.
62:45 - Now, as we change the values of W and B manually, trying to move the line visually closer to the points,
62:52 - we are learning the approximate relationship between age and charges.
62:57 - So wouldn't it be nicer if a computer could try several different values of W and B and learn the relationship between age and charges.
63:06 - Because ultimately now, once we've established that there's going to be a linear relationship,
63:11 - we just need to move the line around up and down, left and right, change its slope.
63:16 - And we should be able to get to the right point.
63:21 - Well, to do this, we need to solve a couple of problems.
63:26 - One, we have eyes and we can see that the line is far away from the points,
63:31 - but the computer does not have eyes, so to speak. So we need a way to measure numerically how well the line fits the points.
63:39 - That's the first thing.
63:40 - Okay.
63:41 - Second, we are able to guess which way we should move W and B by looking at how far the line is from the points.
63:49 - But again, we are applying a lot of insight here.
63:52 - So once we measure the fit of the line, we need a way to modify W and B to improve the line.
63:59 - Okay. So we need a way to measure how well the line fits the points.
64:02 - And we need a way to improve W and B once we have made a measure and we realize that this measure is bad.
64:09 - So if we can solve the above problems, this will be a breakthrough because it should then be possible for a computer to determine
64:16 - W and B for the best fit line, starting from a random guess.
64:21 - So let's solve the first problem.
64:24 - Now we want to compare our models predictions with the actual targets.
64:29 - And this is the method that we can follow.
64:31 - We calculate the difference between the targets, which is the actual charges from the dataset and the predictions from our model.
64:39 - And this difference is called the residual.
64:43 - So for each target, you have a bunch of targets here.
64:45 - The targets are simply the actual charges.
64:48 - So we have non-smoker DF not charges.
64:54 - These are the targets.
64:56 - And then you have the predictions, which is the estimated charges.
64:59 - This is what our model has predicted for the input data.
65:02 - So predictions is estimated charges.
65:10 - Okay.
65:11 - And this is what a particular value of our model is.
65:14 - So what we do is we subtract each prediction from the corresponding target.
65:21 - So this is going to tell us how far away our prediction is from a target.
65:25 - But the problem is some predictions may be lower than the target.
65:28 - Some predictions may be higher than the target.
65:30 - So to remove negative values, we square all the elements in the difference vector.
65:36 - Let me remove this matrix term here.
65:38 - Yeah. So we square all the elements to remove negative values.
65:44 - So you subtract 1000 minus one, seven, two, five, that's seven, 25.
65:48 - And then you square it.
65:49 - So 25 squared, then you do 1500 minus four, four, four, nine.
65:53 - That's again, some negative value, a square it at some points.
65:56 - You may have positive values.
65:57 - Maybe you have 2,600 here and 1,600 here.
66:00 - So you get a positive value.
66:02 - Square it.
66:03 - So we take the residuals.
66:08 - Each difference is called a residual and we square all the residuals.
66:11 - Then we calculate the average of all those elements in the result, right?
66:15 - So we have all of these residuals.
66:17 - We simply add up all the squares of residuals and calculate the average.
66:21 - So now we have this minus the actual target squared plus this minus the actual target squared
66:27 - plus this minus the actual target squared divided by the total target.
66:30 - And finally, we take the square root of the result.
66:33 - Okay.
66:34 - Seems like a complicated process, but it's actually fairly straightforward.
66:37 - What it's giving us is called the root mean squared error.
66:41 - So let's break that down.
66:42 - Error is simply the difference between the targets and the predictions.
66:46 - So that is the error.
66:47 - But of course, if you just add up errors, positives and negatives may cancel out.
66:51 - So that's why we square all the elements in the result.
66:53 - And then we take the square root of the result.
66:56 - If you just add up errors, positives and negatives may cancel out.
67:00 - So that's why we squared it.
67:01 - So now when we square it, all the errors become positive and then we take that average.
67:07 - So that gives us the average squared error or mean squared error.
67:10 - But then we want to take the square root again, because we want to interpret the number that
67:14 - we get as a dollar value, essentially.
67:16 - So now when we took squares, we converted the difference in dollars into dollars squared.
67:20 - So we just took, take a root again, and that just gives us a dollar value.
67:25 - So that's why this is called a root mean squared error.
67:28 - And it tells us on average, how far away we are, how far away each point is from the line.
67:35 - Now, this is not the only way to do it.
67:37 - There is also something called the root mean absolute error where you do not take squares.
67:42 - You actually take the absolute value, which means you simply ignore the sign.
67:45 - And the difference between root mean squared error and root mean absolute error is simply
67:52 - that outliers have a big factor or outliers contribute highly in a squared error because
67:59 - the, the greater the error, the greater its square is going to be.
68:03 - So it's going to be a bigger factor in the overall error.
68:06 - Okay.
68:07 - So that's just one thing to keep in mind, but root mean squared error.
68:10 - Make sure you understand this.
68:11 - This is the average on average, how far away we are from the line, right?
68:15 - And this is the formula, which is exactly the same thing.
68:18 - Prediction minus actual squared sum over all the predictions divided by N square root of
68:24 - that.
68:25 - And this is how you can visualize root mean squared error.
68:27 - So these are the rest.
68:28 - So suppose this is the line and then these are the actual target points for each point.
68:32 - You calculate how far away it is from the prediction and the prediction is simply the
68:36 - point on the line at the same X value.
68:38 - So this is a prediction.
68:39 - This is the actual point you calculate the residual for that point.
68:43 - And then you add up the squares of all the residuals, take their average and take the
68:46 - square root.
68:48 - So these are all different ways to look at the root mean squared error, but let's look
68:52 - at it in a way that we understand best, which is using cool.

71:35 - And this error is also called a loss because it indicates how bad the model is at predicting the target.
71:44 - Remember the difference between the two things, which is targets and predictions will be higher.
71:49 - And then the squares will be even higher and the average will be higher.
71:53 - And so the square root will be higher if the targets are very far away from the predictions.
71:57 - That means if your model is really bad, then the root mean squared error is going to be very high.
72:01 - That's why it's called a loss because it represents the information loss in the model.
72:05 - Remember, we are not capturing the actual relationship.
72:09 - We are simply modeling the relationship and all models are wrong.
72:12 - It's just that some are useful.

74:08 - Let's see if you can beat that and try and come up with a general strategy
74:15 - for bet for finding better values of W and B just by looking at the loss, not
74:20 - necessarily by looking at the graph, but just by looking at the loss.
74:23 - Here's one strategy that I will suggest.
74:25 - If you have a weight, if you have a certain W on a certain B, try slightly
74:30 - increasing W.
74:31 - If that reduces the loss, then you can increase W by a large amount.
74:36 - If that does not reduce the loss, try slightly decreasing W.
74:39 - If that reduces the loss, then maybe you can reduce W by a significant amount.
74:44 - If that does not help, try the same with B or maybe try the same with W and B
74:49 - in parallel. Okay.
74:51 - And this strategy of just trying a small change and seeing whether it leads
74:56 - to an increase or decrease, and then taking a larger step in that direction,
74:59 - which is sort of assume you're blind and you're in a dark room and you have to
75:05 - figure out which way to go down, which way goes down, right?
75:09 - If it's not an uneven surface that you're on.
75:11 - So you put one foot and you put one foot and you realize, okay, this is higher
75:15 - ground and you put one another foot and you realize, okay, that is lower ground.
75:18 - If you want to go downhill, then you step, take a couple of steps, maybe along
75:23 - the lower ground, and then you repeat the process.
75:25 - So this strategy is called the gradient descent strategy, and it can be
75:29 - implemented mathematically using derivatives, but that's what we want to
75:33 - come up with, right?
75:34 - So we need a, we need a strategy to modify the weights and the, and the
75:38 - biases, which is the, the parameters of our model to reduce the model, to
75:43 - reduce the loss and improve the fit of the line to the data.
75:47 - And there are a couple of strategies that are used to do this.
75:50 - One is called the ordinary least squares method.
75:54 - And the way it works is using some matrix operations and some matrix inversions.
75:59 - It directly arrives at the best value of W and B.
76:02 - So it uses a combination of calculus and linear algebra.
76:05 - To directly give you the values of W and B, it works well for small data sets,
76:10 - like data sets with a few thousand rows of data, but for larger data sets,
76:15 - it is very inefficient.
76:16 - And sometimes it takes up a lot of memory.
76:18 - So for that, you have this, another technique called the stochastic gradient
76:22 - descent technique, which is what I just talked about, which is imagine that
76:26 - you're on a hill and it's dark and you want to figure out how to go down.
76:30 - You just take steps in each direction, figure out which direction goes down and then take a few steps in that direction and then repeat, right?
76:36 - So that's called stochastic gradient descent.
76:39 - You can check out these videos for some explanation of how these work, some mathematical explanation.
76:44 - In general, we are not going to look at it in a lot of detail because you will never have to implement these.
76:49 - It helps to understand them, but in general, you won't.
76:52 - And you can't really implement these.
76:54 - You will most likely have to implement these.
76:56 - But in general, you won't, and you can't really implement these.
77:00 - You will mostly have to depend on the libraries to do this.
77:04 - And the more important skill for you is to know how to use these rather than to understand the mathematical representation.
77:12 - But yeah, ordinary three squares works well for small data sets, uses some direct matrix computations.
77:18 - Gradient descent works well for larger data sets and uses an iterative approach.
77:25 - That's the actualization of how gradient descent works.
77:27 - It starts out with a flat line and then slowly improves both the weight.
77:31 - So you can see now it is improving the bias so far, but once it gets close enough, it's going to start turning the line.
77:36 - So it's going to start changing the line.
77:39 - So it computes the loss.
77:40 - It figures out whether it should increase or decrease the weight.
77:43 - It figures out whether it should increase or decrease the bias or the intercept.
77:48 - And that's how it keeps changing the line step by step.
77:51 - And then it gets to the very close to the best fit line.
77:54 - And it works really well for large data sets where you have millions or tens of millions of data points.
77:59 - So you will be applying linear regression to some really large data sets.
78:02 - And that's where you will get to see gradient descent in action.
78:06 - Okay.
78:07 - And it is actually quite similar to our own strategy of just gradually moving the line closer to the points.

85:23 - This person incurred 2007 and we predicted 3520.
85:27 - So it's in the good range.
85:28 - It's not that bad.
85:29 - It's maybe off by a thousand or so, but when you're dealing with values in the range of about 15,000 or so,
85:36 - the error of thousand is probably acceptable, right?
85:40 - And it's mostly on the higher side for lower values, which is fine too,
85:45 - because we know that there are a lot of outliers which are quite high in value.
85:50 - Okay.
85:51 - We can also look at the laws.
85:53 - We have this RMSE function, which is the root means squared error.
85:57 - So that we will take the targets minus predictions, square all of the numbers, add up all the squares,
86:03 - take the average and take the square root of that.
86:06 - Let's look at the RMSE.
86:08 - So the RMSE for this model, the root means squared error for this model is 4662,
86:13 - which means on average, we are off by about $4,600 and that's the average.
86:20 - But actually, when you look at the values, you'll see that you're off by much less.
86:24 - It's just that some of these are such big outliers that we cannot capture that relationship with just a simple line.
86:30 - But you can see that this one, we should be predicting 21,000, but we get 6,720.
86:35 - And it's simply not possible to get that far out of an outlier using a line.
86:40 - So on average, we're actually doing much better than 4662.
86:43 - We are probably in the thousand, 2000 range, but yeah,
86:46 - this captures the fact that there are a bunch of outliers and in the model as well.
86:51 - So this is the whole process of machine learning that you assume a certain relationship between inputs and targets,
86:57 - which is the linear relationship. You then find a loss.
87:02 - You find a way to measure how bad your model is based on certain random parameters that you've picked initially.
87:10 - And then you use some kind of an optimization algorithm to improve the parameters of the model.
87:15 - In this case, WNB till you can minimize the loss.
87:20 - Okay.
87:22 - So we've gotten to a good point. Our model is off by 4,000 on average, which is not too bad considering that there are several outliers.
87:30 - Now you may be wondering, where's the WNB?
87:32 - Well, in scikit-learn, the W is stored in model.cof.
87:37 - It stands for coefficients, which are the coefficients or the weights applied to each individual feature.
87:43 - In this case, we're just working with age.
87:45 - So we have 267 is the coefficient W and then we have B here.
87:50 - Okay. So model dot intercept contains B and that is minus two zero nine one.
87:55 - So it seems like if you had picked a W of two 67 and a B of two zero nine one,
88:01 - we would have gotten a pretty good line and that would have been our best.
88:04 - That would have been the best possible model.
88:07 - So when you try this out later, see how close you can get without actually looking at the values of W and B.
88:13 - Let's maybe just plot them once again.
88:16 - So here we have all the points in blue and here we have our model, our line showing the predictions.
88:23 - So you see that our line is fitting quite nicely.
88:27 - I wouldn't say it's bad and it's slightly above this cluster because we also want to somehow capture the fact that there are certain outliers at the top.
88:35 - So if the line was somewhere here, it would technically not be giving the right information because it would not be suggesting the fact that there are outliers.
88:42 - So to account for all these outliers, it's slightly above the data, but that's pretty good.
88:46 - That's how you do linear regression using scikit-learn.
88:49 - You use the linear regression class, then you fit the model and then you generate predictions on new data or on existing data.
88:57 - Now, the linear regression class uses this optimization technique called ordinary least squares.
89:04 - There is another technique called gradient descent that I'd mentioned.
89:07 - For that, you need to use the SGD regressor.
89:10 - So I encourage you to try out SGD regressor.

89:20 - It's just that internally what's happening is different.

90:05 - And that's it.
90:06 - Congratulations.
90:07 - You have just trained your first machine learning model and machine learning is simply the process of computing the best parameters to model the relationship between some feature and targets.
90:20 - So every machine learning problem that we'll solve in this entire course or in general that you'll solve anytime will generally have three components.
90:30 - The first thing you will have to decide is how do you want to model the relationship?
90:34 - Do you want to model the relationship as a linear equation?
90:37 - Maybe you want to model the relationship as a polynomial equation.
90:41 - Maybe you want to model the relationship as some kind of a decision tree.
90:44 - Maybe you want to model the relationship in some other way.
90:46 - And there are many, many, many ways to model relationships.
90:49 - The simplest one is to just say that the thing that we're trying to predict the target is some kind of a weighted sum of the thing that we're trying to predict the target is a weighted sum of the input features that we're interested in.
91:04 - For example, we could say that the charges is simply some weight w one multiplied by age, some weight w two multiplied by number of children, some weight w three multiplied by BMI plus some number B.
91:16 - Some intercept, right? So that's the model and every model has parameters. That's what the machine has to learn.
91:24 - So to understand how good the parameters are of the model, we have a cost function and there are several choices for cost function.
91:33 - But the idea for the cost function is that it should give you a cost, which it should give you how badly the model is performing and the lower the cost, the better the model.
91:44 - Okay. Once you have a cost function that can be computed given some targets and predictions, then you need to use some kind of an optimization technique to optimize the cost, which means to change the parameters of the model so that it better fits the data.
92:03 - And this is what this entire process looks like. You put some input data into the model and you get some outputs. You put, you take both the target and the output into the error or the loss function.
92:14 - You then apply an optimization method and that optimization method changes the weights and biases or changes the parameters of the model.
92:21 - So model gets slightly better.
92:23 - Then you put some more input data, you get some more output. You take that, put that into the loss function, perform optimization and improve the model.
92:30 - This, what we're seeing here is essentially this animation that we saw here, which is taking the line and slowly moving it so that it perfectly fits the data, right?
92:42 - So most of machine learning and even a lot of deep learning is basically glorified line fitting.
92:48 - That's all we are doing.
92:49 - We are fitting lines.
92:50 - And the fact is that the only difference is we are saying that the relationship instead of being a line is something else. And we're asking the computer to compute the parameters in that relationship or the parameters of that model.
93:07 - Okay. So that's, that's machine learning.
93:10 - And as we've seen, it just, it takes just a few lines of code to train a machine learning model using scikit-learn.
93:17 - You start out by creating some inputs and some targets you, for example, in the inputs in this case are non-smoker DF.
93:24 - And we are just picking a set of columns and currently we're just picking one column age.
93:28 - So the inputs need to be a two dimensional array.
93:31 - Then you have targets, which can be one dimensional or two dimensional.
93:34 - So you have a list of inputs and a list of targets and then you create a model.
93:39 - So here we are creating this model linear regression.
93:42 - And most of the time immediately, you just want to fit the model, not always, but most of the time.
93:47 - So if you just want to fit the model, you can create the object and immediately call dot fit on it.
93:51 - And that will also return the model.
93:53 - So you can just do this linear regression dot fit and into it, you provide the inputs and the targets and it's going to go and do its thing.
94:01 - It's going to do all of this for you.
94:02 - This class determines what kind of relationship you want to assume, like here, you want to assume the linear relationship, right?
94:11 - So you fit the data and that gives you a model.
94:15 - Then you can use that model to make predictions.
94:18 - So now you can just take this model and every time a new customer comes in, you ask them, Hey, what's your age?
94:23 - And they say 32 and you put in the number 32 and you get a certain estimate for the medical charges.
94:28 - That estimate can then be used to compute their insurance premium and off they go.
94:33 - So it automates that piece of analysis, which you had to do with maybe using several experts with years of expertise and there's a certain error.
94:43 - So whenever you use a model, you should be aware of what the error in your model is or what the loss, the information loss in your model is.
94:50 - So in this case, what we say is that, Hey, my predictions are off by maybe about three or 4,000.
94:55 - So you may just want to keep that in mind when you are comparing, when you are calculating the insurance premium for this person.
95:01 - All right. And that's your three or four step process, create inputs and targets, create a training model, create and train a model and generate some predictions with the model.
95:13 - And wherever possible, you also should have a measure of what is the information loss or what is the error in your model.
95:20 - So you create the input data, and then you put that into some kind of a model and the model gives you some predictions.
95:26 - Now you compare the predictions with the actual outputs and that gives you some kind of a measurement, how bad your model is your model is really bad initially.
95:37 - Then you run some kind of an optimization method and that improves your model.
95:42 - So as you give some data into the model, it learns from the data, it makes better predictions.
95:47 - Then you give it some more feedback using the loss function.
95:51 - It makes a better prediction and it gets better over time. If you can just grasp that basic idea and see how it is translated into code here, that is enough to get started.
96:02 - And it is a fundamentally different way of thinking about problems.
96:06 - If you are struggling with it a little bit, that's okay.
96:09 - Once you struggle through it, and once you get the idea, once it clicks, what's happening here, you will suddenly realize the potential of what it makes possible.
96:16 - Because now instead of let's say having several years of expertise in analyzing or evaluating insurance applications, you just have this one system.
96:27 - You just feed in some input and it's going to give you an output and you know how much it is going to be off by and you can use it.

105:44 - you're trying to predict are in this range of five, 6,000.
105:47 - And if you're off by 11,000, then that doesn't really make sense at all.
105:52 - So the next thing that you might want to do is to start using the
105:56 - categorical features for machine learning as well.
105:59 - Now, so far, we've only been using numeric columns because we can only perform
106:03 - the computations with numbers.
106:05 - Remember the computation of the loss, the optimization that is again using
106:09 - calculus and linear algebra.
106:10 - So all of that can only be done with numbers.
106:13 - Now, if we could use categorical columns like smoker, then it would be possible
106:18 - to maybe train a single model for the entire dataset, which can also account
106:22 - for smokers in some fashion or to use the categorical columns.
106:27 - One trick is to simply convert them into numbers.
106:31 - And there are three common techniques for converting categorical columns into numbers.
106:35 - The first one is if a categorical column has just two categories, let's say smoker,
106:40 - non-smoker, yes, no, then it's called a binary category.
106:44 - It simply indicates the presence or absence of something.
106:49 - In such a case, we can replace the values with zero and one.
106:53 - We can replace no with zero and we can replace yes with one.
106:57 - So now a weight would apply when we have a smoker and when the, when the person
107:03 - is not a smoker, then that weight would simply not apply, right?
107:06 - So there's a certain term that gets added.
107:08 - It's like a penalty that we're adding for a person is a smoker or not.
107:12 - Then another way to go about it is if a categorical column has more than two
107:18 - categories, for example, the region, then we can perform a one hot encoding, which
107:24 - means that we perform a new, we create a new column for each category in that.
107:28 - So let's say for the Northeast column, Northeast region, we create a category
107:32 - which contains ones and zeros once at the places where a row belongs to the
107:36 - Northeast category, we can create a Northwest and Southeast and Southwest.
107:40 - So we create these four categories.
107:42 - Each of them contain numbers, and then we can ignore the original region column.
107:47 - So each of these columns, North Northwest, Northeast, Southwest,
107:51 - Southwest, Southeast will contain zeros and ones, and every row will contain exactly
107:56 - a single one.
107:58 - So it'll contain three zeros and a single one.
108:00 - And that's why it is called one hot encoding.
108:03 - Next, if the categories have a natural order, sometimes you may have a natural
108:07 - order like this cold, neutral, warm, hot, then they can be converted into numbers
108:12 - like one, two, three, four, while still preserving the order.
108:16 - So it's possible, not in this problem, but in some other problem that cold,
108:20 - neutral, warm, hot are indications of temperature and there is actually a
108:24 - linear relationship between what you're trying to predict and the temperature.
108:28 - So in such a case, it may make sense to convert them into numbers to preserve
108:32 - that order.
108:33 - And in these cases, they are called ordinance.
108:35 - So you will often have to decide whether you want to convert certain categories
108:39 - into numbers or you want to convert them into one hot.
108:42 - When should you convert them into numbers?
108:44 - When you see that there is a high correlation between these categories in
108:48 - their original order and their natural order and the target, then you should
108:53 - convert them into numbers.
108:54 - If you do not see a correlation, if you see things go up and down like region,
108:58 - for example, there's no clear region, there's no clear reason why region should
109:02 - have some kind of an order in determining what kind of charges you have.
109:05 - So you can just convert them into one hot encoded columns.
109:09 - Okay.
109:10 - So let's start with the smoker column.
109:11 - We are going to convert the smoker column into, we're going to add a
109:15 - new column called smoker code.

109:30 - The medical charges that the mean, but that's because you have a lot of outliers.

112:55 - for Southwest and put ones and zeros.

113:03 - And this is, this process is called one hot encoding.
113:05 - So I typically just look up an example.
113:07 - So here again, if you see that there is a difference by region, so maybe region is a factor.
113:13 - Maybe different regions based on different average incomes have different medical costs at different hospitals.
113:20 - So maybe region is a factor.

113:32 - So from sklearn, we import pre-processing and then we use pre-processing or one hot encoder.
113:37 - And on the encoder, we call, we give it the list of regions and it's simply going to identify the list of regions.

116:01 - So we have w one times age plus w two times BMI plus w three times charges plus w four times smoker w five times six times region plus B.
116:11 - The idea here is once you understand linear regression with one variable and you really understand it well, if you internalize how it works,
116:19 - then all of this is really, it's a very simple extension.
116:22 - You don't even have to change any of the code.
116:24 - But all you want to understand is that when you're working with one variable, you're trying to fit a line and you start out with a random line and you move the line around.
116:33 - You use the loss function to find out how bad the line is.

116:44 - which is to minimize the loss, right?
116:47 - And then you simply have to extend it mathematically into a bunch of other dimensions.
116:51 - So now we're no longer dealing with one feature.

Now, based on these weights, if we compare w one is for age, w two is for BMI, w three is for charges, w four is for smoker.
123:46 - So you might be tempted to say at this point that look, we apply a very high weight to smokers and $23,000.
123:53 - We've accounted for simply because you're a smoker, right?

124:04 - It makes sense.

124:12 - If you notice the weight carefully, it seems like BMI has a higher weight than age.
124:17 - BMI has a weight 339 while age has a weight 256 and children have the weight 475.
124:23 - So this goes completely opposite to what we understand.
124:27 - We understand that age is the age is one of the most important factors.
124:31 - We saw that small for non-smokers, at least BMI has no bearing and children again, we saw had has no bearing.
124:38 - So what's going on here?
124:40 - Our model's results seem to be completely out of sync with the weights that it is assigning to the different features.
124:47 - We felt that age and smoker, the smoker definitely has a high weight, no doubt,
124:52 - but we felt that age has a far more important impact than BMI children, sex code, et cetera.
124:58 - But it seems like even Southwest Southeast region has minus four 48.
125:01 - So it has a negative correlation that is twice as high as age.
125:06 - So what's going on here?
125:08 - What's going on is that the range of values for BMI is limited.
125:15 - BMI is going to be limited from 15 to 40.
125:17 - BMI is never going to go beyond 40.
125:19 - And in fact, in most cases, it's going to be around 30.
125:22 - The Northeast column is only going to take the values zero or one.
125:27 - That means the maximum change that the Northeast column can compute,
125:31 - and then can create in the final output of charges is $500, not more than that.
125:37 - On the other hand, the age, even though 256 is the weight for it, age can go up to 60.
125:43 - So it can create 256 times 60.
125:46 - What's that 256 times 60.
125:49 - It can create a difference of $21,000, right?
125:53 - So the weights do not accurately represent which features are important because the ranges of the different features are different.
126:03 - That's one issue.
126:05 - And another issue that happens, not so much in linear regression, but in later data sets, we'll see that sometimes when one column has a very large range of inputs,
126:13 - like age has a very large range of 15 to 60.
126:15 - And one column has a very low range of inputs, like region can only go zero to one.
126:20 - So then when you are calculating the loss and when you're performing any optimizations,
126:25 - that large number disproportionately affects the optimization process because ultimately your number is your model is simply looking at a single number, the loss.
126:34 - And the loss is computed using all of these inputs and outputs and weights and everything.
126:39 - And if some column has a very large inputs or very large outputs, definitely very large inputs,
126:45 - then yeah, if some column has very large inputs, then it will disproportionately contribute to the loss.
126:52 - So most of our effort will be spent just optimizing for that one single column.
126:59 - So that's where we perform a certain thing called standardization.
127:03 - We take the values in every column from the value we subtract the mean of the column,
127:08 - and then we divide by the standard deviation of the column.
127:11 - Okay.
127:12 - What does that do?
127:13 - For example, let's say BMI, BMI goes in the range or BMI varies from the range of 15 to 40.
127:21 - After applying the standardization, we subtract the mean, which means we subtract 30 from the BMI.
127:27 - And then we divide by the standard deviation.
127:28 - The standard deviation is around six, let's say after applying this standardization, the values become centered around zero.
127:35 - So you have the value zero, and then you have BMI centered around zero.
127:39 - And they are also scaled down so that it becomes a normal distribution with standard deviation, one and mean of zero.
127:47 - So the idea is we scale down all the values to small numbers that are in the range of one to minus one or two to minus two.
127:54 - And then their mean is also zero.
127:57 - And we do that for every column.
127:59 - So what we do is we standardize every column into the zero to one range only for the numeric columns.
128:03 - The categoricals are already like a zero to one.
128:06 - So we standardized the, the numeric columns in the minus one to one range means zero standard deviation one.
128:13 - And then the weights will make a lot more sense.
128:17 - So here's how you do it.
128:18 - I'll just show you quickly.
128:20 - The way to do it is again, the way to really do it is to just look up online.
128:25 - How do I perform scaling of features in a scalar?

128:52 - So it turns out that the mean for age is 39 and the mean for BMI is 30 and the mean for children is one.
128:59 - It turns out that the very variance in age is one 97 variance is square of the standard deviation.
129:04 - The variance in BMI is far less and the variance in children is even lesser.
129:09 - So now we can scale the data.

133:51 - And I guess we're going to end here today.
133:53 - So just a quick summary of how you approach a machine learning problem.
133:59 - First step is to explore the data and find different correlations between inputs and targets.
134:04 - Understand what leads to a certain target.
134:08 - Maybe even go back and do some research, whether there is a cause effect relationship or is there just a correlation?
134:13 - And is it possible that the correlation may just go away or is it possible that the correlation is unfair in any way?
134:19 - For example, sure.
134:20 - Maybe you should not be using race as a factor in computing insurance, right?
134:24 - So that's something you should be conscious of as a data scientist.
134:28 - Then you pick the right model.
134:30 - In this case, we pick linear regression.
134:31 - You pick the light loss functions.
134:33 - In this case, we picked root mean squared error and you pick the right optimizer.
134:37 - In this case, we pick least squares and all of these three are captured in the linear regression class from scikit-learn.
134:45 - So for different problems, you have to pick different models.
134:47 - Sometimes you have to pick decision trees.
134:49 - Sometimes you have to pick neural networks or something else.
134:51 - Then you scale the numeric variables and one hot, you scale the numeric variables so that they all have a mean of zero standard deviation of one.
134:59 - You perform one hot encoding for categorical data.
135:03 - And this is not something we covered today, but this is something that we'll cover next time about setting aside a test set.
135:09 - Then you train a model.
135:10 - Then you make predictions and compute the loss.
135:13 - Now we didn't do this today, but one thing you should do is you should actually set aside 10% of your data,
135:20 - a small fraction of your data, just for testing and reporting the results of your model,
135:24 - because the model like the ones we have created today are designed to be used in the real world,
135:29 - not only on the data that we train them on.
135:31 - So what people typically do is when they get some data from let's say a product manager or somebody,
135:37 - whoever has given us the insurance data, we take 10% of the data and then we set it aside forever.
135:44 - Then we do all our modeling and everything.
135:46 - Let's say we build a linear regression model on 90% of the data.
135:50 - And then when we report the loss, when we actually report the metrics that, Hey, I built this model and this is the result it gives.
135:58 - And this is the kind of loss that I've been able to achieve.
136:00 - Or this is the kind of error that my model has.
136:03 - You should be then reporting that error on the test data, which means on the 10% of the data,
136:09 - which you set aside at the beginning and did not use for training.
136:12 - And you can do this in scikit-learn using this train test split.
136:16 - So what that does is it takes some inputs.
136:18 - It takes some targets.
136:19 - It takes a 0.1 like a fraction and it gives you a bunch of 90% of the data, which you can use for training,
136:26 - which is input strain and target strain, and then 10% of the data, which you can use for testing.
136:30 - Okay.
136:31 - And we'll talk about this in a lot more detail the next time.
136:34 - But what you will notice is that the score on your test set or the loss on your test set is going to be always higher than the loss on your training set because your model has not seen these examples.
136:47 - So model is bad is worse at predicting examples that it has not seen.
136:51 - And this is again, true.
136:52 - A lot of machine learning models, when you put them out into the real world,
136:55 - they perform worse, even though you may get a really, you get like a 98% accuracy when you're training the model.
137:01 - But when you put it out, it's less than 30%.
137:04 - So we will talk about a lot of techniques in this course on how to counter that.
137:08 - This is called overfitting and we'll talk in a lot of detail about that.
137:12 - So the right strategy is to set aside a test set before you train a model and then train the model and then make predictions and compute the loss and report the results on your test set.
137:21 - And we will apply this process over and over to several problems with different kinds of models over the next few weeks.
137:28 - The topic for today is logistic regression with scikit learn.
137:35 - And here is a quick overview of the topics that we're covering.
137:39 - This image will give you a hint of the problem statement that we're looking at today.
137:44 - So we'll start by downloading a real world dataset from Kaggle.
137:48 - We will explore the dataset.
137:50 - We'll perform some exploratory data analysis and visualization.
137:53 - Very little.
137:55 - We will then split the dataset node into a training validation and test set.
138:00 - So we'll talk about why these are important.
138:03 - We will talk about filling and imputing missing values in numeric columns.
138:08 - We will also look at how we can scale numeric features to a zero to one range.
138:12 - We will also look at encoding categorical columns as one hot vectors.
138:17 - Then we will train a logistic regression model using the scikit learn library.
138:23 - Then we will evaluate the model using the validation set in the test set that we had created.
138:29 - And then we'll save the model to disc and load it back.
138:33 - So you'll see quite a bit of overlap between what we're doing today and what we did last week.
138:38 - And that is intentional.
138:42 - The idea here is that the machine learning workflow is something that you will apply to pretty much every machine learning problem you solve.
138:47 - So by looking at it multiple times with multiple dataset in the context of different machine learning algorithms, you will start to get used to it.
138:56 - And by the end of this course, this should become second nature to you.

140:15 - So we'll talk about what that is.

146:58 - So those are the kinds of problems that we're looking at today, but the kind of problems that we looked at the last time, which is problems where a new continuous numeric value must be predicted for each input are known as regression problems.

148:08 - So once again, this is called a regression problem, not a classification problem.

148:23 - And you can try and replicate the steps we followed in the previous tutorial with each of these datasets.
148:29 - Okay. So that's classification and regression classification is just classifying data into certain classes regression.
148:38 - Technically literally means fitting data.
148:41 - So trying to create a model which can fit exactly to the numeric value that you want to predict, right?
148:47 - So whenever you see regression, think continuous values.
148:50 - Whenever you think classification, think discrete classes.
148:54 - And we saw that linear regression is a commonly used technique for solving regression problems.
149:01 - Hence the name linear regression and in a linear regression model, the target is modeled as a linear combination or a weighted sum of input features.
149:11 - For example, we said that trying to predict the medical charges can be done by taking a linear combination of some input features.
149:22 - So let's say we're looking at the input features age and whether the person is a smoker.
149:27 - So zero or one.
149:28 - So the model that we created the last time assumed that age has a certain weight w one and smoker zero or one has a certain weight w two.
149:38 - And then there's certain number B.
149:40 - So you have w one, w two and B.
149:42 - If you can figure out good values for w one, w two and B, then you can take any value of age and any information about whether the person or smoker is a smoker or not.
149:51 - And get a good estimate of their medical charges.
149:53 - So that was the model that we had created the last time.
149:57 - And what we did was we took that model and using that model and we took random values of w one, w two and B to get started.
150:05 - We took that model and using that model, we generated predictions for all the inputs that we had.
150:10 - And we compared the predictions of our model, our randomly initialized model, assuming a linear relationship,
150:17 - we compared its predictions with the actual targets or with the actual medical charges of those people using a loss function.
150:25 - So called the root mean squared error, right?
150:27 - So we compared it using a loss function, and then we trained a machine learning model to reduce the loss function by adjusting the weights w one, w two and B.
150:38 - That is what a machine learning training process looks like.
Okay.
150:41 - So here's what that looks like.
150:44 - We take some input data training data.
150:47 - So this would contain information like age, whether the person is smoker, number of children, et cetera.
150:52 - And it would also have some outputs.
150:55 - So we would put the input data into the model and we would get some predictions from the model.
151:00 - So we would take the predicted output from the model and we would also take the actual output or the real data from the training set,
151:09 - put them both into a loss function, which was a root mean squared error in case of linear regression,
151:15 - and then run an optimization method to reduce the loss by changing the weights within the model.
151:21 - So that will then improve the model over time.
151:23 - And as we do this over and over repeatedly for long enough, the weights get pretty good.
151:28 - And then we can use the model to make predictions on new data, right?
151:32 - That's the machine learning process that we followed.
151:37 - For linear regression.
151:39 - Okay.
151:40 - And if you want to see a more mathematical discussion of linear regression, you should check out this YouTube playlist that I've linked to here.
151:48 - And that will then go through in more detail how each component fits in and how the optimization works.
151:55 - So for classification problems, similarly, the technique that is often used is called logistic regression.
152:03 - Specifically for binary classification problems, which is a kind of classification problem.
152:07 - We're looking at today, just a yes, no classification.
152:11 - So in a logistic regression model, we start out the same way.
152:16 - We take a linear combination or a weighted sum of the input features.
152:20 - So let's say if we just look at today's temperature and today's rainfall, and we want to use those to predict whether it will rain tomorrow or not.
152:29 - So we start out by taking a linear combination.
152:32 - Let's say we pick a weight W1, a random weight W1.
152:36 - We pick a random weight W2 and random weight B and we fix them.
152:40 - So W1 W2 B we fix them.
152:42 - Then we calculate this quantity for a given input.
152:46 - Let's say we have some information about the city Melbourne.
152:50 - We take the temperature at Melbourne.
152:52 - We take the rainfall at Melbourne.
152:54 - We multiply them with W1 and W2 and we add B.
152:57 - So we get this quantity X1 W1 plus X2 W2 plus B.
153:02 - Then we have an additional step here.
153:06 - So in linear regression, we were done at this point, but in logistic regression, we have an additional step.
153:12 - We take this quantity and then we put it through this activation function called Sigma or called sigmoid.
153:20 - It's represented by this character Sigma, but it stands for sigmoid.
153:25 - What the sigmoid function does is it takes this output of this linear combination and it squishes it between the range zero to one.
153:34 - Okay. So the exact details are not very important about how this function does.
153:39 - So, but what it does is it takes this linear combination or this quantity that we get X1 W1 plus X2 W2 plus B and it squishes it into the range zero to one.
153:49 - And then that value, which we get out of the Sigma function is inferred as the probability of the class that we're trying to predict.
154:03 - So since we're trying to do a yes, no prediction, which is it will rain tomorrow or it will not rain tomorrow.
154:09 - So the output of Sigma Z output of Sigma will be a number between zero and one, and that number will indicate what our model thinks is the probability that it will rain tomorrow.
154:20 - Okay. And then we compare those probabilities with the actual values because we have historical data, we can see whether our model is predicting the right probabilities or not.
154:31 - If it is not predicting the right probabilities, then we penalize it by giving it a high loss.
154:36 - If it is predicting the right probabilities, then we penalize it, then we penalize it less by giving it a low loss.
154:42 - But overall, we come up with a loss for the model and for logistic regression, the loss is called the cross entropy loss.
154:49 - It has a formula like this. Again, the details are not that important.
154:55 - The important thing is that there is a small change in the structure of the model, which is this function Sigma.
155:00 - And then this loss is a value, which is high if the model predicts bad probabilities and the loss is low if the model predicts good probabilities.
155:10 - Okay. And then once again, we train the model in the exact same way.
155:15 - So we take the data that we have. So we take the weather data for today, put it through the model, and then we get a prediction from the model.
155:22 - We take the prediction of the model and we compare it with the actual data that we have because this is historical data of whether it will rain tomorrow.
155:30 - So we have the actual yes, no, yes, no answers of whether it will rain tomorrow.
155:34 - And we take the predictions, which are probabilities and we put them into this loss function called cross entropy.
155:40 - We run that through the optimization algorithm. Once again, the optimization algorithms like gradient descent least squares.
155:47 - There are many optimization algorithms, and that is able to then change the parameters or change the weights and biases of the model, the W1 W2, et cetera.
155:57 - So that the model now makes better predictions and gets a lower loss, right?
156:01 - So this is the same machine learning workflow that is applied, except that the details are changed.
156:07 - The model now, instead of being just a linear combination also applies a sigmoid function.
156:12 - So it outputs numbers between zero and one, and then the error, instead of being a root mean squared error is a cross entropy error, which is between these yes, no outputs and these probabilities.
156:24 - So on the one hand, the targets are like yes, no, or zero one, while the predictions are probabilities in the range of zero to one, something like 0.3, 0.7, 0.9.
156:35 - And the optimization method may also differ, but all of these parts remain the same.
156:41 - So that's logistic regression.
156:43 - And that's all we'll say about it right now, because we want to focus on how to build good logistic regression models.
156:50 - So if you do want to check out internally, how all of this works, you should once again, check out this YouTube playlist.
156:56 - It is about one hour long.
156:57 - It will go into the mathematics and also show you a more geometric interpretation and as to why it is called logistic regression, because it's solving a classification problem.
157:09 - So it's a bit confusing the name.
157:11 - The reason is that the output of this sigmoid function or the Sigma function that we have, that is a number between zero to one that is called a logistic.
157:20 - And what we're trying to do is we are trying to fit or regress that logistic to the data.
157:27 - So we're trying to get that value of between zero to one as close to one in the cases of inputs, which have the output. Yes. And as close to zero in the cases of inputs, which have the output zero.
157:39 - So in some sense, we have, even though we are working with discrete classes, yes and no, we have created this continuous quantity of the probability.
157:47 - And then we want to fit this probability as close to the desired inputs as possible.
157:52 - So that's why it's called logistic regression.
157:54 - But logistic regression is a classification algorithm.
157:57 - So just keep that in mind.
157:59 - Okay.
158:02 - So that's the machine learning workflow.
158:04 - And that's basically all the theory for today.
158:07 - Maybe if we have time at the end, we may walk through an actual logistic regression example with a few inputs.
158:14 - But roughly what you want to understand is that it is a different kind of algorithm which outputs probabilities and it uses a different error function.
158:23 - But the training process is the same and it is used for classification.
158:27 - Now classification and regression are both supervised machine learning problems because they use labeled data.
158:36 - Machine learning by label data, we mean we have some targets.
158:41 - So for classification, the target is the class that we want to assign to each input rain or no rain,
158:49 - which we already have in our dataset.
158:53 - And similarly for regression, it is the quantity that we want to predict.
158:57 - For example, the medical charges.
159:00 - Both of these are called supervised learning and you can see supervised learning have as classification and regression.
159:08 - But there are certain cases where we do not have any labels.
159:11 - And mostly what we want to do is we want to group data into clusters and that is called unsupervised learning.
159:17 - So we will also look at unsupervised learning towards the very end of this course.
159:24 - But our primary focus will be on supervised learning, which is classification and regression. Okay.

169:54 - And they will often give you a lot of interesting insights about the data.

171:42 - So that's what this tells us.
171:44 - We're getting a good sense that we have mostly uniform distribution of data across locations.
171:51 - I have also chosen color as rain today.
171:55 - So we have split these bars to show whether the value of rain today is nor yes.
172:00 - So if you roughly look at this, you can see that in Albury, there were 2300 rain today, 2300 measurements where there was no rain on those days.
172:13 - And there was 600 days where there was rain on those days.

172:49 - Yeah. On Walpole, there are quite a few days where there was rain, almost a thousand out of 2,500.
172:55 - Okay.

173:02 - So there is some correlation here for sure.

173:50 - So if the temperature is lower, it's more, it seems more likely that it would rain.
173:54 - Although there are still a decent number of examples where the temperature has been high and it has still rained, right?
174:01 - So this is how you can break down histograms specifically for classification problems.
174:06 - You can use this color argument in plot, and I'm using Plotly here, but you can, or Plotly express,
174:11 - but you can use Seaborn and there you have the hue argument.

174:33 - Yes. In how many cases is it set to?
174:35 - No.

174:44 - It seems like it did not rain.

174:53 - So this is called class imbalance.
174:55 - You have two classes, no, and yes.
174:57 - And you do not have an equal number of observations in each class.
