179:27 - All right.
179:29 - Now there is one other optional step that I would like to suggest when you're working with massive datasets, where you have millions of rows.
179:36 - We don't have it right now.
179:37 - We have a hundred thousand rows that's fairly small, relatively speaking.
179:41 - But if you have millions of rows or tens of millions of rows, it's always a good idea to initially work with a sample.
179:47 - And by a sample, we mean a fraction, a randomly picked fraction.
179:51 - And this is so that you can quickly set up your model training notebooks so that each line of code that you execute runs quickly and you're able to just try out many different ideas very quickly.
180:02 - So if you would like to work with a sample in this notebook, just set you sample equals true.
180:07 - So let's say if you said you samples equal equals true, and then we pick a fraction of the data that we want to work with.
180:12 - Then all we are doing here is we are setting raw DF, the data frame that we have created to a sample of the data frame.
180:19 - So we are setting raw DF to raw DF dot sample, and we have the fraction sample fraction dot copy.
180:25 - So we are basically taking a 10% fraction.
180:28 - And instead of using 140,000 rows, we would just be using 14,000 rows and that will make our training or our analysis much faster.
180:38 - In this case, not by so much, but if we had like 10 million rows, then it would make a lot of sense to maybe just work with a hundred thousand initially set up the notebook and then come back and change you sample back to false.
180:49 - And if it's false, then we won't pick a sample and then rerun the notebook from top to bottom.
180:53 - Okay.
180:54 - This will save you a lot of time when you're working with massive data sets.
180:57 - So always set up this, these three lines of code, you sample sample fraction and this if else condition, which you can easily switch between having a sample and working with the entire data.
181:10 - So that's a quick trick there.
181:12 - All right.
181:13 - So moving right ahead, before we train the model, we have to learn a few best practices.
181:18 - So we are going to learn a few best practices that now you will start to see coming up over and over again with every model we build.
181:25 - Now, while building real world machine learning models, it is quite common to split a dataset into three parts.
181:31 - The first part is the training set and the training set is used to train the model, which means that we take the inputs from the training set, put them into the model, which is randomly initialized with some random weights.
181:43 - We then take the outputs or the predictions of that model, compare them with the targets, the actual targets and computer loss using a loss function. And then we put them through the optimizer to change the models weights using an optimization technique.
181:56 - So that's machine learning. That's a machine learning training workflow.
181:59 - The training set is used to train the model, but remember that your model is not going to be used on the training data.
182:06 - The training data in this case, for example, is historical data, but we want to use the model on new data.
182:11 - So it will not be accurate to report the model's performance on just the training set.
182:19 - And that is why we create two other sets.
182:22 - We create a validation set and a test set.
182:25 - Now a validation set is used to evaluate the model during training because training is often not a one step process.
182:32 - Often you train a little bit and then see if you've got a good enough result, maybe train some more.
182:36 - Maybe you change some parameters in the model, maybe instead of using a logistic regression model, you use a polynomial logistic regression model, or maybe you change the optimization algorithm.
182:47 - Maybe you change from least squares to gradient descent to bilinear solver, et cetera, et cetera.
182:52 - So while you're training the model, you will want to experiment with a lot of different tweaks to the model structure itself and to the optimization process itself, or maybe even to the loss function.
183:02 - You can even change the loss function.
183:03 - So as you want to tune all of these different ways of training the model, you should be using what is called a validation set, which is simply a fraction of the dataset.
183:15 - And you shouldn't use it to train the model, but you should use it to evaluate the model, which means that once you have trained the model using the training set, you then make some predictions on the validation set and simply check what the score on the validation set is.
183:30 - So instead of now using that score to once again, train the model or improve the weights, you don't do that.
183:36 - You use just the training set for training and you use the validation set simply for checking how well the model is doing while you are still experimenting with the model.
183:46 - And picking a good validation set is an essential, a very essential, probably the most, one of the most important parts of a machine learning project, because you want your model to generalize well.
183:59 - And you can learn more about it here.
184:00 - I've linked to a blog about picking good validation sets.
184:03 - And then finally, there is a test set.
184:05 - So then there's a third set and this test set is used to compare different models or compare different approaches by different people.
184:14 - For example, you have certain data sets, which are public data sets that are used by researchers around the world.
184:21 - Now with these data sets, if everybody reports their accuracies or their performance on a different validation set, maybe somebody picks a first 10% of data.
184:33 - Somebody picks a last 10% of data.
184:35 - Somebody picks a middle 10% or a random 10%.
184:38 - Then those results will not be comparable.
184:41 - So that's why typically it's a common practice to standardize a test set for a data set.
184:47 - And you will often see that you will get a training data and then you will get a test data.
184:52 - So when you have training data, you split it into training and validation, but the test data is what is standardized and you're not supposed to use it for training.
185:00 - You're not even supposed to use it for validation.
185:02 - You should only use it at the end to report the model's final accuracy.
185:06 - And for many data sets, test sets are provided separately.
185:10 - And then in a lot of cases, for example, in Kaggle data science competitions, you are not given the actual targets for the test set.
185:18 - So you are simply given the inputs for the test set, and you have to then make some predictions for the test set, create a CSV file with your predictions, submit it to Kaggle and then Kaggle will compare them with the actual data for the test set.
185:30 - And then give you the result or give you the score.
185:33 - So this is called a hidden test set.
185:35 - And a lot of companies tend to do this as well as a data scientist.
185:38 - So once you're given a project, you're the, you will not be given the entire data.
185:44 - So you'll be given maybe 80% of the data with labels, and then you will be given another 20% of the data with the labels hidden from you.
185:51 - So you will then, once you train all your models, you will take that 20% of data and you will make predictions, give it back to whoever has given you the project and they will tell you how well your model is doing in the real world.
186:02 - Okay.
186:03 - So this is a very important piece of machine learning and you will often see when you start out with machine learning that the models that you train perform really well in training.
186:12 - You get to like 98, 99, 100% accuracy, but when you put them out into the real world, they get like 30, 40% accuracy.
186:20 - And this phenomenon is called overfitting where your model is optimizing too much for the training set.
186:26 - So to give you an analogy to think about the training validation and test set, think about how school works or how high school works.
186:34 - So now in India, we have 12 grades and in grade 12, what happens is you have a textbook and you have classes.
186:41 - So you read the textbook and in the textbook, for example, for a math scores in the textbook, you have some questions.
186:47 - So now you solve the questions in a textbook and you use that to improve your understanding of mathematics.
186:54 - And one way to do it is to actually learn the concepts, but the other way to do is to simply memorize the answers, right?
187:01 - And your model, because you are simply trying to optimize for the lowest possible laws, your model over time will start memorizing training examples.
187:09 - Just like in a lot of school systems, people start memorizing answers to questions.
187:16 - So to avoid blind memorization, what people tend to do is schools conduct exams.
187:24 - So school can schools conduct a midterm school, schools conduct quizzes.
187:27 - So they conduct exams at various places during the school year.
187:31 - And you can think of that as the validation set.
187:33 - So that is where the model or you face questions that you have not already solved.
187:39 - And obviously your performance is a little bit worse, but more importantly,
187:43 - you need to learn the actual concepts or the underlying relationships rather than simply memorizing answers, right?
187:49 - So that's a validation set, but then you have these board exams or what you might call the SATs,
187:55 - which are used to compare the performances of students across the nation or across the world, even so you can think of that as the test set.
188:02 - So that is like at the end, at the very end of your school year, you have to give this one exam and everybody in the country will be ranked based on that exam.
188:11 - So that's the training set validation set and test set training set is what you use to learn.
188:15 - Validation set is what you use to improve yourself and change your approach while you're still building a model.
188:21 - And the test set is to report your final performance.
188:24 - Okay.
188:25 - And as a general rule of thumb, this is not, this is not set in stone, but as a general rule of thumb,
188:31 - you can use about 60% of the data for training.
188:34 - You can use about 20% data for validation and 20% for test.
188:38 - And this is typically good enough if you're working with the, let's say tens of thousands of rows or hundreds of thousands.
188:44 - If you have more data, millions of rows, then you can shrink the size of your validation and test sets and use more for training.
188:51 - If you have less data, then you may have to even keep a larger fraction, but it really depends on problem to problem.
189:00 - And if a separate test set is already provided to you, let's say you're given a training set and a test set separately,
189:07 - then you can do a training validation split, which could be like a 75 25 or a 70 30 split.
189:16 - So typically this pick or this division of the validation and test set is done randomly,
189:22 - especially when the dataset does not have any inherent order.
189:25 - So if you have just random datasets or random rows in the data, it is very common practice to just pick a random subset of rows for creating the test set and the validation set.
189:34 - And this can be done using the train test split utility from scikit-learn.
189:39 - So we import from scikit-learn.model selection, train test split, and you give train test split the data that you want to split.
189:47 - So in this case, we want to split the raw DF, the entire dataset that we have.
189:51 - And we want to extract out first 20% and set that aside as the test DF.
189:56 - So as the test data frame, so I'm just setting test size equals 20%.
190:00 - Now, which 20% do we want to extract?
190:04 - So we can specify a random number and we don't have to.
190:07 - If we don't, then it will pick something automatically, but we can specify a random number.
190:12 - So in this case, I'm just specifying the number 42.
190:14 - And what this will do is this will initialize a random number generator and then using that random number generator, certain rows will be picked.
190:21 - So a certain fraction of 20% fraction of the data will be put into test DF and the remaining will be put into what I'm calling train while DF.
190:29 - Okay.
190:30 - Now the benefit of random state is that it gives you the guarantee that every time you pass 42 as the random state, the same fraction, the same 20% fraction will get picked as a test set.
190:41 - So the benefit here is that each time you rerun the notebook, your test and validation sets will not change.
190:47 - So we want a random fraction, which is picked randomly once, but we also want it to be fixed across our runs because otherwise we will not be able to compare with each run of our notebook, whether we're doing better or not.
191:00 - Right.
191:01 - So you want to pick a random fraction, but we want to fix it.
191:03 - And that's what random status for.
191:05 - Okay.
191:06 - So now we've created a test data frame, which is 20% of data.
191:09 - And then we have a training validation data frame, which is the 80% of the data.
191:12 - Now out of the 80, I once again want to do a 20 60 split, which means 25% of the remaining data becomes validation data.
191:21 - And then 20% 80% 75% of the remaining data becomes the training data.
191:27 - So I'm using train test split once again.
191:30 - And this time I'm setting the test set 2.25 and I can use a different random state, but that I, if I want, but it's okay.
191:38 - I'm just using 42 again here.
191:40 - And that's going to give me a training data frame and a validation data frame.
191:44 - So first we extracted a test data frame, then we extracted a validation data frame.
191:48 - And finally we were left with the training data frame.
191:50 - So this is how we have created three data frames and you can check their sizes.
191:54 - Training data frame now contains 84,500 data points.
191:59 - Validation data frame contains 28,000 test contains 28,000.
192:03 - Okay.
192:04 - So this is what you will do for most datasets.
192:06 - You will pick a random sample as a validation set and a random sample as a test set.
192:11 - If you're given a test set already, this will go away.
192:14 - Maybe you'll have a separate CSV file for tests.
192:16 - So you'll simply do a 75 25 split between training and validation.
192:20 - Okay.
192:21 - Now, one other thing I want to add here is when you're working with dates, which we are in this case, fortunately or unfortunately.
192:29 - So when you're working with dates, there is an additional consideration to keep in mind,
192:33 - because we want to take this model, which has been trained on historical data.
192:39 - And then we want to use it in the future.
192:42 - Okay.
192:43 - So that means that your model ideally when it is making prediction on a certain date,
192:51 - it should not have seen any data that came after that date, right?
192:56 - Because you should not train your model to learn from future data to predict past data.
193:01 - So whenever you're working with, this is called time series data, or whenever you're working with dates,
193:05 - it is often a better idea to separate training, validation, and test sets with time.
193:11 - So what you want to do is maybe if we just check out the years in the data.
193:15 - So we have, this is what the distribution of the data looks like.
193:18 - We have these many, we have a bunch of values for 2007, a bunch of them for 2008, nine, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14.
193:25 - And we are presumably going to use the model to make predictions in 2018 or 2019.
193:30 - So here is a good way to divide the training and validation and test sets.
193:34 - How about we take the data till 2014 as the training set.
193:39 - So we train the model using data till 2014.
193:43 - Then we use the data from 2015 as the validation set.
193:47 - So now the model will be evaluated on data from the future data.
193:52 - It has not already seen in the past, right?
193:54 - So we use 2015 as the validation set, and then we use 2016 and 2017 as the test set.
194:02 - So our final accuracy of the model will be reported by its performance on 2016 and 2017.
194:11 - While the model has been trained and evaluated on data till 2014 and 2015.
194:16 - The benefit of this is that because we are going to use a model in 2018 and 2019.
194:21 - So the test sets score is going to very well reflect how the model will perform in real life.
194:27 - On the other hand, let's say if you pick 2011 as the test set, then it's possible that the model
194:32 - may use some information from 2010, 2012 to become a better predictable, better predictor
194:38 - for 2011 than it would be for 2018, right?
194:42 - Because it has access to data from the past as well as the future.
194:45 - So what I want to want you to take away from this is whenever you're working with dates
194:50 - or with time series data, it's often a good idea to take the last fraction as the test set and maybe
194:56 - a fraction just before that as the validation set.
194:59 - Okay.
195:00 - So that's what I'm going to do.
195:02 - I have created this year column.
195:04 - So I'm going to convert raw DF dot date to a date time series, and then I'm going to get the year out of it.
195:11 - And for the training data frame.
195:14 - So I'm going to ignore what I created earlier, all of these data frames using random splitting.
195:19 - But for the training data frame, I'm just going to use the data before 2015 for the validation data frame.
195:25 - I'm going to use data just from 2015 and from the test data frame, I'm going to use the data after 2015.
195:32 - So 2016 and 17 are going to be the test set validation is going to be 2015 and training is going to be before 2015.
195:39 - And this is what the split looks like.
195:41 - So it's not a perfect 60, 20, 20 split, but we have still ensured that the test validation, that the validation and test set.
195:50 - Both contains both contain data for at least 12 months or entire calendar year, which means they see all the seasonality and they occur in the future after the training data.
195:59 - So which will more accurately reflect our models performance in the real world.
196:04 - So the whole purpose of test training, validation, et cetera, is to create a model.
196:09 - Whose performance can be reliably measured on how it will perform in the real world, right?
196:14 - We don't just want to get a higher accuracy just for the sake of reporting it.
196:18 - We want to create models that work well in the real world.
196:21 - And that's why we do all these splits.
196:24 - So that's your training set.
196:25 - Now the first eight years of data, the first seven and seven years of data, then we validation set the next one year of data.
196:32 - And then the next year and a half of data is the test set.
196:36 - Okay.
196:38 - If you do not have dates, then pick a random 60, 20, 20 sample.
196:43 - All right.
196:44 - And I'm just going to save my notebook once again and record another snapshot.
196:48 - Now, some of what we have done here may seem a little complex may seem, it's not something that you may be able to grasp in the first glance, but do work through the notebook or do go through every line of code.
197:01 - All of it is explained and you can check out, you can separate out each line into a separate cell and try and work through it and see how it works out.
197:11 - So next best practice or next step in a machine learning problem is to identify the input and target columns.
197:19 - And often this is something that people tend to mess up as well.
197:22 - Just in the hurry to get to the modeling process.
197:26 - So not all columns in a dataset are useful for training a model.
197:29 - In fact, in the current dataset, if we look at raw DF, you can see here that we have a date column and the date column is different for each day.
197:41 - In fact, it only contains dates from 2008 to 2017.
197:44 - Now, presumably we're going to use the model in 2020 or 2021 and onwards.
197:49 - So the date will never be something like this, right?
197:54 - So the model will, so there's no point training the model on these dates or dates, which it has seen in the past.
198:03 - If it is going to be used in the future, right?
198:05 - So date is not a useful input to the model.
198:09 - On the other hand, minimum temperature definitely is because the model is going to see temperatures in the same ranges.
198:14 - It may see, it may not see 13.4, but it may see 13.5.
198:18 - It may see 13.1.
198:19 - So this is a useful thing to have maximum temperature is again, a useful thing to have.
198:23 - So all of these rows, apart from date, like location, main temp, max temp, et cetera, these are definitely useful for a prediction.
198:31 - So we definitely want to use these.
198:33 - Similarly, sometimes you will have ID columns.
198:35 - For example, in the last example of insurance or medical charges prediction, there was certain IDs.
198:42 - Sometimes you will have names of people like you, you may have names of a customer or maybe you may have emails of customers or you may have like a customer ID.
198:52 - Or some unique identifier, which is different for every row.
198:56 - So whenever you have these ID columns, you should completely ignore those because those are just unique.
199:02 - And that is not useful information to use.
199:05 - Then there is obviously also a target column, the column that we want to predict.
199:09 - We want to take all of this information and we want to use it to predict the rain tomorrow column.
199:15 - So we want to make sure that we don't use the rain tomorrow column as an input for sure.
199:20 - Right?
199:21 - You don't want to use a weather train tomorrow to predict whether it rain tomorrow.
199:25 - You don't the rain tomorrow is a target.
199:27 - And that is why, and it seems like an obvious thing, but in a lot of cases, you will see that you are training a model and then you train the model and you suddenly see a hundred percent accuracy, a hundred percent training accuracy, a hundred percent validation, a hundred percent test accuracy.
199:41 - And you debug and debug, or maybe you just think you've won, but ultimately you will figure out that you were actually using the target as an input.
199:49 - I do this all the time whenever I'm training models.
199:51 - So that's why one thing you should try and do is very clearly identify what are the inputs to your model and what are the outputs and what are the things you need to ignore.
200:00 - So I'm going to create two lists here.
200:02 - One is a list of input columns.

202:02 - So you want to make sure that and rain tomorrow is rainfall tomorrow is going to be a very strong indicator of rain tomorrow, but at the same time, it is derived information from rain tomorrow.

208:46 - Now, machine learning models cannot work with missing data.
208:49 - Whenever you have a nan and you try to train a machine learning model, it's probably going to crash.
208:54 - So you need to fill these missing values with some valid values.
208:58 - And the process of filling missing values is called imputation.
209:02 - Now there are several techniques for imputation, but we will use the most basic technique here.
209:07 - And I'll let you check out some of the other techniques and we will try out some other techniques over time.
209:12 - But the most basic technique is to replace missing values with the average value in the column.
209:18 - And you can do this using the simple imputed class from SK learn dot impute.
209:22 - So what we want to do is we want to replace this nan with the average value in this column.
209:27 - And I think the average in this column, if we have just three rows is 17 plus five, 22 by two 11.
209:31 - So we have 11 here and the average in this column is six.
209:34 - So we have six here.
209:35 - The average in this column is just seven.
209:37 - So we'll just put seven here.
209:39 - So this is just a guess.
209:40 - It's obviously may not be correct, but you have a choice here.
209:44 - You can either throw away those rows, but if you have a lot of nan values in a certain column and you throw away those rows, you may lose a lot of data.
209:51 - So you just take a guess there and you think that, okay, maybe I replace it with the average.
209:56 - Sometimes you may choose to replace it with not, not the average, but maybe a fixed value and it can do that as well.
210:02 - Simple imputer has several strategies.
210:05 - Sometimes you may replace it by the mean.
210:07 - If you are by the median, if you think that there are outliers that may affect the average.
210:11 - For example, if you have an income column, it's always a good idea to replace it with a, with the median rather than the mean, because there will be outliers that may affect the average.
210:24 - Okay.
210:25 - So many different strategies we are going to use a simple strategy of filling in nan values with the average value in that column.

215:57 - Okay.

216:00 - Another good practice is to scale features to a small range of values.
216:06 - Right now, if you check the numeric features or the numeric columns of data, you will see that they have a fairly wide range.
216:12 - For example, min temperature goes from minus eight to 33.
216:15 - On the other hand, wind speed goes from six to 135.
216:20 - I think this is min and this is max.
216:22 - Let's see your pressure at 3PM.
216:28 - Okay.
216:29 - This seems to go all the way up to 1039 and the minimum seems to be 977.
216:34 - Now what's what happens is when you put all these numbers into machine learning algorithm and you apply weights to them and then you compute a loss function.
216:43 - Ultimately, the loss is a single number, right?
216:45 - The cross entropy or root mean square loss.
216:47 - The loss is a single number and we say that higher the loss, worse the model.
216:53 - But what happens is if a certain feature has a very high range of values, maybe like rainfall takes values that are in the thousands.
217:01 - But minimum and maximum temperature rate take values that are in less than 10.
217:05 - And maybe there are certain.
217:06 - There's a certain column where the values are 0.00 point something, which are basically in the range of values.
217:13 - Are 0.00 point something, which are basically in the decimals.
217:18 - So what happens is that the values, which have a very high magnitude tend to dominate the loss because it's ultimately all, all these numbers getting multiplied and added together.
217:28 - So the values that have a high magnitude, the features that have a high range tend to dominate the loss, but features that have a lower absolute values and features that have lower range of values.
217:40 - Tend to not show up in the loss as much.
217:43 - So what happens is that if what dominates the loss also dominates the optimization process.
217:48 - So that means the values which have these high numbers are going to their rates are going to change a lot, but the values which have low numbers or smaller ranges, their value, their rates are not going to change that much during optimization.
218:00 - So just to give everybody a level playing field, just because we measure rainfall in a certain unit where it gets large values, but we measure a temperature in a certain unit where it gets lower values.
218:11 - So just to level the playing field for all the features, what we like to do is we should scale all the features into a same range of values.
218:18 - So we're going to scale the features of, we're going to scale all the numeric features into the range of value zero to one.
218:24 - And sometimes this is also minus one to one.
218:27 - Either one is fine. It depends on the circumstances, but zero to one is fine for classification problems.
218:34 - And you, and the way you do this is using a min max scaler.
218:39 - So from SK learn dot pre-processing, this is again another module.
218:43 - And we are, in fact, what we're doing right now is called pre-processing from a scaler under pre-processing import min max scaler.
218:49 - And then you create a min max scaler and then you can give it some options.
218:54 - Like you can give it, you can check here.
218:58 - It supports like a feature range.
219:00 - It supports whether it should create a copy of the data, et cetera, et cetera.
219:04 - But the objective of the min max scaler is to identify for each column.
219:08 - What is the minimum and what is the maximum and then scale the values in the column so that they all line the range zero to one.
219:16 - So it's a two step process, just like the imputer.
219:19 - First, we fit the scaler to the data.
219:22 - So we compute the range of values for each numeric column.
219:25 - So we say scaler dot fit raw DF numeric column.
219:28 - So what's happening here is it's going to look at each column from raw DF, the entire data frame, main temperature, max temperature, rainfall, evaporation, et cetera.
219:38 - It's going to look at each column and it's going to find the minimum and maximum of each column when we run scaler dot fit.
219:46 - So now we have, if we check the minimum, we can say that the data minimum in, you can see that for these columns, for the numeric columns, which are.
219:59 - Min temp, max temp, rainfall, et cetera.
220:01 - The minimum values are minus 8.5 minus 4.8, zero, zero, et cetera.
220:06 - And then for the maximum values, the maximum values are 33, 48, 375, 371, 145, et cetera.
220:12 - So now it knows the minimum and the maximum.
220:14 - And this is stored in data main and data max.
220:17 - Now, when we call scaler dot transform, what it's going to do is it's going to take this column.
220:24 - And instead of these being in the range minimum to maximum, it is going to scale them in the range zero to one.
220:29 - So the minimum value will become zero.
220:31 - The maximum value will become one and everything else will be scaled proportionately.
220:35 - So let's do that.
220:37 - It's a pretty simple transformation ultimately.
220:39 - So let's not let's not check train inputs.
220:42 - I think we can just check this here.
220:45 - We can just call describe and you can check for each of the columns.
220:48 - Now for each of the numeric columns, you will see that the minimum becomes a zero or very close to zero.
220:54 - You can see all of these are very close to zero and the maximum becomes one or very close to one.
221:01 - So in this case, you can see that the maximum is 0.56, 0.98.
221:07 - Yeah, it either becomes one or very close to one.
221:09 - In some cases, it may not actually be one because of how internally the imputer works,
221:14 - but you can also verify this by looking at the actual data instead of just the statistics
221:19 - that now all of these values are nice and small.
221:23 - All of these values are between zero to one.
221:25 - Okay.
221:26 - All the numerical columns for sure.
221:31 - Okay.
221:32 - So now we have all our numeric data between the range zero to one.
221:37 - So none of them will disproportionately affect the loss.
221:40 - And another thing is also that optimization algorithms often use calculus and calculus involves derivatives
221:46 - and powers of functions and polynomials.
221:49 - So all of these optimization algorithms also work really well when all the numbers are small in the zero to one range.
221:56 - And there are also issues with numerical methods where they cross floating point computation ranges.
222:03 - So if numbers get too large, then decimal information can be lost.
222:07 - And there's a lot of bunch of issues with large numbers, especially when you're working with these numerical optimization methods.
222:14 - So it's always a good idea to get your numbers into a small range.
222:18 - Okay.
222:20 - This one is about categorical data.
222:22 - Now we are numerical data is in good shape.
222:24 - Messing values have been filled and the data is in a good zero to one range because machine learning models can only be trained with numeric data.
222:32 - We also need to convert categorical data to numbers.
222:35 - So a common technique is to use the one hot encoding for categorical columns.
222:40 - So you take a categorical column, like a column, which has maybe a category, a category, B category, C.
222:45 - And what do you do is you get rid of this column and you instead create a column for each category.
222:50 - So category A becomes a column.
222:52 - Cat B becomes a column.
222:53 - Cat C becomes a column and whichever row had the value category A in this categorical column.
223:00 - We put a one there in the category column and we put zeros in all the other columns.
223:03 - So that's why this is called a one hot vector.
223:06 - So instead of this category string or this category class, we replace it with a vector,
223:13 - which contains a one for that particular columns for that particular categories column and zeros everywhere else.
223:20 - Similarly, we have category B.
223:22 - This is also one hot vector.
223:23 - Now this becomes zero one zero and category C becomes zero zero one.
223:27 - Now here, there are only three categories, but you can have any number of categories.
223:30 - For example, if we check the number of unique categories for location, we have 49 categories for wind gust direction.
223:37 - We have 16 wind direction, nine AM we have 16.
223:40 - And for rain today, we have two categories.
223:42 - So now if we want to perform one hot encoding, what we are actually trying to say is that if I just look at the location data.
223:50 - What we're actually trying to say is that we want to create one column in the data for Albury,
223:55 - Badgley Creek, Cobar, et cetera, and put ones and zeros in these columns.
223:59 - So we're going to introduce 49 columns for location.
224:02 - Now that may seem like a lot, but it's okay.
224:05 - It's not a problem because most of these are just going to be zero one.
224:08 - And then most of the time they're going to be zero one.
224:10 - And then most of the time they're going to be zero one.
224:12 - And then most of the time they're going to be zero one.
224:14 - And then most of the time they're going to be zero one.
224:16 - So it's not something to worry about too much.
224:20 - And our data frame can handle it.
224:23 - So how do we create these one hot encoded columns?
224:27 - The way to do that is using a one hot encoder again, from a skill or not pre-processing import one hot encoder.
224:33 - And I hope, I hope you're starting to get the drill.
224:35 - Now for all of these pre-processing steps, you create that object.
224:38 - So we are creating a one hot encoder.
224:40 - And we're giving it a bunch of options. We're telling it that we want to, don't want to create a sparse matrix.
224:46 - We want to actually create a proper NumPy array.
224:48 - So sparse is just an optimization technique.
224:51 - And we are saying that if you come across a category that is, that you haven't seen before, just ignore it.
224:56 - Then there are several other options that it supports.
Okay.
224:58 - So we create the encoder object.
225:00 - Then the encoder needs to first understand the data.
225:03 - So we call an encoder.
225:05 - fit, and at this point it's not creating any one hot encodings. It's simply identifying the categories in the data.
225:10 - So we, okay.
225:23 - So I think this needs to be fixed somehow.

233:04 - And finally, after all of that, we are finally ready to train the logistic regression model.
233:10 - Okay.
233:11 - This may seem like we've done a lot of work, but actually it's just been three or four
233:14 - steps, which is identifying the drop, identifying the inputs and the targets and identifying
233:23 - numeric and categorical columns, converting, filling missing values in numerical columns,
233:28 - filling imputing, yeah, that was through imputation, then scaling numeric columns to the zero to
233:36 - one range.
233:37 - And then we also replace the categorical columns with one hot vectors.
233:42 - So these are just four or five pre-processing steps that we've performed.
233:45 - And now we have our data in the form where most of it is numeric data.
233:50 - Like if you have, if I check train inputs, yeah.
233:56 - So we have, we still have these categorical columns, which we will probably get rid of
233:59 - while actually training the model, but we have numeric data for the numeric columns.
234:04 - And then the categorical columns have also be converted into numeric data.
234:07 - So now we're ready to train the model and logistic regression, as I've already mentioned
234:11 - is a common technique for solving binary classification problems.
234:15 - We take a linear combination or a weighted sum of the input features.
234:18 - That's why we need them all to be numeric.
234:21 - And that's why we also need them all to be in similar ranges so that they don't mess
234:24 - up one feature does not mess up the loss.
234:28 - Then we take that weighted combination and we apply the sigmoid function, which ultimately
234:33 - gives us a number between zero to one for each input.
234:36 - So for each set of inputs for each specific row of data, we get a number as zero between
234:42 - zero and one as the output of the model.
234:44 - The number represents a probability of the input being classified as yes.
234:48 - So that's how we interpret the number from the model.
234:50 - Then we use the cross entropy loss to evaluate how good the probability is with respect to
234:56 - the results.
234:57 - Now, obviously intuitively, what we want is if the target is yes or one, then we want
235:04 - the probability to be high, very close to one.
235:07 - If the target is no or zero, then we want the probability to be no.
235:11 - And that's what this formula captures.
235:13 - This is called cross entropy.
235:14 - We won't get into it, but the idea is it penalizes bad predictions.
235:20 - Okay.
235:21 - And then we train it using the normal machine learning training process.
235:27 - So here's how we train a logistic regression model.
235:29 - The actual model training part is so simple that you simply import logistic regression
235:35 - from a skill or not linear model.
235:37 - And then you train logistic regression.
235:39 - Now here, if I hover over it here, you should be able to see that there are a lot of different
235:44 - arguments that we can pass the kind of penalty.
235:47 - There's something called a dual, something called a C, something called a tolerance fit,
235:50 - intercept, et cetera, et cetera.
235:52 - You can even specify random state.
235:54 - You can provide weights for the different classes.
235:57 - You can specify the number of iterations.
235:59 - So these are all parameters that you can change.
236:01 - And remember I was talking about the validation set.
236:04 - So each time you try a different kind of model with a different set of parameters, you can
236:08 - use a validation set to judge whether those parameters set led to a good result or not.
236:13 - Okay.

236:19 - what kind of solvers it supports.

237:33 - want.

238:05 - weights of the model.

238:12 - Then we repeat the steps one to four till the predictions from the model are good enough.
238:16 - So if you see here, if I see logistic regression, you will see that there is this max.
238:22 - Itter.
238:23 - This is the maximum number of iterations that we want the model to take.
238:27 - So here, what we are telling the model is that we want to repeat this process of creating
238:31 - predictions, comparing them with the targets, running some optimization a hundred times
238:36 - at most, or we want to stop at a point where the tolerance or where the loss gets lower
238:43 - than a particular value of 0.001, right?

238:50 - max iterations and reduce the value of tolerance, make the tolerance lower.
238:55 - And that way it will go on for longer.
238:56 - It will take more time, but maybe it will learn better.

249:41 - of matching values in train preds and train targets.

250:16 - It's going to do a one by one match between train targets and train predictions.
250:20 - It's going to count the matches divided by the total number of values.
250:23 - And that gives us an accuracy of 85.1% on the training set.

251:54 - matrix.

252:10 - So the actual value was no.
252:11 - And the model predicted.
252:12 - Yes.
252:13 - We call that a true.
252:14 - And then, and the model predicted, no, so if the actual value was no, and the model
252:18 - predicted, no, we call that a true negative, which means it was able to identify a negative
252:22 - correctly that it will not rain correctly.
252:25 - And similarly, if the actual value is yes, and your model predicted, yes, we call that
252:31 - a true positive, which means that it is going to rain tomorrow and your model did, it did
252:36 - predict that it is going to rain tomorrow.
252:38 - So we call that a true positive.
252:41 - So these are both cases in which your model has succeeded.
252:43 - These are both the success scenarios.
252:46 - Then there are two types of scenarios, error scenarios, and they are called the type one
252:50 - error and type two error, or false positive and false negative.
252:54 - Once we have false positive.
252:55 - So false positive is when it is not going to rain tomorrow or the actual value is no,
253:01 - but your model has predicted yes.
253:05 - So model has predicted that yes, it is going to rain tomorrow.
253:08 - And then similarly here, we have a false negative when the, where the actual value is, yes,
253:14 - it is going to rain tomorrow, but your model has predicted no.
253:17 - Now, depending on the business case or what you want to use the model for, you may want
253:22 - to very closely look at false positives or false negatives.
253:26 - For example, if you want to use this model to predict whether a baseball game should
253:32 - be hosted tomorrow in the open, then false negatives are a big problem.
253:38 - You may want to avoid false negatives where it is going to rain tomorrow, but your model
253:42 - predicts that it is not going to rain.
253:44 - So if you have a high number of false negatives, that means you are in for a surprise where
253:48 - you get 50,000 people and people are playing baseball and starts to rain.
253:53 - That's why maybe you want to optimize.
253:55 - You want to reduce the false negatives and you're not just interested in the accuracy.
254:00 - On the other hand, let's say it's a different kind of model, which is predicting whether
254:05 - you may have best breast cancer.
254:07 - Then at that point, you may want to take a close look at false positives before let's
254:13 - say recommending, I don't know, chemotherapy to somebody.
254:17 - You want to make sure that your model, you want to make sure that it is not a false positive.
254:21 - And for that while training the model, you want to make sure that the number of false
254:24 - positives is low.
254:25 - So in general, depending on the kind of problem you may want to optimize either for false
254:30 - positives or for false negatives.
254:32 - And how to do that is something that we will discuss in future lessons.
254:37 - But just keep this in mind that this is called the confusion matrix.
254:40 - And again, SK learn gives you a single line of code to create a confusion matrix.
254:45 - Like you just give it some targets and some predictions, and it is going to give you confusion
254:50 - matrix and it's also going to convert them into percentages.
254:53 - So here, what it tells you is among the actual yeses, which means the among the actual noes,
254:59 - which means all the days where rainfall was actually supposed to be no, it predicted no
255:04 - in 94% of the cases and it, it predicted yes in 5% of the cases.
255:10 - And then here, it tells you that among the cases where it was actually going to rain,
255:15 - it predicted, no, it predicted that it won't rain in 47% of cases.
255:20 - So that means your model is actually pretty bad.
255:21 - It has a lot of false negatives and you should probably not use it for deciding whether you
255:26 - should hold a baseball game in the open tomorrow.
255:31 - And it was 52% of the time when it was going to rain, it has predicted, right?
255:35 - So just by looking at this now 85% accuracy doesn't seem all that good because it seems
255:39 - like if it is going to rain tomorrow and really that's what we're all concerned about whether
255:45 - you should carry on your umbrella or not, your model's performance seems to be 50 50
255:50 - more or less, right?
255:51 - It's a bit more confident than a random guess.
255:53 - It's about 0.5 to, but it's not that great, right?
255:57 - So if the model says that it's not going to rain tomorrow, I'm probably not that sure
256:03 - if I can.
256:04 - So if the model says that, yeah, the model said that it's not going to rain tomorrow.
256:09 - I don't know because if it is going to rain tomorrow, there is still a 47% chance that
256:14 - the model says that it's not going to rain tomorrow, right?
256:17 - So look at these numbers, spend some time looking at this matrix and you can, what you
256:21 - can do is you can convert this matrix into a nice heat map.
256:26 - This confusion matrix can be converted into a nice heat map and you can, then you can
256:29 - start to interpret this heat map.
256:30 - Dark values means, especially in these negative regions means that's good.
256:36 - And like bright values here indicate that this is probably a bad area for the model.
256:42 - Right?
256:43 - So yeah, that's a confusion matrix.
256:45 - And what we've done is we've simply created this predict and plot function, which can
256:51 - take some inputs and take some targets and it will predict, generate the predictions
256:56 - for those targets using the model.
256:58 - It will compute the accuracy.
257:00 - It will print the accuracy.

257:04 - Okay.
257:05 - So this is how you analyze the results of a model.
257:08 - So in this case, it has about 85% accuracy on the training set.
257:12 - Let's validate this.
257:13 - Let's check it on the validation set.

257:19 - with the validation data and the validation targets.

257:27 - So that's good.

257:33 - That's good.
257:35 - Let's check the test set.

257:41 - year.

257:45 - It's about 84.2%.
257:47 - All right, so now you can start to see that how the training and validation and test sets
257:53 - are useful.
257:54 - If the test set accuracy was 30%, that means the model is very badly overfitted to the
257:58 - training data.
257:59 - But since it is quite close, it's about 84% and training is 85%.
258:04 - You can accurately just go back and report to your boss or whoever gave you the project
258:09 - that, Hey, my model is about 84% accurate, although it does have a lot of false negatives.
258:15 - So please don't use it to decide if you should do something in the open tomorrow.
258:21 - Okay.
258:23 - Now one thing you might wonder is how good is 84% accuracy.
258:29 - And while this depends on the nature of the problem and on the business requirements,
258:34 - a good way to verify whether a model has actually learned something useful is to compare its
258:39 - result to a random or a dumb model, right?
258:42 - So for example, let's create two models.
258:45 - We'll create a model called random guests, which takes some inputs like the training
258:48 - inputs or validation inputs, and it completely ignores the inputs and it randomly picks
258:53 - yes or no.

259:02 - And this is a model that just says that it's not going to rain.
259:05 - It always says that it's not going to rain.

259:13 - guests on X well, which is the data from the validation set, you see that it, it, half
259:20 - of them are nos and half of them are yeses.
259:23 - And on the other hand, if I use all no on the X, you see that this always returns no.
259:31 - Okay.

259:38 - And one thing that you should always try and do is take your brilliant machine learning
259:42 - model that you've created after all this pre-processing, et cetera, et cetera, and compare it to a baseline
259:48 - model like this, something like a random guess or all no.
259:51 - So let's do that.
259:52 - Let's compute the accuracy for the test data or the test set using the random guest model.
260:00 - So we give it the X test that gives us the predictions for the random guests from the
260:04 - random guest model and compare that with targets.
260:07 - Oh, so a random guest gives us about a 50% accuracy.
260:11 - Does that make sense?
260:13 - Because you have a certain, you have two outcomes.
260:15 - And if you just guess randomly, 50%, you would, you're like any given input, you have a 50%
260:23 - chance of getting it right roughly, so to speak.
260:27 - But if you are more intelligent, if you were to always get, always say no, then what would
260:34 - you get?
260:35 - Then your model would have a 77% accuracy.
260:39 - And this is because in the dataset, remember there's an imbalance.
260:43 - So on 77% of days, there was no rain and only on 23% of days there was rain.
260:49 - So just by predicting that there was no rain, your model achieves an accuracy of 77%.
260:55 - Now thankfully the model that we have created has an accuracy of 85 or 84%, which is definitely
261:03 - better than 77%.
261:05 - But this is not always the case, and you will often find that once you train a model and
261:09 - do all of this analysis and create all these features and normalization, et cetera, et
261:13 - cetera.
261:14 - And after all that, you get a model that's worse than a dumb model like this, like it's
261:20 - that there are definitely ways in which we could have created a logistic regression model
261:24 - that was maybe a 65% accurate.
261:27 - So that means that your model is worse than simply predicting no, always, right?
261:32 - So always analyze your models against these dumb or very simplistic baselines and make
261:39 - sure that it makes sense.
261:40 - And now you may say, okay, if 77 is so easy to get, then I don't know if 84% is something
261:45 - that is worth putting all this effort for, right?

262:12 - kind of beaten a human.

262:25 - and you are beating maybe the average of their predictions.

272:08 - And that is what machine learning is.
272:09 - It is about taking data and using data to make predictions, but how do you make predictions
272:15 - from data?
272:16 - You assume a certain relationship between the inputs, which is the weather information
272:22 - for today and the output, which is whether it will rain tomorrow.
272:26 - And that relationship is called the model.
272:28 - And that model has some inherent parameters called weights of the model, which are initially
272:32 - randomly initialized.

272:38 - the actual data.

272:43 - the next day for the last 10 years.
272:46 - And using that comparison, computer loss, reduce the loss using an optimization technique,
272:51 - make the models parameters better.
272:53 - And as the model gets better, then you evaluate the model, you interpret the model, and then
272:57 - you use the model in the real world.
272:59 - This is used for weather prediction.
273:01 - This is used for predicting whether somebody will default on a loan.
273:04 - This can be used for predicting if a certain tumor will cause cancer.

273:16 - for predicting, for recognizing pictures of cats and dogs, logistic regression.

274:36 - at the data anymore.

275:38 - maybe a thousand numbers, but still these very dense representations, which is the sort
275:43 - of the intelligence of the data and can be used to make predictions.

302:23 - So now we've done most of this before, so let's go over this quickly.
302:28 - We will perform some steps to prepare the dataset for training.
302:31 - The first step is to create a training test and validation split.
302:36 - Remember it's common practice to set aside only about 60% of the data for training the model.
302:43 - And then we use 10, 20% of the data for validation, which is to evaluate different versions of the model as we try out different parameters to train the model.
302:55 - And finally, to report the final accuracy, we use the test set.
302:58 - Now it's common practice to do a random split, but in this case, because the data is ordered by date and because the model that we are going to create using this data is going to be used in the future, we can simulate that, which is using the model train on the past to the, to predict values in the future by picking the last couple of years for the test set.
303:21 - And we can maybe pick one year before that for the validation set, and then all of this data can be used for the training set.
303:28 - So this is the distribution of the number of rows per, uh, and we've done that using a simple count plot using seaborn.
303:35 - So here's what we'll do.
303:36 - We will create a train data frame, which is a fraction of this rows of the raw data frame, which we just loaded up where the year is less than 2015.
303:46 - And here is how we've converted the year.
303:49 - We have taken the date column, raw DF dot date, and we have passed it as a date time field, each value in the column, and from that date time field, we have extracted the year.
303:59 - So this is basic pandas date operations that you should check out if you're not familiar with this already.

312:24 - replacing them with the average of that column.

312:34 - strategy that we want to use strategy is mean.

312:57 - Now, once you've fitted the imputer, which means once it has found the averages or the statistic that we want to use.

313:22 - We can take that new result and put it back into the original data frame, train inputs and replace the original numeric columns.
313:31 - Okay.

314:11 - Okay.
314:12 - Next up, we are going to scale the numeric features scaling simply means we want to take the ranges of each of the numeric features, which is the min and the max.
314:21 - And we want to bring them down into a zero to one range.
314:25 - As you can see here in the validation training or test dataset, each numeric feature has a different range min temp is minus eight to plus 31 and wind speed is seven to 135.
314:37 - Whereas certain values like pressure can be like 988 to 1039.
314:43 - So because there are a lot of numerical computations that happen inside a machine learning algorithm and ultimately a single loss value is optimized.
314:52 - We don't want the data to have any, we don't want any specific feature to dominate the training process.
315:00 - We want to give every feature a level playing field to participate in the training of the model.
315:05 - And that is why we scale all of these feature values to the range zero to one.
315:09 - And we do that using min max scalar.
315:12 - So here we are creating a min max scalar, and then we call on min max scalar fit and we give it the numerical columns.
315:19 - The data from all the numerical columns.
315:21 - So it is going to figure out for each column, what is the minimum and the maximum value.
315:26 - And then we can call scalar dot transform, give it all the data from the numeric columns, and it is going to scale them into the zero to one range.
315:35 - And then we can take that output and put it back into our training validation and test data frames.
315:44 - So the net result of all of this is the minimum and the maximum value.
315:48 - So the net result of all of this is that the inputs are going to change from a variety of different ranges to the zero to one range.
316:09 - Now the zero to one range is not the only scaling strategy.
316:13 - There are several other scaling strategies as well.

323:11 - Let's talk about training and visualizing decision trees.
323:15 - A decision tree in general parlance represents a hierarchical set of binary decisions.
323:20 - For example, here is a kind of decision tree that you may set up to decide whether or not you accept a job offer.
323:29 - Maybe if the salary is between 50,000 to $80,000, then you will be able to accept a job offer.
323:37 - If the salary is between 50,000 to $80,000, then you, then you consider the offer.
323:44 - If it is not between 50 to $80,000, maybe you decline the offer.
323:48 - If it is between 50 to $80,000, then maybe you check if the office is close to your home.
323:55 - If it is not, then you decline the offer.
323:57 - Otherwise you check if the office, if the company provides a cab facility, and if it, if it doesn't, then maybe you decline the offer.
324:06 - Otherwise you accept the offer.
324:08 - So this kind of a strategy is how we make a lot of decisions in the real world.
324:14 - In fact, this is how a lot of processes are set up.
324:16 - And if you think carefully, this is how programs are also set up or where we write a lot of if-else, if-else statements to come to a certain decision.
324:27 - Now a decision tree in machine learning works exactly the same way, except that we let the computer figure out the optimal structure and hierarchy of decisions instead of coming up with the criteria manually.
324:40 - So applying it to our problem about whether or not it will rain tomorrow.
324:43 - First, we'll set, we let the computer figure out what is the most important criteria to decide whether or not it will rain tomorrow.
324:51 - And maybe after checking the value of that criteria, let's say maybe it's whether it rained today or not, there is a different tree on where based on whether it rained today and a different tree or based on whether it did not rain today.
325:04 - So if it did, if it did rain today, then maybe we simply look at the pressure.
325:09 - And if it did not rain today, maybe we look at the wind speed at 3PM.
325:12 - And so on, right?
325:14 - So you can have multiple trees on either side, and we will see how these trees come up, but the important point is we are not creating those trees.
325:22 - We are letting the machine learning model figure out what the right criteria and the right decision points are going to be to best fit the model.
325:32 - Okay. And to train a decision tree, we simply import the decision tree classifier model from scikit-learn.tree to train a decision tree.
325:44 - Now why decision tree classifier?
325:46 - Because this is a classification problem.
325:49 - Remember there are two types of problems classification and regression in regression.
325:53 - You're trying to predict a continuous value, which is, for example, the medical charges for an insurance application.
326:01 - But in classification, you're trying to classify the input into one of two categories.
326:05 - For instance, here, we're trying to classify the measurements given today based on to whether or not it will rain tomorrow.
326:11 - So yes or no.
326:14 - So that's why we're using a decision tree classifier.
326:15 - If it was a regression problem, we can use a decision tree regressor.
326:20 - So from scikit-learn.tree, we import decision tree classifier, and then we create the decision tree model.
326:33 - So we create the decision tree model by simply creating an object of the class decision tree classifier.
326:39 - And there is some randomness involved in how decision trees work.
326:44 - So if you want to get the same output each time you run this code, just provide a value for random state.
326:51 - So random state 42.
326:52 - So this is initializing the random number generator inside the decision tree.
326:56 - So each time you run this code, you will get the same kind of randomization and health, hence the same kind of outputs.
327:04 - Now, if you do not want to have the same kind of output each time you run this code,
327:08 - then you can remove this random state, but it is generally recommended to have a random state.
327:15 - And you can pick this to be any number you want, but it is generally recommended to have a random
327:19 - state for your decision tree classifier so that you can replicate your results.
327:23 - Otherwise your results will not be replicable.
327:27 - All right.
327:27 - So now we've created the model and the next step is to fit the model.
327:31 - So we give the model the training data, which is all the numerical columns, which have been
327:36 - imputed and which have been scaled to the range zero to one, and we give it the targets, which
327:41 - is simply the yes, no value for whether it will rain tomorrow for each of the input columns.
327:48 - And we run that and it takes maybe a second, maybe a couple of seconds.
327:53 - So it took 2.8 seconds and our decision tree classifier has been trained.

331:01 - number of matches. I'm going to run accuracy score on train preds and train targets.

331:16 - accuracy of the model on the training set on which it has been trained is 99.99%. So practically
331:23 - a hundred percent, this could just be a floating point error. So the accuracy is now is close to
331:28 - a hundred percent. And the decision tree also returns probabilities for each production for
