331:57 - one for all the, for most of the predictions. And you can verify if this is actually true
332:01 - throughout or not. So it seems like we've learned everything there is to learn from this data.
332:08 - Or is that so the training set accuracy is close to a hundred percent, but we can't rely
332:13 - solely on the training set accuracy because your model will not be used in the real world
332:18 - on the same training data. In the real world, your model will see data that it has not seen before.
332:25 - And so far it hasn't seen the validation set. So we must evaluate the model on the validation set.
332:30 - So now we need to make predictions on the validation set by calling model dot predict.
332:35 - And then we can compare the validation set predictions, which are obtained from the validation
332:41 - inputs with the validation targets using the score accuracy score function. But because this
332:49 - is such a common operation, scikit-learn models already have a dot score method. So in the case
332:55 - of decision trees, if you call model dot score, give it the input. So in this case, the validation
333:00 - inputs and give it the targets, then it will make a prediction on the, it'll make predictions on
333:06 - the validation inputs. And it will then compare those predictions with the targets and it will
333:11 - give you the accuracy here. And it turns out that the accuracy on the validation set is just 79.2%.
333:18 - So you can see that the accuracy on the training set was a hundred percent, as we saw here,
333:24 - 99.99% and the accuracy on the validation set is just about 79%. And in fact, 79% is only
333:32 - marginally, only marginally better than always predicting. No, for example, if you look at the
333:38 - validation data and we see the percentage of values that are no, which is by getting the value
333:44 - counts and then dividing that by the length of the validation data set. So it turns out that 78.8%
333:51 - of the data is, has the target. No. And 21% of the data has the target. Yes. Which means if we had
334:00 - a model that simply predicted no all the time, that would be 78.8% accurate. And our fancy
334:06 - decision tree that we've trained, which is a hundred percent accurate on the training set
334:10 - is only marginally better, just less than 1% better, just only half a person better than our
334:16 - dumb model, which always predicts. No. So what's going on here? What's going on? How is the model?
334:22 - A hundred percent accurate about the training data, but completely missing or learning anything,
334:27 - but completely failing to learn anything important, anything useful about the validation data.
334:33 - So here's what has happened. It appears that the model has learned the training examples
334:38 - perfectly, which means it has basically memorized all the training examples. It's like if you
334:43 - memorize the answers to all the questions in your textbook for an exam, and then you go to the
334:50 - exam and none of the questions come up with exactly the same values. So you are likely to score a
334:56 - very low mark in the exam. In the same way, the model has learned all the training examples, but
335:01 - it does not generalize very well to previously unseen examples. This phenomenon is called
335:07 - overfitting and reducing overfitting is one of the most important parts of any machine learning
335:13 - project, especially when you're dealing with tree based models like decision trees. So we'll see how
335:19 - to improve. We'll see how to reduce overfitting. And the first step in understanding what's going
335:25 - on is to visualize the decision tree that has been learned from the training data. Now I told you in
335:30 - the beginning that decision tree is a hierarchical tree of binary decisions, something like this,
335:37 - something like this. So our model actually builds a decision tree, which is pretty close to what we
335:46 - saw above. And we can visualize this tree using the plot tree function from sklearn.tree. So I'm
335:52 - just going to import plot tree from sklearn.tree and plot tree uses matplotlib under the hood. So
335:58 - I'm just setting, I'm just increasing the figure size here so that this is a big image that we can
336:03 - look at and we call plot tree with the model and plot tree can also takes the name of the features
336:10 - or the name of the columns. So we can provide to plot tree the names of these columns so that it
336:18 - can actually tell us which columns the model is looking at. And then we provide a maximum depth
336:26 - because this tree is a very deep tree. It's going to have a depth of about 40 or 50 of which cannot
336:32 - be printed very easily. So we're just going to look at two levels of the tree. And we just,
336:37 - this is just some, some information about color. So we're just filling up. We'll just fill some
336:42 - nodes of the tree with some backgrounds. So let's run this and let's see what this looks like.
336:49 - So here's what our models predictions look like. The model first checks
336:55 - the humidity at 3 p.m. and it checks if the humidity at 3 p.m. is less than 0.7 1 5. Then
337:02 - it goes into this direction and then it checks if the rainfall at after, after checking, well,
337:10 - if the humidity at 3 p.m. is less than 0.7 1 5, it checks whether the rainfall is less than 0.0
337:15 - 0 4. If that is so in, then checks if sunshine is less than 0.25 0.5 2 5, and then it has
337:21 - multiple checks and so on. So this is how the model proceeds each time it makes a decision based on
337:26 - this value based on checking the humidity that either goes left or right. Now, if it is gone,
337:31 - right, then here there is another check on humidity. And once again, based on that, it goes left or
337:35 - right. And then based on this condition, it checks left or right. And then it keeps going. Now we
337:41 - have only plotted till the depth of two, but you can plot till any depth here. So you can see here
337:49 - here, you can plot to any, any depth. Now, there seems to be a problem here. Typically this image,
337:54 - you will see that it is connected. So in this image, you will see that there are lines connecting
337:58 - these, but you can see the tree that's building up here. So this is the first decision. And based on
338:03 - this decision, this may be the second decision based on this, this may be the third decision and so
338:07 - on. And that keeps going till it finds a final leaf node where there are no more decisions to be made.
338:13 - And at that leaf node, it contains information about which class should be returned as the output.
338:20 - Okay. So I hope you can see how a model classifies a given input as a series of decisions. Now,
338:27 - of course, the tree is truncated here, but following any path from the root node to a leaf will result
338:34 - in a yes or a no. And I hope now you can also start to see how a decision tree differs from a
338:40 - logistic regression model. Now, one important difference that I can immediately tell you
338:49 - is that instead of having a standard weightage for every, instead of having a fixed weight for
338:55 - every column, as you go left and right, the, the kind of conditions and the kind of weights can
339:01 - change, for example, based on whether the humidity is less than 0.7 or more than 0.7, the conditions
339:08 - that are applied to wind gust speed may change. And that makes sense. Like if it has rained today,
339:13 - maybe the factors I should look at are different compared to whether it has not rained today.
339:19 - And that non-linear relationship can be captured better in a decision tree. And it's a bit harder
339:26 - to capture in a linear model. So whenever you have these non-linear relationships, then it's
339:31 - always better to try out a decision tree and see if that performs better in a decision tree.
339:36 - And see if that performs better than a logistic regression model. Okay.
339:42 - Now you may wonder how this decision tree is created. How exactly does the model figure out
339:49 - what is the first decision to be made and what's the second decision and so on. And this is where
339:54 - you should pay attention to this Gini value. So in each box, you will see this Gini score.
340:01 - Now, every machine learning model has something called a loss function or a cost function. And
340:06 - the objective of the model is to minimize the cost. So the way the model does this is the
340:11 - decision tree does this is by using a Gini score. The Gini score represents how good a certain
340:17 - split is. So a Gini score, a lower Gini score means a lower cost, which means a good split.
340:23 - So a perfect split, let's say by just looking at humidity 3PM, you could perfectly classify
340:29 - things as will not rain tomorrow versus rain tomorrow. In that case, the Gini score will be zero.
340:34 - So a perfect split has the Gini score zero. And as, as a split gets worse and worse. So if, if your
340:41 - split is completely useless, which means that even after splitting, there are 50% yeses and 50%
340:47 - nose on this side and 50% yeses and 50% nose on this side, then you will have a high Gini score,
340:52 - maybe close to 0.5 or I think somewhere around the range of 0.5. All right. So all right.
340:58 - So a low Gini score means a good split, a high Gini score means a bad split. So what does,
341:06 - what does our decision tree model do? Conceptually speaking, while training, the model evaluates
341:15 - all possible splits across all possible columns. So right now we are looking at this one split
341:21 - humidity 3PM, but conceptually speaking, what the model has done is it is looked at all the different
341:26 - columns and then for each column, it has looked at all the possible split points. So it has
341:32 - basically sorted all the values in those columns in increasing order. And then it has taken each
341:36 - value as a split point. And then for each split point, it has performed the split and based on
341:44 - the split, it has calculated the Gini score. Now, good splits will have a low Gini score and
341:49 - bad splits will have a high Gini score out of all the, all the columns, all the splits.
341:57 - It has selected the best column with the best split, which leads to a lowest possible Gini score.
342:03 - Now, of course, with just one split, you cannot really get to a Gini score of zero because
342:09 - you can't just look at one feature and one split and perfectly make predictions about whether or
342:15 - not it will rain tomorrow. But among all the possible splits, it turns out that humidity at
342:20 - 3PM, whether that's less than 0.7 or more than 0.7 is the most important factor. It is, it
342:27 - leads to the lowest Gini score. Okay. So that's how the decision tree figures out what should be the
342:34 - top level root level node. Now, once it is figured out what the root level node is, which is the best
342:40 - split among all the columns and all the possible splits, it performs a split using that data.
342:46 - So certain data points fall into this region. All the training data, which has humidity less than
342:51 - 0.7 falls into this region. All the data, which has humidity greater than 0.7 falls into this region.
342:58 - And this is where now the process is repeated. Now for this entire data, which has humidity
343:02 - less than 0.7, it tries all the columns, all the possible splits and figure out the figures
343:08 - out the best split. Now it turns out that if humidity is already less than 0.7, rainfall
343:12 - less than 0.04 is the best split. And if humidity is greater than 0.7 and humidity, whether that's
343:19 - humidity less than equal to 0.8 to five is the best split. Okay. So that's what is happening here.
343:26 - So the iterative approach of machine learning in the case of a decision tree involves growing
343:33 - a tree layer by layer. So what we do first is input all the training data. And we essentially
343:41 - look at all possible splits and we take all those possible splits. And then we compute the Gini score
343:47 - for all the possible splits across all the possible columns. Based on the Gini score,
343:51 - we pick the best possible split. Then we split the data into based on the split that was decided.
344:00 - And then we repeat the process recursively for each split for the left split and for the right
344:04 - split, right? So we are recursively growing the tree. We have the level one decision, and then
344:10 - we make level two decisions with the split data. Then we make level three decisions with the split
344:14 - data. Then we make level four decisions with the split data and so on. And for how long does this
344:19 - go on? Well, this goes on forever till the point that you end up with just a single value. Now,
344:24 - right now you can, and in fact, that is the number that you can see here at the very top,
344:29 - you have 98,988 rows of data and this split send 76,000 rows into the left and 22,000 rows into
344:38 - the right. Now, similarly, this particular split has 82,000 rows of data and this split sends
344:47 - 70,000 this way and 11,000 this way, right? So that's roughly how it works. It, it, it divides
344:56 - the data into multiple parts and it keeps dividing till it gets to single leaf nodes. So you, where
345:01 - you just have a single row of data. And then for that row of data, since you already have the
345:06 - target, so that the target for that row is used as the value of that leaf, right? So every leaf
345:13 - ultimately contains just one sample and that sample already has a target of yes or no.
345:20 - So essentially what we're saying is we want to follow this decision tree down to a specific
345:24 - example from our training set and just look at the label of that training example and return
345:31 - the same label. Okay. So I hope now you understand why the training accuracy is a hundred percent
345:36 - because the decision tree has literally learned or literally memorized the entire training set
345:43 - in the form of this tree based structure. Okay. And you can verify how deep this tree is by
345:51 - checking the maximum depth of the tree. So you just call model dot tree dot max depth. And it
345:56 - turns out that this tree is 48 layers deep. So it's possible that within 48 decisions,
346:02 - you will get to a leaf node and on that leaf node, you will have a label corresponding to
346:08 - that specific training example, which lies in that leaf node. Okay.
346:13 - So this is one way to visualize a decision tree, what the model learns. And as I said,
346:19 - you will see arrows here. Normally I don't, I'm not sure why they don't,
346:23 - they're not showing up here, but normally you do see arrows.
346:27 - One other way to display a decision tree, which can be easier to follow is as text. So you can
346:34 - call export text and you can pass in the model. You can again, specify a maximum depth up to which
346:40 - you want to show things because again, this can get pretty large as well. And you provide a list
346:45 - of feature names here too. So here's what the textual representation looks like. So here we're
346:50 - checking if the humidity is less than a 0.72 and if the humidity is less than 0.72, we go down this
346:57 - path. Otherwise we go down the other path, which is, well, I think we've not shown it here. We've
347:02 - just shown a few lines because the street itself, even with 10 layers of depth is very high. But
347:09 - yeah, if you first you check humidity, then you check rainfall, then you check sunshine,
347:13 - then you check pressure, then you check wind gust speed, then you check humidity again,
347:17 - then you check wind direction, then you check the location. Now, if you're looking at
347:22 - West Watsonia, then we check the cloud cover at 9 a.m. And then we check the wind speed at 3 p.m.
347:28 - And then we check the pressure. So if all of these checks succeed,
347:32 - then we return. Yes, that yes, it will rain tomorrow. If the pressure check fails,
347:39 - if the pressure is not less than equal to 0.47, then we return no. And if the wind speed check
347:47 - fails, if the wind speed is not less than equal to 0.07, if it is greater than 0.7, then we check
347:51 - the minimum temperature. And then there is another branch of decisions that is to be made. And
347:56 - similarly, you have this, if the cloud cover is greater than 0.83, then we check the cloud cover
348:01 - at 3 p.m. And then we return. Yes. Otherwise we return true. Otherwise we return otherwise.
348:07 - Well, we check the temperature and then we return. Yes. Otherwise there is another decision tree
348:11 - here. Okay. So the idea is this is the same as the decision tree that we saw above. And the idea is
348:16 - that we make these hierarchical decisions and the model has learned which decision to make first by
348:22 - analyzing all possible decisions. Now, one small note I want to give you here is this is how you
348:29 - should think about it conceptually. The model actually has not really analyzed all possible
348:33 - decisions because that is going to be very inefficient. So there are certain techniques or
348:37 - certain, what are called heuristics that are applied. So which is basically strategies to
348:42 - figure out good decisions, good enough decisions, if not the best decisions. And there is some
348:47 - randomization involved in there as well, right? So just as an optimization, there is some
348:52 - randomization and some strategies to pick if not the best, but at least a good enough decision.
348:57 - All right. So that's the internals of decision trees, which we don't really need to worry about.
349:03 - So based on this discussion, now, can you explain why the training accuracy is a hundred percent,
349:08 - whereas the validation accuracy is lower. And you can think about it. It's because the model has
349:13 - literally learned every training example. And when it sees an example, which does not fit exactly
349:20 - with training, it tries to categorize it into one of the existing training examples by following
349:26 - one path of the decision tree. And that may or may not end up really well because it's going to
349:35 - ultimately boil down to a specific training example. And this is what is called overfitting
349:40 - where your model has learned or memorized specific training examples, and does not generalize well
349:45 - to examples that it has not seen before. Okay. Okay. Let's keep going. Now, based on the genie
349:52 - index computation, a decision tree assigns an importance value to each feature. Again, there is
349:59 - a certain calculation involved here on figuring out how the importance is assigned, but these values

353:19 - the humidity column, or maybe we should try and fill those missing values and so on. Right? So
353:24 - you need to go back and forth. You need to go back and check if your data makes sense, given that
353:28 - this is the feature importance that you're working with. So that's how you train a decision tree.
353:37 - You import the decision tree classifier from sklearn.tree and then you fit it to the input data
353:45 - and then you can analyze it. You can evaluate it using the validation dataset. And we saw
353:53 - that the decision tree classifier that we train memorized all the training examples leading to
353:58 - a hundred percent training accuracy while the validation accuracy was only marginally better
354:02 - than a dumb baseline model. So at this point, our decision trees basically useless because
354:09 - it has just memorized all the training examples. And this phenomenon is called overfitting. And
354:14 - in this section, we will look at some strategies for reducing overfitting.
354:20 - So you will hear a lot of these terms. Now there'll be four or five terms that you'll hear
354:25 - right now. And often in machine learning overfitting simply means that you're doing
354:30 - very well on the training data, but you're doing very poorly on the validation data. And we'll
354:34 - define it a bit more rigidly, a bit more concretely in, in a short while. And the process of reducing
354:43 - overfitting is known as regularization. So whenever you see regularization or regular
354:48 - regularization techniques, regularization, coefficient, regularization, component,
354:55 - et cetera, et cetera, all of that is concerned with reducing overfitting, which means trying to
355:00 - increase the validation accuracy or get it closer to the training accuracy. And sometimes
355:06 - we may be okay to give up some training accuracy to get a better validation accuracy,
355:11 - because the validation accuracy is what we ultimately care about.
355:18 - Now, how do we reduce overfitting in a decision tree classifier? Now the decision tree classifier,
355:23 - when we created it, we gave it a couple of arguments. We set some random state. We give
355:28 - it just one argument, which was the random state. And apart from that, it also accepts several
355:33 - other arguments, which can be used to reduce overfitting. So if you just check the help,
355:38 - which is by typing a question mark for decision tree classifier,
355:45 - you will see that you can specify a criterion, which can be Gini or entropy. And this is simply
355:50 - the loss function. So there are two loss functions. One is Gini and one is entropy.
355:57 - You can specify a splitter. So this is the strategy that is used to split at each node.
356:02 - And by default, it picks the best strategy, which just picks the best possible split,
356:07 - of course, with some randomization, or you can also specify a completely random split with,
356:13 - without actually looking at the, without actually evaluating different splits.
356:17 - But here's something interesting. So you have a max depth parameter and you can specify the
356:22 - maximum depth of the tree. So let's see that there is a max depth parameter. And typically
356:31 - these arguments in the context of machine learning that you set right when you are creating your
356:36 - machine learning model are called hyper parameters because the term parameter is generally reserved
356:43 - for the parameters or the numbers inside a machine learning model. For example, in logistic
356:48 - regression, the weights of the different features are known as parameters in a decision tree,
356:54 - which column is the root node and what point we are splitting at. And then what do the splits
356:59 - look like? Those are known as parameters. Anything that the model learns or figures out on its own
357:04 - is called a parameter. So just to separate things that model figures out versus things that we have
357:11 - to set upfront, we call some of these things hyper parameters. So we call max depth, which is
357:17 - something that we specify at the very beginning. When we are creating the classifier, we call it a
357:22 - hyper parameter because it's not something the model figures out. It's something that we are
357:26 - specifying. So what is maximum depth? Well, if you saw the tree, the tree went down to about 40,
357:35 - 42 levels deep, and we could check that using. So the previous model that we had, the model that
357:40 - we trained earlier, if we just check the tree inside it, so we can call model or tree underscore,
357:45 - and then we can check max depth. So the model that we had trained earlier, the decision tree
357:50 - went 48 levels deep. And that was one of the reasons for overfitting because it was learning
357:56 - every training example. So what if we did not go 48 levels deep? What if we only went three levels
358:00 - deep? Let's try and see what that will give us. So if you only go three levels deep, so now we have
358:06 - put in a restriction that we do not want our decision tree to go more than three levels deep.
358:12 - And then we call model dot fit with the same training input data and the same training targets.
358:17 - So now the model has been trained again, it just takes a second or two. And then we try to compute
358:22 - the accuracy of the model on the training and validation data sets. So we call model dot score
358:27 - on X train, and we call model dot score on X, while and while targets. And now it turns out that
358:34 - the model is only 82% or 83% accurate on the training data. And this makes sense because the
358:42 - model can no longer learn every training example. It can only go three layers deep. So it just has
358:47 - to make the best it can out of three layers. But this has the unintended consequence that the model
358:55 - is no longer overfitting. The model now performs better on the validations set than it did before.
359:00 - So this may seem counterintuitive that a three level deep tree performs better in the real world
359:07 - on real world data compared to a 48 level deep tree. And that's because the 48 level deep tree is
359:15 - learning specific training examples, whereas the three level deep tree is picking up general trends.
359:21 - And in machine learning, you want models to pick up general trends and not memorize training examples.
359:27 - Okay. So that's the model. The model's accuracy has gone up to 83% from 79%. That's a good
359:34 - improvement. And even though this has gone down, ultimately, what we care about is the validation
359:39 - accuracy and let's visualize the model now. So we can visualize the model using plot tree once again.
359:48 - So here's what our entire decision tree model looks like. First, we check humidity at 3 p.m.
359:54 - First, we check humidity at 3 p.m. If the humidity at 3 p.m. is less than 0.715, then we go left.
360:05 - Now here, we check the rainfall. If the rainfall is less than 0.004, then we go left. Then we check
360:11 - sunshine at the sunshine is less than 0.0525. We go left. And finally, if, if we reach this point,
360:17 - we return the class. No. So whenever you reach a leaf node, you return the class of that leaf node.
360:25 - Similarly, now you check humidity, rainfall, humidity, and you get to this point, you return.
360:30 - No. So it seems like a lot of these have no. And so in a lot of cases, as you go along this decision
360:35 - tree, you will end up at no, but there are certain cases where you will end up at yes.
360:39 - So you go to humidity or humidity 3 p.m. rainfall. So if the rainfall, if the humidity at 3 p.m.
360:45 - is less than 0.825, and then the wind speed, wind gust speed is less than 0.279.

361:08 - here are the classes. Yes. So here is what here you return that there will be rain tomorrow.
361:13 - And if the humidity is greater than 0.7 and greater than 0.8, well, it turns out that in
361:18 - all these cases, you end up at yes. Right. And of course, these trees got truncated. These trees
361:23 - could not be built beyond three layers deep. So that's why you see a bunch of yeses here. It's
361:29 - possible that if you had allowed more layers, then maybe some of these yeses would then split
361:34 - once again into nodes. But because we are ending the tree at three layers, it's going to return
361:39 - no in all these conditions and it's going to return. Yes. In all these conditions. Okay.
361:45 - So this is what you want to study carefully, because at this point, we already know that we
361:48 - can predict with 83% accuracy simply by looking at humidity, rainfall, sunshine, wind gust speed.
361:56 - And that's it, right? So just four out of the 23 plus columns can be used to predict,
362:04 - to get a prediction of 83% accuracy. And once again, we can also look at it as a textual tree.
362:15 - So here you can see the same thing, humidity less than 0.72 and humidity greater than 0.72.
362:20 - And then you check the rainfall and based on the rainfall value, you either check sunshine or you
362:25 - check humidity once again, and it turns yes and no. Okay. So one thing you may want wonder is
362:33 - what is the right maximum depth to use? Should we use a maximum depth of zero? Obviously not,
362:38 - because if you use a maximum depth of zero, then your model would not learn anything. That means
362:43 - it would always just predict. No. And while that would be 79% accurate. And while that would be
362:49 - regularized, that would not be very useful because you've not given enough power to your model.
362:56 - But on the other hand, if you allow your model to go 40 layers deep or 50 layers deep, then your
363:02 - model can memorize every single training example. And since it is trying to optimize for the lowest
363:07 - Gini score, it is basically memorizing all the training data. And that's bad because then your
363:11 - model will not generalize. So the best value for the maximum depth of the tree is going to be
363:18 - somewhere between zero and 40. So let's try and explore that. Let's try and figure out what the
363:23 - best value for maximum depth is going to be. So here's what I'm defining. I'm defining a function
363:29 - called max depth error, which takes a sample max depth value, which we can give as an input. And
363:36 - then we create a decision tree classifier for that particular max depth with the random state 42.
363:43 - And we get this model. Then we fit this model to the training data for that given max depth. We
363:48 - create the model fitted to the training data. Then we calculate the accuracy on the training set.
363:54 - And we calculate the accuracy on the validation set, and we define, let's call this error.
364:03 - And we define the training error as one minus the training accuracy. And let's call,
364:07 - and we define the validation error as one minus the validation accuracy. So if accuracy is what
364:13 - percentage it got, right? Error is the percentage that it got wrong. And then we simply return this
364:19 - dictionary. And you'll see in a moment why I'm doing this. Now we take this max depth error
364:25 - function, which takes a max depth and then figures out for that max depth, what is the training error
364:30 - and the validation error. And we run that through this list comprehension. So we try all the max,
364:38 - we try all possible values of max depth from one to 21. And that's why it's taking a while because
364:44 - we are building a decision tree for every max depth value from one to 21. And we are computing
364:50 - the training error and the validation error for each of these max depth value models. And then
364:55 - we're putting all those results into a data frame. So let's yeah. So let's give that a minute. And
365:01 - then here you go. So this is what we get. When you have a max depth of one, the training error
365:07 - is 0.18, which means just by, which means just by selecting a max depth of one, just by making
365:16 - one decision, you get to a training accuracy of about 81% and a validation accuracy of about 82%.
365:28 - That's what it looks like. And, but as you, as you increase the max depth, the error goes down,
365:33 - which means the accuracy improves. You can see here, the training error keeps increasing 18,
365:38 - seven, the training error keeps decreasing. The accuracy keeps improving. So 18, 17, 16,
365:43 - 15, 14, 13, and it goes on all the way up to 0.0903. So at this point we are at 99 point.
365:51 - So at this point, we are at 97% training accuracy at a max depth of 20. And of course,
365:56 - if we increase the max depth further, the model will be, so to speak, learn or memorize
366:02 - more training examples, and it will get better at the training data. But notice what's happening
366:07 - with the validation error. So the validation error is at 0.17 and it goes down and it goes down and
366:12 - it goes down to 0.15. And then it starts to increase again. So you can see here from 0.15
366:18 - starts to go to 0.16, 0.17, 0.18, 0.19. And if you plot this, so here's, here's what it will look
366:25 - like if I plot it. So here I've simply plotted the training versus validation error. The blue line
366:30 - is the training error, which is one minus accuracy. And the orange line is the validation error. So
366:36 - what's happening here? Here you see both the training and the validation loss decreasing. So
366:40 - what's happening here is you are making your model progressively more powerful, which means you're
366:46 - allowing it to make a one decision right now. And here you're allowing this model, the model at
366:52 - where max depth two, you allow it to make two layers of decisions. And this model with max
366:58 - step four, you allow it to make four layers of decisions and so on. So up to a certain point,
367:03 - it helps to add more complexity or help helps to add more power within your model, right? It helps
367:09 - to make your model bigger. But after a certain point, when, once your model's capacity gets
367:14 - large enough, it starts to just focus on memorizing the training data and it stops generalizing. So
367:20 - at this point, you see it gets better and better at the training data and it gets worse and worse
367:24 - at the validation data. And this is the scenario that is known as overfitting. Okay. So here is
367:31 - the graph that you will see over and over and over again in pretty much every problem. As you
367:37 - increase the complexity or the size of your model, as you increase the size of your model, or the
367:43 - power of your model or the capacity of your model. So many different ways of looking at it.
367:47 - Ultimately, it's a question of how many parameters are there inside the model. So as you increase
367:51 - the complexity or size or power or parameters of your model, you will notice that both the
367:57 - training error and the test or validation error will go down up to a certain point because the
368:02 - model is getting, the model has more capacity, so it can learn more and it can actually capture
368:08 - some information about the inputs and the targets and how they are related. But after a certain
368:12 - point, it will start memorizing training examples. And that is a point where your test or your
368:17 - validation error will start to increase. That is the point where your validation accuracy will
368:21 - start to drop. And this scenario is known as overfitting where your training error is going
368:26 - down, but your validation error is going up. If you train your model a little more, if you increase
368:31 - the complexity of your model, a little more, if you add one more layer to your decision tree,
368:36 - then the training error goes down, but the validation error actually gets worse. And this
368:41 - is where you should stop training your model. So you want to stop training your model at the point
368:47 - where, or this is where you want to pick the complexity of your model. So you want to pick the
368:51 - complexity of your model at the point where the validation loss is just about to increase. So
368:57 - here, by plotting this graph, we have been able to figure out that at, at a max depth of seven,
369:03 - we get as good as this decision tree can get on the validation error for the given dataset.
369:10 - So the max depth of seven is actually the best depth for a decision tree. So this is how you
369:15 - figure out, this is how you regularize a decision tree. So you regularize a decision tree, which
369:20 - means to reduce overfitting by tuning some hyper parameters. So this is called a hyper parameter
369:26 - max depth, and just changing its value is called tuning the hyper parameter. And by tuning this
369:31 - hyper parameter, we have to regularize the model a little bit. We have now reduced the
369:38 - amount of overfitting that it has. So you can now see that the validation score, it may be also,
369:43 - let me also print out the training score here, the training score and validation score or training
369:55 - accuracy, validation accuracy, both are about 84.5, 84.6%. So that seems like the best we can do
370:03 - by modifying the max depth of the decision tree. Okay. So we just looked at one hyper parameter,
370:11 - which is max tree depth. And we also looked at how that hyper parameter can be used to, can we use
370:18 - to regularize the model? Let's look at another hyper parameter. This one is called max leaf nodes.
370:25 - So this is another way to control the size of the complexity of a decision tree. So we
370:31 - have the complexity of a decision tree, another way to control the complexity of a decision tree,
370:39 - and which is to limit the number of leaf nodes. Now, whenever you have a decision tree, there are,
370:45 - as you can see here, there are a certain number of decision nodes, and then there are a certain
370:50 - number of leaf nodes. Now, the way we have limited the size of the decision tree or the,
370:54 - and the complexity or the parameters of the decision tree in this case is by specifying
370:59 - how deep it can get, but that may not be the best way. Maybe you want to allow it to go a few layers
371:05 - deep here. Maybe you want to allow it to go five layers deep here, and you want to allow it to just
371:09 - stay two layers deep here. So that's where you can actually specify the maximum number of leaf
371:16 - nodes that your decision tree can have. So here's how I'm going to do that. I'm going to specify
371:23 - that for my decision tree, that the maximum number of leaf nodes it can have is 128. And
371:30 - roughly speaking, if you have one, one node at the top that splits into two nodes below it,
371:36 - that splits into four nodes below it. What we might think is that the decision tree actually
371:40 - goes layer by layer, where it goes builds layer one and then builds layer two, and then it builds
371:44 - layer three. But actually what happens is it always tries to make the best possible split. So if it is
371:50 - created a layer one, maybe let's look at it here. So if a decision tree has created a layer one,
371:56 - it has created a split here. And then based on the split, you now have two splits left and right.
372:02 - Now it looks at both of these and it sees which is the better to split. If this is going to,
372:08 - if splitting this is going to result in a lower Gini coefficient, then it splits this into two
372:13 - parts by creating a split condition here. And now it's going to analyze among all of these leaf
372:19 - nodes, which is the best split to make. So if it determines that this is the best split to make,
372:23 - then it's going to make this split first. And now maybe at this point, it's going to look at all
372:28 - these leaf nodes and determine which is the best split to make. So maybe at this point,
372:31 - the next best split to make is, is this, and maybe after this, the next best split to make is this
372:37 - and so on. So your decision tree doesn't really go layer by layer where it first does this,
372:42 - and then it does this. Rather it goes, it looks at all the leaf nodes and it figures out which
372:48 - is the best leaf node to split at the moment. And it splits it. Now, how does that tie down,
372:55 - tie back to max leaf nodes? Now here, what we're saying is we want max leaf nodes to be 128 and
373:00 - 128, I believe is two to the power of seven. So if you had a decision tree, which was seven layers
373:09 - deep at its lowest point, it would have 128 nodes. Now let's try and give the max leaf nodes of 128
373:17 - and let's see if the decision tree actually has a depth of seven. So here we create this decision
373:23 - tree. We call decision tree classifier, and then we call model dot fit. So now we're training and
373:30 - the only restriction we've specified is that the number of leaf nodes, the number of these nodes,
373:34 - which have not been split, should not go higher than 128. And that limits a certain number of
373:42 - splits. So now we fed the data on the training. We fed the model on the training data and it turns
373:48 - out that the training accuracy is only 84.8% and not a hundred percent because of the same reason
373:53 - it cannot go down and memorize every training example. There's only a limited number of nodes
373:57 - it can create. And let's check the models accuracy on the validation dataset. So on the validation
374:03 - dataset, this time the accuracy is 84.4%. And let's check the tree's depth as well. So the depth
374:10 - of the tree is 12. So let's compare this 84 with what we had the previous time.
374:20 - Yeah. With a model here, we had a model that could go to maximum depth of seven
374:26 - and that had 84.5% validation accuracy. In this case, we have 84.4%.
374:34 - Maybe if you change this a little bit, maybe if you change this to one 130 or 140, you may find
374:39 - that it may actually cross, but the important thing is that these two are different. And the
374:43 - reason these two accuracies are different is because the strategy by which we are limiting
374:49 - the size of the tree is different. In one case, we are saying that the max depth can be seven. In
374:54 - the other case, we're saying that the maximum number of leaf nodes can be 128. And the tree
374:58 - actually does go down to a depth of 12 in certain places. So that means certain parts go down to a

377:03 - with a random split, et cetera, is worth figuring out. Look at, there are some other parameters,
377:12 - hyper parameters here that you can look at. So try and experiment with all of these. And you can
377:16 - see that there are detailed explanations for each of these. And in fact, in certain cases,
377:21 - you will find that there are links to other resources. And as I said, a lot of these are
377:26 - implementations of some of the best papers in machine learning. So a lot of the best practices
377:30 - are given to us. A lot of the best techniques are given to us. We just have to try them out with
377:34 - scikit-learn. Another exercise for you is to try out a more advanced technique for reducing
377:43 - overfitting. This is called cost complexity pruning. So just as we have limited the number
377:49 - of loads by depth, and we have limited the number of nodes by the number of leaf nodes,
377:56 - there is a way to limit the number of nodes by the kind of split that a node performs. So we
378:02 - perform a split only if it satisfies certain criteria, and this is called cost complexity
378:09 - pruning. So you can learn more about it here. It's not a very commonly used technique because
378:13 - decision trees by themselves are almost never used in isolation. So I will not cover it here,
378:18 - but it's something that you can check out scikit-learn has good documentation on it. And in
378:22 - fact, it has an example implementation and also the link to the paper. So you can check this out
378:29 - and try and follow the code from this tutorial and try to implement cost complexity pruning
378:34 - and see if you can improve the validation accuracy further. Okay. Machine learning is
378:38 - all about trying different hyper parameters, trying different techniques and getting that
378:43 - additional boost in the model's performance. Okay. All right. So that was a quick introduction
378:49 - to decision trees. Now, of course we've skipped over some parts, especially the more mathematical
378:56 - parts about the Gini index and the importance calculation and things like that. But I hope you
379:01 - were able to get a basic intuition of how these splits are created. We look at all possible
379:08 - features, all possible splits, find the best split, and the best evaluation is done using
379:12 - the Gini index. Then we divide the data into these two parts or these two portions. And then
379:18 - we identify which is the next best split to be made based on the leaf nodes that we have. And
379:23 - then we make that split. And then we keep going till we either hit leaf nodes, in which case we
379:29 - essentially memorize the entire training dataset, or till we hit some limits that have been
379:34 - artificially imposed via some hyper parameters for the purpose of regularization. And in general,
379:40 - you don't want to have an unbounded decision tree. You want it to be somewhat generalized.
379:46 - So that's why you want to limit its depth and you want to maybe limit some of the other
379:50 - hyper parameters as well. Now, while tuning the hyper parameters of a single decision tree may
379:56 - lead to some improvements, a much more effective strategy is to combine the results of several
380:02 - decision trees that are trained with slightly different parameters. And we'll talk about these
380:08 - slightly different parameters slowly, but just assume that we are training maybe a bunch of
380:13 - different decision trees with a slightly different max depth, slightly different max nodes, slightly
380:19 - different, some other parameters. And then you combine the results of several decision trees
380:26 - that you've trained on the same dataset that is called a random forest. As the name suggests,
380:31 - a forest is simply a collection of trees and random forest, because there is some amount of
380:38 - randomization involved here on how this forest is created. Now, if you created a forest with
380:43 - the exact same dataset, then each decision tree would be identical. So we use randomization to
380:49 - make sure that all the, all the trees in the forest are slightly different to each other.
380:55 - And why are we doing this? Why are we combining the results of several trees? Well, the key idea
380:59 - here is that each decision tree in the forest, because of all this randomization will make
381:04 - different kinds of errors and upon averaging, many of those errors will cancel out. So it's a very
381:13 - interesting idea and sometimes seems counterintuitive, but we let's look at common world,
381:19 - a real life example of this. And the real life example is commonly known as the wisdom of the
381:23 - crowd. Now let's see if you, if you want to estimate the weight of this cow here, the way
381:32 - we would do it, one way we could do it is we could actually measure and that would give us
381:36 - the weight of the cow. One other way we could do is we could actually ask a lot of people.
381:40 - Now it turns out that the more people you ask, the better or the closer you get to the actual
381:45 - result. So if you just ask one person that one person could be way off because they may not be
381:51 - exposed to livestock at all. They may not know what a cow is, but if you ask enough people
381:57 - over time, you'll find some people who are underestimating some people who are overestimating
382:01 - some people who actually know what the information is. And the average of 800 guesses is a real
382:08 - experiment that was conducted turns out to be very close to the, and this is an org sorry,
382:13 - it turns out to be very close to the actual weight of the orgs. Right? So this is an idea
382:19 - that intuitively makes sense that if you ask enough people, you can get closer to the real answer.
382:27 - Of course, that's not a hundred percent true in all cases because humans have biases as well,
382:32 - but in general, this is the idea. And this is the kind of the strategy here that when we take
382:38 - decisions from several decision trees that have been trained with some amount of randomization,
382:43 - then the kind of errors that they make will cancel out upon averaging. And the result that
382:48 - we will get will be better than the result from any individual decision tree. Okay.
382:54 - So let's check it out. So here's how a random forest works. It simply takes the results of
383:03 - multiple decision trees, and then it averages or combines them. For example, here you have tree
383:09 - one, three, two, three, three, or tree and entries and trees have been trained. And then you take,
383:14 - and let's say these are classifiers. So then you take all these entries and you get the output out
383:22 - of each of these entries, and you simply do a basic voting. You figure out which class is the
383:29 - most commonly occurring class among these entries. And you return that as the output of the random
383:34 - forest. So the random forest is simply a collection of all these trees that have been trained
383:37 - independently and slightly differently. And the outcome of the random forest is simply by getting
383:42 - the outcomes of all the trees and then combining them. Now, because we are doing classification,
383:46 - the way you combine them is by voting, which means by picking the most common class, if it
383:52 - was regression, the way you would combine them is by averaging, which means if each decision tree
383:58 - was predicting a continuous number, you could add them all up and get the average and return that
384:02 - as the output. So to train a random forest classifier, as you might be able to guess by now
384:09 - is really easy. You just import the random forest classifier class from scikit learn dot ensemble.
384:15 - So this is called an ensembling technique, which is the more general term. Whenever you take
384:20 - multiple models and they don't have to be decision trees. They don't even have to be the same kind
384:24 - of model. Whenever you take multiple models and you take the results of all those models and
384:29 - combine them together to get the result of this combined model, this is called an ensemble.
384:34 - So let's import the random forest classifier and let's set up a random forest classifier.
384:41 - Now, there are a couple of things I'm passing through the random forest classifier. One is the
384:46 - N jobs and remember random forest classifier is going to have a bunch of trees inside it. And
384:51 - we would want to train the trees in parallel because each tree will be trained independently.
384:57 - So when you specify N jobs equals minus one, then the random forest classifier can pick up
385:02 - can use different workers or different CPU threads to train decision trees in parallel. And that
385:07 - just makes it faster. And you can try removing N jobs equals minus one and see the difference.
385:12 - And I'm also specifying a random space state of 42. This random state will be used inside the
385:18 - decision tree. So this will be passed to each decision tree to control the randomization there.
385:25 - Again, the reason for passing a random state is so that each time I run this line of code or each
385:30 - time I try to fit this model, I get the exact same result. So we've just created the random forest
385:37 - classifier object and let's fit it. So this is where N jobs becomes useful. If you had N jobs
385:43 - on specified, it would just use one thread, but right now it is using all possible threads or all
385:49 - possible workers. Okay. So I recommend you try out changing, removing N jobs and running model.fit
385:55 - once again. All right. So it took about 16 seconds to train the model. And what exactly happened
386:02 - here? Well, it just trained a whole bunch of decision trees. And now once we've trained the model,
386:09 - the next thing is to just score the model. So see how well it does on the training data by
386:15 - calling model.score X train. So once again, it is 99.99% accurate on the training data. And that
386:25 - makes sense because we have not specified any limitations on the decision trees. Each decision
386:30 - tree will train completely to perfectly learn the training dataset, but here's where it starts to
386:38 - get interesting. If you now check the validation accuracy, or so if you score the model on the
386:45 - validation set, you get an accuracy of 85.6%. Remember the first time of the first decision tree
386:52 - that we train had a training accuracy of 99.9% and a validation accuracy of 79, which was barely
387:00 - greater than a very dumb model, which always predicted no rain. But in this case, it was
387:06 - predicted no rain, but in this case, we've gotten to 85.5% accuracy. That's even higher than our
387:13 - fine tuned model. So here, the model that we had created with a certain maximum depth,
387:19 - et cetera, only got to what 84.5. So we've seen a 1% increase simply by taking a bunch of decision
387:26 - trees and averaging their results. How does that even work? How does that make sense? Because each
387:33 - decision tree is worse than their combination, right? And this is where you see the power of
387:40 - ensembling. So this is a general technique of combining the general technique of combining the
387:46 - results of many models. This is called ensembling. And the reason it works is because errors of
387:51 - individual models can cancel out when we average the results. So visually here's what it looks
387:57 - like. Let's say you want to create a separation between, let's say you have two features,
388:01 - feature one and feature two, and then you have a target, which is shown here as a shape. So
388:09 - we have three targets or three classes. One is a triangle, one is a square, and one is a circle.
388:14 - Now, one thing you could do is you could try and train a tree, a decision tree on the entire data.
388:19 - But here's this other approach that that has been taken. So we've taken like a 30% or 40% sample of
388:25 - the data trained one decision tree on it. Then we've taken another 30, 40% sample of the data
388:31 - trained another decision tree on it. And we trained another, we took another 30, 40% sample
388:36 - of the data and trained another decision tree on it. And each of these decision trees is imperfect.
388:41 - You can see that this line kind of cuts through it is, it is missing this triangle, for example,
388:47 - and it is missing this all these circles. And then this one, this one is also
388:53 - kind of imperfect because it is missing a few, I guess it is missing definitely a few squares
388:57 - and circles here. And then this one is also imperfect. So what happens is if you take,
389:02 - if you average out all these decision boundaries, and this is what happens, you combine all these
389:06 - decision boundaries, put together the ensemble decision boundary can be a lot more well-defined
389:14 - or can be a lot more accurate than any individual decision boundary. Okay.
389:21 - So that's the idea here. And this is something you have to think about for some time and see
389:26 - if that intuition makes sense to you. If not, let us know. And maybe we'll talk more about it over
389:32 - in the next lessons or so, but the idea is that the errors cancel out and the ensemble
389:39 - or the wisdom of the crowd is greater than the prediction of any particular tree. And that's why
389:46 - we get this validation accuracy of 85.5%. Now a random forest also gives you probabilities for
389:52 - the predictions, the classifier in the classification case. So if we can also call model dot predict
389:57 - proper with X train and check the training probabilities, and here's what they look like
390:04 - 0.9 0.1 0.97 0.03. So now they're no longer just ones and zeros. They are actual numbers between
390:11 - zero and one. And how does this probability get calculated? Well, the probability of a class,
390:16 - like the probability of the class. No, for the first example is simply the fraction of the trees
390:21 - which predicted the given class. No. So it turns out that among all the trees that were trained
390:28 - in the random forest, 90% of the trees predicted no for the first example, the first input, and only
390:36 - one or only 10% of the trees predicted. Yes. For the first example. And that is why the probability
390:41 - assigned to the first example for the class. No is zero is 0.9. And that's why the result of the
390:50 - random forest or the prediction of the random forest for the first example, the first input
390:54 - in X train is no. Okay. You can see here, this is, this is X train. So this is the first input

391:15 - prediction of the model is a no, and that is because the value is 0.9. Okay. So that's how
391:22 - probability is calculated in a decision tree in a random forest simply by taking the fraction

392:57 - And we will learn more about this as we explore the hyper parameters of a random forest. Now,
393:05 - one exercise for you is to verify that none of the individual decision trees have a better
393:10 - validation accuracy than the random forest. And this is really the thing that you want to get out
393:14 - of this, that the combination of all of these is better than any individual decision tree.
393:20 - And once you get that, you get the power of ensemble methods. Now, just like decision trees,
393:26 - random forest also assign an importance to each feature. And this is done by combining the
393:30 - importance values from individual trees. Again, there are certain mathematics involved in how
393:38 - that computation is done. But the important thing is that random forest, SQL and does that for you.
393:43 - And SQL and gives you that model dot feature importance. So you can just check model dot
393:48 - feature, importance is underscore. And let's just put that into a pandas data frame. And it looks
393:54 - like we have the same things showing up here more or less. So we have humidity, sunshine, pressure,
393:59 - et cetera, right? So you can see the same, the similar features show up here as they did in a
394:07 - decision tree, especially if you compare it with the unbounded decision tree or the decision tree
394:12 - with seven or eight maximum depth, you will see a similar set of things here. One thing that you
394:18 - will notice is that the skew is a lot less because now we are depending on a combination of all the
394:23 - different trees. So we're able to look at every feature and every feature gets some importance
394:30 - because it is important in some decision tree. So you'll see a less of a skew here. And that's how
394:37 - you train a random forest. And that's how you make, that's how you train and evaluate a random forest.
394:42 - Now you can make predictions using a random forest. You just give it a set of inputs and it is,
394:46 - it'll give you a set of outputs. You can get the probabilities and you can get the feature
394:49 - importances. So again, this is a model level feature importance, not to do with any specific
394:54 - input, but the model in general values, the humidity, a lot, and then the sunshine and pressure.
395:00 - So let's talk about how to improve random forest. And this is where random forests and decision
395:07 - trees are more powerful or more versatile, I would say, than some of the linear models, like
395:14 - logistic regression and linear regression, because in a random forest, you can actually increase the
395:19 - capacity. Even in a decision tree, you can increase the number of layers that you have in the tree, or
395:25 - you can increase the number of trees that you have within a random forest. And we'll see some other
395:30 - examples as well. So based on the data that you have, based on the kind of overfitting that you're
395:35 - running into the kind of problems you're running into, you can tune your random forest really well.
395:40 - So just like decision trees, random forests also have several hyper parameters. In fact, many of
395:45 - these hyper parameters are simply passed down to the underlying decision trees. And we look at some
395:51 - of them, not all of them, and you can learn more about them again, on the scikit learn documentation
395:56 - site, excellent documentation, really well explained, really approachable. So these are all the
396:05 - parameters or hyper parameters that you can set for your random forest model. And then there's a
396:08 - detailed description about each parameter. And you can also check it anytime simply by using the
396:15 - question mark here. So let's create a base model, which we can compare with the tuned hyper parameters.
396:23 - Before we tune any hyper parameters, let's just create a base random forest classifier. Let's give
396:29 - it the random state of 42 and end jobs minus one. So this is something that we will keep fixed
396:33 - throughout so that we know that the results we're getting, the changes we're getting are not because
396:39 - of randomness, but because of actual hyper parameters. So let's set random state of 42.
396:44 - And let's fit that to our training data here. And that gives us the base model. And based on that,
396:50 - let us calculate the base training, the training accuracy and the validation accuracy of the base
396:56 - model. So we've not done anything yet. This is just a baseline that we are setting up for ourselves
397:01 - for our comparison. So in the base model, as we already saw earlier, we have 99.9% training
397:11 - accuracy, and we have 85.59% validation accuracy. Now, the first thing we look at is an estimators.
397:19 - This is the first hyper parameter that we look at. And this argument controls the number of decision
397:25 - trees in the random forest. Now we know that if you have just one decision tree, that's just going
397:32 - to overfit to the data very badly. And this is one of those parameters where as you increase the
397:38 - number of estimators, you increase the randomness within the data. And just a general rule for you
397:44 - to keep in mind is randomness increases. Randomness helps reduce overfitting. The more randomness you,
397:52 - the more randomness you bring in into your model, the less overfitting you will have. So the default
397:59 - value is a hundred. And one thing that you can try is you can simply experiment with other values.
398:03 - For example, here is an estimate with, here is a model with 10 estimators or 10 decision trees.
398:11 - So 10 decision trees, obviously train a bit faster, but here with trend decision trees, it turns out
398:18 - that you get to a training accuracy of 98.7%, not really 99.99. And you get to a validation accuracy
398:25 - of 84.4%. So that's not too far from 99.99 and 85.59. Although I think this, this is a little bit
398:34 - low. So it seems like you do need to increase your number of estimators to a certain value. A small
398:41 - number of estimators will not, will probably not give you a very good result. So here we have 500
398:46 - estimators. We've gone from a hundred, which is a default to 500. And that's going to take a minute
398:51 - or so to train because it's five times as many estimators or decision trees. Okay. Maybe I should
398:59 - have tried a smaller number, but the general rule about number of estimators is as, as a general
399:08 - rule, try to have as few estimators as needed. So if you can do the job with a hundred and if going
399:15 - from a hundred to 200 is not really helping, it's not really increasing your accuracy or whatever
399:22 - your loss is, whatever your metric is meaningfully, then stay with a hundred. If you think that going
399:28 - from a hundred to 200 is giving you a reasonable increase, then go to 200 and a good way to try
399:34 - estimators is by just doubling them. So the default is a hundred. One thing you can quickly try out
399:40 - is changing that to 200 and see if that helps and then try changing that to 400. See if that still
399:46 - helps try changing that to 800. See if that still helps at some point, the benefit that you get by
399:53 - doubling is going to be too small. And the cost of how long it takes to train the model is going to
400:00 - be too high, like with 500. So it's, it turns out that when I do 500, I get to 85.7%. So that's a 0.2%
400:08 - increase or 0.857. So there's a 0.2% increase in accuracy from 85.59. Well, that's less than 0.2.
400:16 - That's about 0.13. Now, do I care enough about 0.1% accuracy improvements? If I do, then, and in
400:25 - some cases you might, in some cases that may mean something. For example, if it is some kind of a
400:31 - financial model, then maybe that 0.1% can make you more money or it can improve your estimation of
400:40 - the risk. So in that case, you should maybe get it. And if you also have the hardware to spare,
400:46 - you don't mind training 500 estimators do it. But if you don't really care, if you're more concerned
400:51 - about 85 versus 90, then I wouldn't bother with it too much. If I'm just getting a 0.1, 3% increase
400:58 - by using five times more decision trees. So there's a sort of a diminishing returns here for the
401:05 - number of estimators. Okay. But one thing I'll tell you is when you have really large data sets,
401:10 - data sets with millions of rows of data, then you will have to go with hundreds, sometimes maybe
401:17 - a thousand estimators. That's not very uncommon. The default in scikit-learn used to be 10
401:25 - estimators. And that was recently bumped a few years ago, 200 estimators, because the data sets
401:30 - have started to get much larger. So here's an exercise for you, vary the value of N estimators.
401:36 - And the way you can vary it is by simply doubling it each time and plot the graph between training
401:41 - error and validation error, and try to figure out what the optimal value of N estimators is. Now,
401:48 - N estimators is unique in the sense that it does not really add complexity to the model because it's
401:54 - bringing more randomness and ultimately your averaging results from each decision tree. So
401:59 - a tree by itself is not getting bigger. So complexity is not really increasing, but at the
402:05 - same time, it is bringing some randomness. So you can keep increasing N estimators to a fairly large
402:10 - value without worrying about overfitting on the data. Unlike some other hyper parameters like max
402:18 - depth and max leaf nodes. So you have max depth. A max depth is passed directly to the decision
402:24 - tree. Similarly, max leaf nodes is passed directly to the decision tree. So we've seen both of these
402:29 - in context of the decision trees already. Now, when you pass max depth or max leaf nodes to a
402:35 - random forest, that is going to get applied to every single decision tree. It is true.
402:40 - And by default, no maximum depth is specified, which is why every tree has a training accuracy
402:46 - of close to a hundred percent on the training data. And you can specify max depth to reduce
402:54 - overfitting. So if you feel that you're, or if you observe that your random forest model is
402:59 - overfitting, which means that the training error is going down, but the test error is going up,
403:05 - then specifying the max depth may be a way to limit the complexity of the model and get to a
403:11 - better position. So let's try that out. So what we want to do is we want to try out a random forest
403:16 - with a certain max depth, and maybe we want to try two or three values. Now, because this is
403:22 - getting a bit repetitive, or what I've done is I've written a simple function called test params,

406:09 - power of five, which means 32. So if we have a maximum of 32 leaf nodes, we can only get to about
406:15 - 83.2% accuracy. But if we have a, we, if we allow two to the power of 20, which means that's, I
406:23 - believe that is 2048. Oh no, that two to the power of 20 is a lot of nodes. That's about a million
406:32 - nodes, I guess you have the leaf nodes, but in any case, the tree itself is not going to ever get

406:47 - So anyway, when you have unbounded max leaf nodes, you get to about 85.6%. I guess there is still a
406:53 - bound here probably. And here you have the base. So this is without any of the hyper parameters.
406:59 - You see, there are certain differences here. You have 85.59%. Here you have 85.65%. Here you have
407:06 - 85.70% and maybe there is a combination of max depth and max leaf nodes that can give you a good
407:16 - result. So it's worth figuring out, right? So it's worth trying out different values of max leaf
407:21 - nodes and max depth. And the thing to remember is that the optimal value is somewhere in between.
407:27 - If it's too low, then your model is not powerful enough. If it is too high, then the model is too
407:31 - powerful and it has, it started to memorize and overfit on the training data. So it's somewhere
407:36 - in between and your job as the machine learning practitioner is to figure out what that sweet
407:42 - spot is. And the way to do that is by trying multiple values. One thing you could do is you could
407:46 - try maybe increments of five increments of 10, or maybe increments of just doubling the max depth
407:52 - and max size. Okay. As we did above for a decision tree, you can do the exact same. You can, you can
407:59 - vary the value of max depth, plot the graph between training error and validation error, and figure
408:04 - out the optimal value of max depth that way, and then do the same for max leaf, and then try to
408:09 - combine the two and see if that helps you in any way. Next up, we have max features. Now, instead
408:19 - of picking all the features for every split. So instead of using, and we have a bunch of features,
408:26 - right? We have, let's call X train and let's check the columns. So we have 119 columns. Now, instead
408:36 - of using all 119 columns for every single split, we can specify that only a fraction of the features
408:44 - should be chosen randomly to figure out a split. So here's what I mean by that. You have your data
408:51 - set here with a bunch of features. So this is your data set. Let's let's say this is your data frame.
408:58 - And in your data frame, you have a bunch of columns. Now, typically when a decision tree is
409:05 - created, you look at all the columns. So you check this column, find the best split. You check this
409:11 - column, this column, this column, this column, you check every column. And for each column, you check
409:15 - all possible splits. You check this split, this split, this split, the split, the split, all of
409:19 - these, and you pick the best split. And that's how you decide. Now the trouble with random forest is
409:25 - if you are training two decision trees and you're using this exact same logic of checking all the
409:30 - columns and then checking all possible splits, then this split, let's say this is a greater than seven
409:36 - and this split are going to be the same. Now the two splits are the same. Then it's likely that these
409:42 - next splits are also going to be the same. And then it's likely that the next splits are also going
409:47 - to be the same. So you're not really training multiple decision trees. You're just training
409:50 - a hundred copies of the same decision tree. So you're not really gaining from that randomness
409:55 - and averaging out of errors. So what do you do instead is you specify that for my first decision
410:02 - or for the first split that is being done, I randomly pick a fraction of the columns. So I
410:08 - pick a fraction. Now this fraction is going to be, maybe I pick this column, I pick this column,
410:13 - I pick this column, and I pick this column. So I pick a random selection of columns. And then
410:17 - for those columns, I try all the different splits. And maybe after trying those splits,
410:21 - I figured out that maybe this column is the best. So if this column is the best, then here I'm
410:25 - checking for C and the next time I do a split, I randomly pick a certain fraction of columns.
410:32 - Maybe I pick this, pick this and pick this. And based on that performance split. And then
410:38 - similarly, there's another decision tree being trained in parallel in another thread. Now here
410:42 - also you're picking a random column. So you're picking random selection of column. Maybe you're
410:47 - picking this, this, and this. So what this does is each split, whether it is in the same tree or
410:53 - across different trees, each split is randomized because it uses only a certain fraction of columns.
411:02 - Now, this is again, a bit counterintuitive that using a fraction of the columns,
411:08 - doing randomized splits is better than doing single splits, better doing better than doing
411:14 - perfect splits, where you look at all possible columns and all possible splits, because your
411:20 - objective is not to fit and memorize the training set. Your objective is to generalize. So your
411:25 - objective is to learn general trends. And the way you learn general trends is by dropping
411:30 - random information here and there while training, right? You're skipping some of the columns and
411:34 - that helps you that forces you to learn some general trends rather than specific
411:40 - relationships or specific values within specific columns.
411:43 - So here are the values that you can specify for max features. You can specify auto SQRT
411:50 - log two, or you can specify an integer, or you can specify a float. Now the interesting thing is by
411:56 - default, the value is auto. And what does auto do? So when you specify auto, or you don't specify
412:02 - anything in a random forest by default, it picks the square root of the number of features. So how
412:07 - many features do we have here? We have 119 features. The square root of that is
412:11 - around 11. So every decision tree or every split only looks at 11 features. Every split does not
412:19 - look at 119 features by default. And that is how each decision tree in the forest is different. So
412:26 - I remember we mentioned there is some randomness. So this is that randomness each decision tree in
412:31 - the forest is different. And while it may seem counterintuitive, choosing all features for every
412:36 - split of every tree will just lead to identical trees. So this will overfit badly to the training
412:42 - set. The entire random forest will basically become just copies of the same tree and will not
412:46 - generalize well. So if you don't want to go so aggressive as square root, you can probably, you
412:53 - can specify an actual number. Let's say you want to pick exactly 10 features or you want to pick
412:59 - exactly 20 features each time, or you can specify a fraction. Let's say you want to pick maybe 30
413:04 - percent of the features for each split, or you can also specify a logarithm, a log to the base two,
413:10 - which is also another way to just, these are all different ways of just specifying what fraction
413:14 - of features to pick. Now, remember the overfitting curve. This comes in here as well. If you pick
413:21 - too few features, then your model will not be powerful enough because it is really, let's say,
413:26 - if you just allow it to pick one feature randomly, then it's not really learning. It's just having
413:31 - to pick up, pick a feature and make a split on that feature. So you are going to end up in this
413:36 - space, but if you allow it to pick all the features, then you are going to end up in this space. So
413:41 - somewhere in between is a sweet spot. And through practice, again, this, this must be the result of
413:46 - some paper, which is looked at all possible splits and through in practice, they may have found that
413:51 - square root is a good percentage of features to pick, not to mean that this is the best for every
413:58 - dataset, but in general, it's a good percentage of features to pick as a default. But you should
414:04 - experiment with this because for your dataset, it may be different. So here I'm just going to call
414:09 - test parameters with max features log two. So this is going to take log to the base two of 112,
414:17 - 119, which is about seven, I believe. So it will take seven features. And then I'm also manually
414:25 - testing three features, six features, and maybe I can even try something like 0.3. So if I specify
414:30 - an integer, it's going to pick exactly that many features. I specify a fraction between zero and
