416:02 - like it's a reasonable increase to have. All right. Let's look at a few more and then we will
416:09 - wrap up here, but I hope you're starting to see the trend here. You want to understand what each
416:15 - hyper parameter does, and then you want to understand how it fits on the overfitting curve.
416:21 - And then you want to experiment and figure out the right piece where that hyper parameter needs
416:27 - to be used at. Okay. So I'm going to test a couple more. One is called the min sample split. And
416:35 - the other is called the min samples leaf. So by default, unless you have other parameters like
416:41 - max depth, et cetera, the decision tree classifier tries to split every node that has two or more.
416:48 - Rows of data inside it. So for example, here we have the entire dataset. And when we do a split,
416:55 - maybe 30% of rows go here and maybe 70% of rows go here. And then we do a split again. So some
417:01 - percentage of rows, some like end rows go here and end prime rows go here and so on. But as you keep
417:06 - going by default, the decision tree will keep splitting till we get to leaf nodes with just a
417:11 - single row of data inside it. And maybe this must be two. Okay. Or if it is three, then this will get
417:16 - to two, and then this will get to one and one. So you'll by default, it goes to that step. What you
417:22 - can do to regularize the tree to reduce the complexity of the tree. Again, this is another
417:27 - way of going about it is to say that a node should be split only if it has greater than seven rows.
417:34 - So if a node has less than seven rows, don't split it. That's one thing we can say. The other thing
417:41 - you can say is that when a node is split, then two leaves are created, right? Now, if these leaves
417:47 - are one and six, you can specify a minimum leaf size. You can say that the minimum leaf size is
417:52 - three. So a leaf will get created only, or this division will, this split will be performed only
418:00 - when the leaves have a size greater than three. Okay. So that's why these are two very connected
418:05 - things. This is one is the size to minimum size for splitting a node that even a split will be
418:11 - considered. And second, the minimum size for a leaf node that is created when you split a node,
418:17 - both of these, you can specify. So by default, you split a node, which has two or more rows of data.
418:23 - And by default, the default, the minimum leaf size is one. So that's just going out maximum overfitting
418:30 - as much as possible. But let's change that. Let's maybe change the minimum sample split to three
418:38 - and the minimal samples leave to two. So a node will be split only if there are at least three.
418:49 - Only if there are at least, well, that doesn't really make sense. Let me make that five. So
418:54 - the node will be split only if there are five rows of data inside it and a leaf, a node will be
419:02 - split only if the leaves created have at least two nodes, two rows of data each. So here it turns
419:08 - out that using a sample split of five, two gives you 85.5% accuracy, 85.56. So that's a reduction.
419:18 - And if you increase the size, if you increase a main sample size, that means you're saying that
419:23 - nodes must be larger and larger. So you are reducing the power of the tree because what you're
419:28 - essentially saying is that I'm not allowed to have a node of size two. I'm not allowed to have a node
419:32 - of size three, not allowed to have a node of, node of size five. I must have a node of size a hundred.
419:36 - I've said the main sample split 200. So nodes will not be split if they have less than a hundred
419:42 - rows. And here I've said the main sample leaves to 60 nodes will not be split if the leaves that
419:47 - they create are not of size 60. So that definitely reduces the power of the model. And because of that.
419:57 - We could end up in this situation here, right? So now what happens is a very high value for the
420:03 - size or the split size is going to put you in the low power space, the low complexity space,
420:11 - a very low value or a zero value or the default values put you in this space. So somewhere in
420:17 - between maybe around, let's say a split size of 10 and a node size of three or something like that
420:23 - is the best fit. So that is again, something that you have to explore. Okay.
420:29 - So that's about min sample split and min, min samples leave. Next up, just a couple more.
420:38 - And then we're done. One is the min impurity decrease. So here's yet another way of controlling
420:44 - the split. Now consider a point in the decision tree. So you have a point in the decision tree
420:54 - here, and this has a certain Gini value, right? Based on the most optimal split. Let's say this has a
420:59 - Gini value of 0.7. And then when you split it, you get two nodes and those nodes have Gini values of
421:08 - 0.68 and 0.69. So there's not really been a significant reduction in the Gini value, right?
421:15 - Because this was 0.7 and this is 0.68 and 0.69. If the most optimal split only leads to a negligible
421:22 - reduction in Gini value, then maybe the split is completely useless. It's just adding more
421:27 - complexity to the model. It's just causing overfitting. So what you can specify is that
421:32 - nodes should be split only when the decrease in the impurity is higher than a certain value. So
421:38 - I can specify that a node should be split only when the decrease in the Gini value, which means
421:44 - from 0.9 to 0.68 is higher than 0.1. Now 0.1 is a very high value. It should probably use something
421:50 - much lower, but just to give you an example. So this node will be split only when the Gini value
421:55 - goes from 0.7 to 0.6 or lower for each node, right? So that's the, that's the value. That's the
422:06 - purpose of min impurity decrease. And once again, by default, it is zero. So by default, whatever
422:12 - minimum or even zero reduction in the Gini value will allow creating multiple nodes will allow
422:18 - splitting, but if you want to control it, then we pass some, a value like this. Okay. Now, once
422:26 - again, where does this lie on the overfitting curve? Everywhere you see hyper parameters, you
422:31 - should start thinking about the overfitting curve, Gini value, a minimum threshold of zero, which
422:37 - means that we can split without having to worry about how much reduction in error in, in the Gini
422:42 - index there was that is maximum complexity. On the other hand, a very high value for the threshold
422:49 - that if you say that 0.1, a Gini value, a Gini reduction of 0.1 is required for a split that
422:55 - makes splits very hard. So that puts you in the low complexity zone. So somewhere in between you
423:00 - have the value of, which is the optimal for getting the maximum validation accuracy, right?
423:06 - Remember that's our goal, maximum validation accuracy. Now here, I recommend trying to
423:11 - try out powers of 10, 10 to the minus seven, 10 to the minus six, 10 to the minus five, and so on.
423:18 - And I found here, for example, we went, I think I found with 10 to the minus six or something,
423:24 - I found the best reduction. Yeah. But 10 to the minus six was where I saw the best value.
423:31 - So somewhere between zero and one or zero and 0.1, as you go with powers of 10, you will find the
423:40 - best min impurity decrease, where you have the maximum increase in the valid, where you have the
423:46 - maximum validation accuracy. Yeah. You can see here, when we set the minute impurity decrease to
423:50 - one E minus six. So that's 85.68% validation accuracy versus 85.59. All right. Last two,
424:02 - one is called, this one is called bootstrap and max samples. So one trick that I told you about
424:07 - random forest is by picking a random selection of features. That's good. But one, and that picks
424:15 - just a random selection of columns. Another trick that random forests apply is not to use the entire
424:21 - dataset for training each decision tree. Instead, it applies a technique called bootstrapping. And
424:27 - here's how bootstrapping works. Let's say you have a training dataset. So here we have a dataset
424:34 - with a whole bunch of rows, row one, row, two, row, three, row, four, row, five, row six. Typically
424:41 - to train a decision tree, and there are columns as well. So typically to train a decision tree,
424:47 - you would take this entire dataset and you would feed it into the decision tree algorithm. And
424:52 - that would figure out the optimal split, et cetera, et cetera. Bootstrapping works in a slightly
424:56 - different way. Now let's say you have, what's this? Let's say you have 10 rows. The way bootstrapping
425:04 - works is you randomly pick one of the 10 rows. Let's say you pick this and then you copy it here.
425:14 - Of course, it's only a conceptual copy. I'm not saying that an actual copy is created. Then you
425:19 - forget that you picked this row. And then once again, you randomly pick a row. And maybe this
425:24 - time you got this, and then you copy it here. Then you forget that you pick these two rows and then
425:30 - you randomly pick one another row and you get another row. Fine. Then you, again, you forget
425:35 - that you picked any rows and then you randomly pick and turns out maybe you pick this one again.
425:40 - And that's fine. So this row, this row will now come up here again. So now you have two copies
425:47 - of this row in, this is called a bootstrap. So this is called random picking with replacement.
425:53 - So you pick a row, but then you don't keep track of the fact that you've picked it already. And
425:59 - you allow yourself to pick it again. What this does is a couple of things. I know you can see by
426:06 - the end of this process, that by the time that I have 10 rows, maybe two of these rows got picked
426:10 - twice. And then some of these rows got picked once. And then some of these rows did not get picked.
426:16 - And then this is going to be used to train a decision tree. So one bootstrap is used to train
426:21 - one decision tree. And what this does is different bootstraps will drop different rows. So each
426:29 - decision tree will only be trained with on a particular fraction of the data rather than the
426:34 - entire data, because even though we are picking 10 rows, we are picking with replacement. So we are
426:38 - missing certain rows, potentially. And second, we also randomly assign like a double weight or a
426:45 - triple weight to rose when they get a big twice, right? Any, like initially, every row has equal
426:51 - weightage, but what we're saying is for certain decision trees, we are assigning a higher weight
426:56 - to certain rows because we are picking them twice or thrice in the dataset, right? And again, this is
427:01 - happening randomly. And this is happening for a hundred or hundreds of decision trees. And that's
427:06 - where all this randomness actually helps. Again, this is one of these techniques that has been
427:10 - tested empirically and has been shown to work. Well, papers have been written on it. And the
427:15 - authors of scikit-learn have very kindly made that the default within random forests. So by
427:21 - default bootstrap is set to true. And if you said bootstrap to false, what will happen is every
427:27 - decision tree will be trained using the entire dataset, which is one copy of each row. Now I let
427:34 - you decide which has better randomness. And I'll let you decide which will generalize better.
427:38 - Okay. So that's your bootstrap. And this entire system of picking a bootstrap, training a decision
427:48 - tree, picking another bootstrap, training, another decision tree, picking another bootstrap,
427:52 - training a decision tree. This is called a bag of bootstraps. So this is also sometimes called
427:58 - bagging. And one thing that you can also do is you can also control the size of each bootstrap.
428:04 - Now here, what I said was you have 10 rows of data and you keep picking randomly with replacement
428:09 - till you get 10 rows, even if they may have copies, but you can actually decide that maybe
428:14 - you just want to pick seven rows with random replacement. So that's called the bag of little
428:18 - bootstraps where you don't use the entire dataset, but you train a decision tree, or maybe you just
428:24 - want to pick a 20% fraction. So you train using bootstrapping and you train and you only pick
428:31 - samples of a certain size. So for example, and here, by the way, without bootstrapping, you can
428:37 - see that the accuracy is about the same. In this case, it did not make a big difference, but maybe
428:42 - in certain other datasets, you will see it's different. But what you can do is you can pick,
428:46 - you can specify when bootstrapping is set to true that you want to pick only a certain number of
428:51 - samples or only a certain fraction of samples. So instead of picking a bootstrap of size 98,000,
428:58 - which is the size of the training set. Maybe you want to pick a bootstrap of just 90% of the rows.
429:05 - Right? So you, you pick just, I don't know about 89, 80, 89 or 90,000 rows, not 98,000. And you pick
429:12 - them with replacement using the bootstrapping technique. And again, that will help you. That
429:18 - will, that will help you by reducing over-pitting. If each decision tree is being trained on a
429:24 - smaller fraction, then there is more randomization across trees. So then there is more, then there
429:31 - is more generalization. And you can see here, we got to 85.65 from 85.59. So that's a small
429:38 - increase. Once again, on the over-fitting curve, if max samples are set to one, which means you're
429:45 - picking as many as possible, then you are on the high complexity side. Then you are in the over-fitting
429:51 - side. If max samples is set to zero or 0.01 or something like that, where you're only putting,
429:56 - picking one person of the rows for each decision tree, then each decision tree is very weak, very
430:01 - less powerful. So that's going to be on the low power side. So somewhere in between is where you
430:06 - will have the optimal value. Okay. The last one, and this is slightly tangential, but the last one
430:14 - is class weight. Now, one of the things we have in our data set, especially is this particular data
430:21 - set, especially if you look at the targets and you check the value counts. Let's call that train
430:33 - targets and check the value counts. You have 76,000 knows and just 22,000 yeses. And then you
430:42 - divide this by the length. So Len off train targets. So 77%, 77.8% knows and only 22%
431:00 - yeses. So that there aren't many yeses here. And maybe you want to give higher weight, higher
431:06 - weightage to the rows, which have, yes, right? Simply because you have a very low number of rows
431:13 - with that particular weight. So you want to give that weight, you want to with that particular
431:17 - class. So you want to give rows with that class, a higher weightage. You want your decision tree
431:23 - to consider them twice as important or three times as important or four times as important
431:29 - in your calculation. So you can do that. And the way you do that is by specifying
431:34 - class weight, when you create the random forest. So when you create the random forest, you specify
431:38 - a class weight, and you can either give like a proper class weight to each one. So you can say
431:42 - for the no class, we set a weight of one. So each row of the no class will have a weight of one
431:48 - and each row of the yes class will have a weight of two. And that is going to be used somehow in
431:53 - the Gini calculation and somehow in the splitting. But the, the underlying concept is that more
431:58 - weightage will be given to the class. Yes. So you can specify that and you can compare that with
432:05 - the base, which is to give equal weightage to every class or equal weightage to every row, no
432:10 - matter what, or you can also specify a term like this balanced. So if you specify balanced and you
432:16 - can check out the documentation here, scikit learn will automatically figure out that. Okay. You have
432:21 - four times as many knows than you have yeses. So maybe I'm or three times as many. So maybe I'm
432:26 - going to apply a weight of three. So the inverse ratio is going to get applied as the weight of
432:31 - that particular class. So yes, it's going to get a weight of three or 3.5 and no, it's going to have
432:36 - a weight of one, right? That may not be ideal. You may not want to give so, so higher weight. So
432:42 - probably something in this range might work best for you where you manually give a slightly higher
432:47 - weight to the class, which is underrepresented. And you can see here, we go from 85.59 to 85.7
432:55 - to 85.65 simply by applying a class weight to yes. Okay. And once again, with class weights,
433:04 - there is an optimal value somewhere. It's not one, one is not optimal and one four is not optimal.
433:10 - You can see that this actually led to a reduction. Maybe somewhere around one, two is optimal for
433:15 - this particular balance. And this is the central theme in machine learning. You will have hyper
433:21 - parameters. One end of the hyper parameter will lead to a very bad result for training and
433:28 - validation because it just is going to reduce the power of the model. And the other end of the
433:34 - hyper parameter is going to lead to a very low training loss or training error, but a very high
433:40 - validation error because it's going to overfit. It's going to be really powerful. Okay. And your
433:45 - job will always be to kind of find the central, find the middle path, find the optimal fit for
433:51 - the data so that the model learns enough, but does not overfit to the training data. And normally
433:58 - you will be modifying all of these things together. So you would set up something like this. You
434:02 - would set up a model here. You have a random forest classifier and you would set up maybe the number
434:07 - of estimators, the number of features, the depth, the class, the weight, you will try some experiments
434:12 - and you will figure out which direction you need to go in. If you change and there's no single way
434:17 - to just look at the number and tell whether you should increase or decrease this, what you should
434:22 - be looking at is what happens when you increase this and what happens when you decrease this.
434:26 - And that will help you decide whether you are in this region. So if we look at the overfitting
434:32 - chart, remember, this is how the training loss goes. And this is how the validation loss goes.
434:38 - So you want to figure out whether you are in this region or you're in this region. Now, if you're in
434:43 - this region, then you can increase the complexity of the model to get to the optimal fit because
434:48 - there's still a possible reduction in the validation loss. And if you're in this region,
434:53 - then you need to reduce the complexity of the model because your validation loss can actually
434:59 - be lower by with a less complex model because your model is overfitting. Okay.
435:04 - So let's try an example here, and then you can play around with this. So apply this, exactly
435:08 - this technique, have the overfitting curve in your head as you work through this. And let's see if
435:14 - after applying all of these random forest, all of these hyper parameters, do we actually get
435:19 - anything useful out of it? Okay. Now I have picked here 500 estimators and seven features, a maximum
435:26 - of seven features. Maybe I should change that to 20, a maximum depth of 30, and a maximum depth
435:33 - of 20 and class weights of one comma 1.5. So this is, this is bringing some regularization for sure.
435:42 - This is also, this is probably increasing the power because max features by default is log N.
435:48 - And this is again, probably bringing some regularization. Well, I guess this is increasing
435:54 - the power of the model as well. So you have to now think about which lies in which area, right?
436:00 - And one exercise for you is to try and modify all of these and see what is the best accuracy
436:05 - that you can get to. So play around with these hyper parameters. Let's give that a second.
436:10 - I think this gets to about an 85.7% accuracy. Finally. Yeah. It's just scoring the data now.
436:22 - Okay. 85.61. I guess in my previous run with certain changes in hyper parameters,
436:27 - I got to about 85.7% accuracy. Maybe I'm just going to run this again,
436:35 - but we increased the accuracy from 84.5% with a single decision tree fine-tuned to 85.7% with
436:43 - a well-tuned random forest. Now, depending on the kind of dataset and the kind of problem,
436:48 - you may or may not find this valuable and you may or may not find the significant or you may not,
436:53 - or you may or may not even see a significant improvement because with your hyper parameter
436:57 - tuning. So it's not that if you tune the right hyper parameters, you will get a hundred percent
437:04 - accuracy, a hundred percent validation accuracy. That's almost never going to happen. And this
437:11 - could be due to one of the following reasons. And this is the order in which you should try to
437:15 - explain what's happening when your model is not improving. The first thing is simply that you
437:20 - may not have found the right mix of hyper parameters. Maybe some of your hyper parameters
437:25 - are still on the low complexity side. And some of your hyper parameters are on the high complexity
437:30 - side. Some are overfitting, some are under fitting, which is the opposite of overfitting.
437:34 - So you need to bring all hyper parameters into the right range. And so you need to maybe keep
437:39 - trying to improve the model. That's one possible region. That's one possible reason why your
437:46 - validation loss is not increasing. The second possible reason is that you may have reached
437:51 - the limits of the modeling technique that you're currently using, which is random forest. It's
437:56 - just as logistic regression has a limitation that any, any nonlinear relationships it will
438:02 - not be able to capture. Similarly, random forest also have certain limitations primarily because
438:11 - we are using decision trees and we are using a averaging between decision trees. It's possible
438:16 - that certain types of relationships cannot get captured. For example, in a decision tree, you're
438:23 - always making a binary decision. So if let's say you're a very simple model where the target is
438:28 - simply a linear multiple of one of the features, your decision tree will have to create a huge,
438:37 - will have to create a huge tree because your decision tree cannot capture these proportional
438:41 - relationships. It's just target is 10 times of a certain feature that that kind of relation does
438:46 - not get captured. So modeling random forest may not work well in such a case. Okay. So when you
438:54 - have linearity linear models work well and entry based models may not work well. And when you do
439:01 - not have linearity, then tree based models are likely to work well. Here's, so we're kind of
439:08 - peeling back. So the most immediate problem may be hyper parameters, but when you've tried and
439:12 - tried and figured out the hyper parameters are not the problem, then maybe the next most immediate
439:17 - problem is a modeling technique. And maybe then you should try a different modeling technique.
439:22 - And then it's possible that maybe you've simply reached some limits of what you can predict using
439:26 - the given amount of data, and we may need more data to improve the model. So think about it.
439:31 - We have data for 10 years. If we had data for one years, would your model be better or worse?
439:36 - I think it would be worse because we have less data. And if we had data for 20 years or a hundred
439:42 - years, would your model be better or worse? I think it would be better. So whenever you get more data,
439:48 - it's possible to train better and better models. So at some point you're going to reach the limits
439:53 - of what you can predict using the given amount of data. That's one possibility. But beyond that,
440:02 - another possibility is let's say you've gathered as much data as possible, and you're still not
440:06 - seeing an improvement, then you may have reached the limit of how well we can predict whether it
440:11 - will rain tomorrow, given just the, using just the given weather measurements. Like we have only 20
440:16 - columns there are, and these 20 columns are arbitrary measure weather measurements that
440:20 - we have invented. There is no physical law that states that the rain tomorrow depends on just
440:26 - these 20 columns and can be predicted accurately. So maybe we need more features. Maybe we need to
440:31 - take more measurements. Maybe we need to take more accurate measurements to further improve the model.
440:35 - Maybe we need to take the rain, not just in the particular region, but maybe we need to consider
440:41 - rain within a larger radius. Maybe we need to consider winds within a larger radius. Maybe we
440:47 - need to consider ocean temperature, et cetera, et cetera. So in many cases, adding new features
440:52 - or adding new columns to the model definitely helps with modeling. And in a lot of cases,
440:57 - we can also generate new features using existing features. This is called feature engineering.
441:02 - And we will look at feature engineering briefly the next time. So adding new features can help.
441:08 - And finally, it's possible that rain tomorrow may be an inherently random or chaotic phenomenon,
441:16 - which simply cannot be predicted beyond a certain accuracy. It's possible that maybe you cannot
441:21 - predict whether it will rain tomorrow, given any amount of data for any number of other
441:26 - measurements with any modeling technique beyond 90% accuracy. It's just not possible. And that's why
441:33 - we have our validation sets and our test sets to remind us of the reality that it's not all about
441:40 - just the training data. You have to make predictions in the real world and your models will fail after
441:45 - a certain point, right? So what do you want to take away from this is that ultimately all models
441:51 - are wrong, but some models are useful. If you can rely on a model that we created today to make a
441:58 - travel decision for tomorrow, or maybe if airline airlines can rely on this model to decide on
442:05 - whether or not they should fly tomorrow, how many flights they should schedule tomorrow.
442:09 - And if that saves them money, then the model is useful. Even if though, even if sometimes it may
442:14 - be wrong, even if one out of 10 times it is wrong, on the other hand, if you cannot rely on this
442:20 - model, then it's practically useless, right? So ultimately all models come down to their
442:24 - practical utility. So whenever you ask, what is a good accuracy or what is a good model or what is,
442:29 - is this good enough? The question is, you should be asking what is the purpose we are looking to
442:34 - use it for? And in its current state, is this model good enough to be used? Okay. So that's
442:39 - just something for you to think about just more generally as a bigger picture of machine learning.
442:45 - Okay. So that's all we have for today. And finally, one last thing you should do is you
442:50 - should also compute the accuracy of the model on the test set. And now you'll see what I'm talking
442:54 - about when I say train validation and test set split. Remember on the validation set,
442:59 - we got to 85.68%. Well, what's happened is that we have been manually testing so many different
443:06 - models and we may have overfitted our choice of hyper parameters to the validation set, right?
443:13 - So think of yourself as a machine learning algorithm that's picking the right hyper parameters
443:18 - and you are now overfitted to the validation set. So the test set is there to give you the human,
443:23 - the reality check that maybe you shouldn't be trying to optimize, over-optimize the validation
443:28 - set. Maybe you should just do a more principle thinking about what will generalize the model
443:34 - better and just choose that. Okay. So that's why you have a test set at the very end, which
443:40 - you should just use at the very end to report the final accuracy of your model. Okay. And then just
443:46 - like last time, you can make predictions on the model. So you can do that. Here's an input,
443:51 - and then you can, we've written a helper function here to generate a prediction on the, and we get
443:57 - like a 77% probability that it's going to rain tomorrow given these inputs. Okay. And you can
444:03 - save and load the model so you can take the model and the imputer and the scaler and the input
444:08 - columns, target columns, et cetera, save it into a job lip file, load it back, and it should work
444:15 - exactly the same way. So that's all we have for today. We looked at how to download a real world
444:20 - dataset. We looked at how to prepare a dataset for training. We looked at how to train and
444:25 - interpret decision trees. We looked at how to interpret random forests. We entrain them. We
444:31 - looked at overfitting hyper parameter tuning and regularization. One of the most central
444:36 - problems in machine learning that you will spend most of your time breaking your head over making
444:41 - predictions on single inputs is something that we looked at the last time and this time as well.
444:45 - It's pretty straightforward. You just set up a function to do that. And then we also introduced
444:49 - a bunch of different terms. So you should start becoming familiar with these terms because you
444:54 - will see them in tutorials that you see online. You will see, you will probably get asked these
444:59 - terms in interviews and try to get a good intuitive understanding and maybe come up with
445:03 - your own one line description here. And that's more important than any description than we can
445:08 - give you. So definitely try and write a one line description for these. And if you want to check
445:13 - out some of these resources, you can check these out decision trees and random forest can be used
445:18 - not just for classification, but also for regression problems. For example,
445:22 - predicting the price of a house. So here are some examples that you can check out the topic for
445:29 - today is how to approach machine learning projects. And we are going to look at a step-by-step
445:36 - process that you can apply for approaching ML problems all the way from conceptualizing and
445:41 - identifying a problem to performing data cleaning preparation, then building some baseline models,
445:48 - doing some model training and evaluation, then maybe regularizing your models and performing
445:54 - some ensembling and finally, interpreting and presenting your results. So this is roughly what
446:00 - the process looks like. And here are the steps in a little more detail. So the first step is to
446:08 - understand the business requirements because machine learning models are always used to serve
446:13 - some business requirement and understand the nature of available data, which tells you how
446:20 - good your model can possibly be, or whether it is possible to even build a model at all.
446:25 - The second is to then classify the problem as a supervised learning problem or an unsupervised
446:30 - learning problem. And so far, we've only been looking at supervised learning, but we will talk
446:36 - about a couple of examples of unsupervised learning as well. And if it is supervised,
446:42 - then whether it is a regression problem or a classification problem, next, you need to download
446:48 - clean, explore the data and possibly create new features that may improve models. So this
446:54 - process is called feature engineering, where the data may not be in a format that makes it very
447:02 - easy for the model to learn from it. So we will look at some ways of doing feature engineering.
447:07 - Next, you create a training test validation split and prepare the data for training machine
447:12 - learning models. So this covers things like imputing missing data, scaling the data and
447:19 - encoding categorical data. The next step is to create a quick and easy baseline model to
447:24 - evaluate and benchmark future models. This is a very important step in any large machine
447:30 - learning project. You want to know what the baseline is so that you don't waste your time
447:34 - on models that are not any better than a very simple approach that you can take somewhere.
447:43 - Next, you pick a certain modeling strategy, train a model, tune hyper parameters, and try to
447:51 - achieve the optimal fit for that modeling strategy. And then you repeat that with the different
447:55 - strategies. So this way you can try a bunch of different modeling strategies and figure out
447:59 - which one works best for the problem. Next, you experiment and combine results from multiple
448:06 - strategies. If possible to get a better result, you may also have to do some regularization,
448:13 - some hyper parameter tuning. And finally, you need to interpret the model,
448:18 - study individual predictions and present your findings.
448:21 - And that's the most important piece, because ultimately your model is going to be used for
448:27 - making individual predictions. And you will have to explain why your model gives the result that
448:35 - it gives. And you will have to present all of this to non-technical stakeholders. So we'll talk a
448:42 - little bit about that too. Okay. Now we're running this code. We're running this code. We're running
448:48 - this code on Google Colab, but you can also run it on your computer locally. Just follow these
448:54 - instructions. So first let's install the required libraries and import them as well. So we are using
449:02 - NumPy for numerical computing pandas for working with data frames, matplotlib, plotly, and seaborn
449:08 - for visualization. And we have the Jovian library for recording snapshots of this notebook. Then we
449:13 - have the open datasets library for downloading data and scikit learn contains all our machine
449:19 - learning algorithms. And let's import all of them too. And we are also setting certain styles for
449:25 - the graph so that our graphs look nicer. Now let's talk about step one. The first step is to
449:38 - understand business requirements and study the nature of the data. The first step is to understand
449:43 - how most machine learning models are trained to serve a real world use case. So it's very
449:49 - important that you understand why you're building a model, what the objectives are, and the nature
449:54 - of the data you have available before you start building a machine learning model. And the best
449:58 - way to do this is by asking questions. So you want to start out by understanding the big picture
450:06 - about why a company cares about a machine learning problem or why somebody's asking you to build a
450:13 - machine learning model and figure out if an, if an ML model is even required in the first place, or
450:20 - maybe you can do something simpler and more effective. Okay. So typically you're either given
450:28 - some data along with some documentation and maybe a problem statement, or you have to talk to
450:34 - somebody. So you have to discuss something with stakeholders and figure things out in either case,
450:39 - whether you have written descriptions and written requirements, or whether you have, whether you're
450:43 - talking to somebody, you should try and ask some of these questions. For example, what is the business
450:52 - problem that you're trying to solve using machine learning? And we'll look at a few examples here,
450:57 - but we'll look at a couple of datasets and we'll ask the questions in that context. But for example,
451:02 - it could be increased sales of a particular product that could be a business problem.
451:08 - It could be to reduce churn. So reduce the number of people leaving your service or your subscription
451:14 - service. It could be to increase conversion of some kind. So the number of people who come on a page,
451:19 - you want them to more of them to buy a certain thing. It could be forecasting of some kinds where
451:28 - you're trying to forecast a value in the future. For example, whether or not it will rain tomorrow or
451:33 - what the sales in a particular location of your business are going to be. So you need to ask what
451:40 - the business problem that you're trying to solve is. And if you, if you don't know what that problem
451:45 - is, then you may not be aligned and you may not really be able to create the best model for the
451:52 - problem. And the next question is to understand why we're interested in solving this problem and
451:57 - what impact it will have on the business. Now, typically there are two or three reasons why
452:02 - people look to machine learning. One is to automate some manual tasks. So there are certain
452:08 - manual tasks or where it either requires a lot of people or it requires some special expertise.
452:16 - And so it is expensive. And that is one reason why people want to automate manual tasks.
452:22 - Another case is if they want to predict the future, and there is no easy way to do that
452:27 - except by looking at all the data we have. So it's sort of an extension of a statistician,
452:33 - but you want to automate that system. So instead of a statistician, having to make forecasts,
452:38 - make a lot of different forecasts. You can just set up a model and the model can give you forecasts.
452:43 - And typically there is some kind of a revenue impact on the business. If not revenue, then maybe
452:48 - there is some impact related to customers, some impact related to some other stakeholders,
452:54 - like partners. So you need to understand what the reason for solving the problem is and what impact
453:01 - it will have on the business. And all, all of this will inform the kind of models you train. All of
453:05 - this will inform the level of interpretability that you will require and the level of complexity
453:11 - that you can use in your models. Next thing you want to know is how is this problem solved currently
453:17 - without any machine learning tools. And in a lot of cases, if you just study this, you will
453:23 - figure out that maybe there is a better way to just improve the process that is used to solve the
453:28 - problem. And maybe you don't really need a machine learning tool, right? Maybe you don't really need
453:33 - a machine learning model. You can also study the cost of building a machine learning model, which
453:38 - is in terms of time and in terms of the people involved and the potential impact the machine
453:45 - learning model will have on the business. Now, obviously the cost of building a machine learning
453:49 - model is higher than the potential savings or earnings that it can create. Then maybe it's not
453:58 - that useful to create a machine learning model, right? Maybe at a smaller stage, it's better to
454:03 - solve the problem using manual processes or some kind of an intelligent estimate.
454:11 - Next, you need to understand who will use the results of the model and how will it fit into
454:15 - other business processes? Your model will not be used in isolation. It will be part of some
454:19 - other system. So you need to understand how they're going to use it. And this is the kind of issue
454:24 - where sometimes the other team is going to use your model more as a yes, no decision point.
454:34 - And in that case, you should create a classification model, but if they're going to look at the exact
454:39 - number, then in that case, maybe you should create a regression model. So the kind of model that you
454:43 - train depends on how it is going to be used. So this is all about the problem. Like why are
454:48 - we doing this? What, what problem are we looking at? Next, we talk about how much historical data
454:54 - do we have and how was it collected? So it's important to understand the scale of the data
454:59 - and the nature of collection. Now, if it was entered manually, if there was some manual
455:03 - digitization involved, then maybe there might be errors. If it was collected through some sensors,
455:08 - then what are the calibration issues those sensors might have? If it was collected from the internet,
455:13 - do we have the rights to use this data, et cetera, et cetera. And these are also places where you
455:19 - might want to think about bias and think about whether it is ethical to use a certain kind of
455:25 - data. For example, is it ethical to use race to decide whether somebody should be given a loan or
455:33 - not. Right. Next, you talk about what features does the historical data contain? So you get a
455:41 - list of columns. You try to understand if those features will help you make the kind of model
455:48 - that you want to create. And very importantly, you need to understand if you have historical data
455:52 - for the values you're trying to predict. So far in all our models, we've seen that we need the
455:57 - target column in our training data set. So if you do not have the values that you're trying to
456:02 - predict, then the data is not useful for machine learning. So the first thing then you will need
456:06 - to do is you will need to add labels or add the targets into the model before you can create a
456:12 - model, then understand the known issues with the data. If there are any data entry errors,
456:18 - or if there's any missing data, sometimes what happens is missing data is just replaced with a
456:21 - zero or a minus one. If there, if the data was limited intentionally at between a certain range,
456:27 - et cetera, et cetera, there are different units. Maybe one person was reporting in kilometers.
456:31 - One person was reporting in miles. All of these are issues that you have to anticipate. Nobody
456:37 - will tell you in advance. I mean, some people will, but in general, you will have to ask people
456:42 - questions and figure them out and then look at some sample rows from the dataset. So if you're
456:46 - in a discussion with someone, you just asked them to show you some sample rows from the dataset.
456:51 - And then once you can actually see the data on your screen, you can ask a lot of questions about
456:56 - the data and you want to figure out how representative the sample is of the entire dataset,
457:02 - right? So you need to be very curious about data. And before you even get into modeling and before
457:09 - you get into ED, et cetera, you need to be curious about the business problem. And you need to ask
457:13 - as many questions as possible, as you can think of, right? And the last thing is to figure out
457:19 - where the data is stored and how will you get access to it? So data can be stored in multiple
457:23 - places. Sometimes you may have to combine data from multiple sources. Sometimes those data
457:28 - access to that data is split across multiple teams. So you, it is your job as a data scientist,
457:34 - as a data science professional to figure out, to make sure that you have access to the
457:38 - right data, right? So that's some questions that you should ask when working on a machine learning
457:44 - problem to get you started. But there are many more that you can ask, right? And if you have
457:50 - any other questions you think which should show up in this list, please feel free to add them
457:54 - in the chat. The main idea is to gather as much information about the problem as possible so that
458:00 - you have a clear understanding of the objective and the feasibility of the project, right?
458:06 - In a lot of cases, machine learning projects are simply infeasible because of
458:12 - a very ambitious problem statement. Like you're trying to do something that is really difficult
458:17 - to do, or because the data isn't good enough or the dataset isn't large enough, right? So
458:22 - before you even build a project, you need to understand the feasibility of the project.
458:27 - And that is something that you can do once you ask a lot of these questions.
458:32 - And of course, you're not working in a professional setting right now. So how do you
458:38 - apply the same strategy, apply the same process to your projects? So whenever possible, try to
458:44 - work with real world datasets. That means try to work with data obtained from real businesses.
458:50 - And Kaggle is a great source of real world datasets. If you just go to Kaggle.com slash
458:54 - datasets, and we've talked about how to get data, search data on Kaggle. All you do is you
459:01 - select, you go down here, you select some filters. Like if you're looking for tabular data, select
459:06 - CSV. If you're looking for a large dataset, put in a number like hundred MB and apply this,
459:12 - these filters, and then maybe search for let's say finance. If you are interested in some kind
459:19 - of financial data and then sort this by the most votes. Okay. So now we are searching for finance
459:26 - datasets greater than a hundred MB in CSV format. And now you have historical data for Bitcoin. Now
459:33 - that is real world data, or here is again, stock histories for Amex NYSE NASDAQ. That is real world
459:42 - data. You have parking tickets, data that's real world data. So Kaggle is a great place to find
459:53 - real world datasets. And another thing you should check out on Kaggle is Kaggle competitions. Now
459:59 - Kaggle competitions are also held on real world data. So for example, if you look at Optiver
460:05 - realized volatility, this competition that's currently ongoing. So the data for this competition
460:13 - is given by a company called Optiver and they have established a objective that you need to meet by
460:20 - building a machine learning model. And if you're able to do that, and if you're among the top three,
460:25 - then you can earn tens of thousands of dollars. Now on Kaggle, you're probably not going to,
460:33 - you're probably not going to take part in competitions for the sake of earning because
460:36 - it's really difficult and it's very unlikely as well. It's a bit unpredictable, but it's a great
460:43 - learning process. So what we will do is we will pick an older competition on Kaggle. So we will
460:51 - go through this Kaggle competition, the Rossman store sales prediction competition, and we'll try
460:57 - and answer all of these questions here. And then we'll try and build a machine learning model.
461:03 - So here's the Rossman store sales competition. And the objective here is stated very clearly
461:09 - forecast sales using store promotion and competitor data. So it's about sales forecasting. You have
461:15 - certain stores or Rossman has a bunch of stores across, I believe a bunch of European countries.
461:24 - Okay. Let's, let's just read this Rossman stores. Rossman operates over 3000 drug stores in seven
461:29 - European countries. And currently Rossman store managers are tasked with predicting their daily
461:34 - sales for up to six weeks in advance. So you can see here, there is a human element involved here.
461:39 - Somebody has to predict their sales and based on their predictions, maybe they can order inventory,
461:44 - et cetera. And not only is human element involved here, it's a manual process, but it's also an
461:50 - error prone process because what is the formula they're applying to make these predictions,
461:55 - right? So everybody has their own approach. So you want to the Rossman wants to standardize this
462:00 - and they know that sales store store sales are influenced by many factors. For example,
462:06 - whether there's a promotion running, whether there's some kind of a competition running
462:10 - between stores, whether it's a holiday or the seasonality and the locality. So with thousands
462:17 - of individual managers predicting sales, the accuracy of the results can be quite varied,
462:22 - right? So now we understand, now we can start to answer some of these questions.
462:26 - Now we can start to answer some of these questions. What's the business problem?
462:30 - We want to predict sales. Why are we interested? Because we have thousands of stores. Everybody
462:35 - tries to make predictions in a different way. If we could standardize it, then we could save a lot
462:40 - of money because then we would not have too little inventory or too much inventory. Our
462:47 - revenue predictions will be more accurate. And based on that, maybe our cost allocations can
462:53 - be more accurate. How is this problem solved currently without machine learning tools? Well
462:59 - by these managers individually. So now at this point you could ask, how can you improve this
463:07 - without using machine learning? So one simple thing that you can try and do is maybe create
463:11 - some kind of a formula. Maybe just do some statistical analysis and create a formula
463:16 - that all managers can put a bunch of variables into and get a result out of it, right? Now,
463:23 - how do you create that formula? One way to create that formula is to train a machine learning model,
463:28 - ultimately a machine learning model is a formula that's just a little more complicated. But the
463:34 - other way is to maybe just do some analysis over the historical data and come up with something
463:39 - manually. And that's perfectly fine. In a lot of cases, it works just fine. How much historical
463:44 - data do we have and how was it collected? Okay, let's see. So now let's go to the data tab.
463:50 - And in the data tab, it says that there are, there's a historical sales data for 1,150
463:57 - Rossman stores. And then there are these files. So there is train.csv test.csv sample submissions
464:06 - store.csv. So apparently this is the historical data on which we need to train our model. And
464:12 - then we need to make some predictions on this test file. And the way it works on Kaggle is that the
464:19 - predictions or the target values for the test set are hidden from you. So you need to train your
464:24 - model on the training data, where you have both the inputs and the targets, and then you need to
464:30 - make predictions on the test data where you only have the inputs. Then you go here and you make a
464:36 - submission. When the competition is active, you can make a submission, but even if the competition
464:40 - has ended, you can just try it out. So you make a submission where you make a prediction for each
464:46 - row in the test set, and then Kaggle through an automated system is going to compare them with
464:50 - the real test targets, which are hidden from you and give you a score. And that's how they create
464:56 - a leaderboard. And that's how they create competition. And we'll see that process by the
465:00 - end of this tutorial. And this is what the submission file looks like. So there is a
465:05 - submission file format that you need to follow. And then finally, it seems like there is some
465:10 - supplemental information about the different stores that are present. And this, this is all
465:15 - the columns that you have. And if you go down here, maybe if you check train.csv, you can see
465:21 - a few rows of data. This is what it looks like. So it seems like we have nine columns day of week
465:26 - date sales. I think sales is what we want to predict. Yeah. Sales is what we want to predict.
465:32 - And there seems to be also a number of customers, not sure if we can use this or not, because we
465:38 - don't know how many customers are going to come to a store in the next month. So good way to check
465:44 - what the targets are is to compare the training data with the test data. If you check the test
465:50 - data here, you have store day of week date, whether the store is open, whether it was running

466:01 - like we have neither customers nor sales. So we can't really use customers, the customers data as

466:12 - to predict. Okay. So now we are getting a clearer understanding. How much data do we have? Well,
466:18 - I think somewhere here in the column section, we should be able to find,

466:58 - just working on the data, because now you know that, okay, now we have three years of data.
467:01 - And for, we have this data for thousand stores. I think that should be sufficient amount of
467:07 - information to build out a sales prediction model for the next two months. Okay. So yeah,

467:24 - should make your own notes about. If you think that there are certain issues, missing data, et cetera,
467:29 - we just saw some sample rows. And next, in this case, the data is stored on Kaggle,

467:39 - a SQL dataset. Maybe you have to get data from multiple sources, maybe trained or CSV, or the,
467:45 - this historical data is in some SQL database, but the store data is in a Jason format somewhere,
467:51 - and you have to read it and combine them. Okay. So those are some things that you will have to do.
467:56 - That is the preparation that goes in. And typically you can take a few days to maybe a week,
468:01 - couple of weeks, just to understand all of this, make sure that you're happy with the
468:07 - initial data that you're getting, make sure that it's clear to you what the objective is. And
468:14 - you feel at least somewhat confident about approaching the problem. Okay.
468:19 - All right. So that was step one. Okay. So step one was all of this preparation,
468:25 - understanding the problem, et cetera. The second step is now when things enter back into the
468:32 - data science domain. So now we are slowly translating the business requirements into
468:40 - a specification for a project for a data science and machine learning project. So we need to now
468:47 - start to classify the problem as an supervised learning problem or an unsupervised unsupervised
468:53 - learning problem. And if it is supervised as a regression problem or a classification problem,
468:58 - okay. And we'll talk about this. We've talked about these before, but here's roughly the landscape
469:03 - of machine learning and where machine learning lies in the entire computer science ecosystem.
469:08 - Now, of course, computer science is a vast field and one piece of computer science is artificial
469:13 - intelligence, which is systems that take seemingly intelligent decisions. Now, artificial intelligence
469:21 - is a very broad term. It includes machine learning, but it can also include hand coded
469:26 - systems. For example, if you look at, uh, I mean, if you look at Amazon Alexa, for example,
469:33 - Alexa answers a lot of questions. So in the background, actually a lot of questions have
469:40 - been hard coded. So what they look for is once they see certain keywords based on those keywords,
469:45 - they trigger specific activities. For example, if any sentence you say has the word alarm, then
469:51 - alarm, then the alarm is going to be set for you. Or if any sentence you say has the word play music,
469:58 - then it's going to play some music for you. So that's not too much machine learning. I mean,
470:02 - there is some machine learning in just converting your voice to text, but ultimately once your
470:07 - instruction is available as text, it's simply a rule based system where you check for a presence
470:13 - of a certain word and then you react in a certain way, right? So artificial intelligence systems
470:17 - can be rule-based where they are coded by somebody manually rule by rule, or they can be
470:23 - machine learning systems or machine learning models, which is what we are building here,
470:27 - where we simply give the data to a model and it learns the relationship between, uh, what we want
470:33 - to use and what we want to predict. Now in machine learning, you have unsupervised learning and
470:38 - supervised learning supervised learning is where you know, what you want to predict. For example,
470:44 - we want to predict the sales at Rossman, or we want to predict whether a tumor is cancerous or
470:49 - not. So that's supervised learning unsupervised learning is where we don't have any targets,
470:54 - where we are primarily just interested in learning the structure of the data.
470:58 - Let's say you have a lot of activity of customers on your website and you want to
471:04 - just figure out which customers are less frequent visitors and which customers are power users and
471:11 - which customers lie somewhere in between. So that becomes a clustering problem where you don't
471:17 - really know already beforehand for each customer, but you want to group customers into similar
471:22 - clusters and then study those clusters. So that's unsupervised learning that we will touch on briefly
471:26 - towards the end of the course and within supervised learning where we have categorized or numerical
471:36 - target data, we have two kinds of problems. We have classification and we have regression.
471:41 - Now classification is when we want to predict a category. For example, we want to take information
471:46 - about a breast tumor and predict whether it is cancerous or not. That is a classification
471:51 - problem. And then a regression problem is where we want to predict a number. So here
471:57 - for the Rossman store sales prediction, you want to predict a dollar value, a continuous value
472:02 - that is called a regression problem. And then within unsupervised learning, you have again,
472:07 - many different types of problems like clustering, where you just want to split up the data into a
472:12 - bunch of similar clusters and maybe then study those clusters. Then you have something called
472:16 - dimensionality reduction, where you want to take data that has a lot of columns, maybe hundreds of
472:22 - columns and reduce it down to five, 10, 15 columns without losing the essence of the data.
472:28 - And then you have another class of problems like association, which is more of like a similarity
472:35 - search or a recommendation. So for example, if you've watched, for example, recommending which
472:43 - movie you should watch next based on the movies you've watched and the movies washed by people
472:49 - who have also watched all of the movies that you have watched, right? So people like you or people
472:55 - who have a similar taste of taste as you, you can pick up a song or a movie that they have watched
473:00 - and you haven't watched and recommended to you, right? So that's association or recommendations or
473:06 - Yeah. Similarity search essentially. So those are the two areas. And today we are just looking at
473:13 - regression and classification. Now here's the question for you. What type of problem is store
473:19 - sales prediction, as we just discussed, because we're trying to predict a single number, it is a
473:23 - regression problem. And what type of problem is best breast cancer identification? Well, as we just
473:29 - discussed, that is a classification problem. Here's a third example. You have this data set for
473:37 - mall customer segmentation. So you have a bunch of information about customers who visited a certain
473:44 - shopping mall. So you have information like the customer ID, which I believe is unique. So not
473:50 - very useful for modeling, but then you have a gender, you have an age, you have an annual income,
473:55 - and you have some kind of a spending score. So there's nothing we want to predict here. All we
474:01 - want to do is we want to figure out what are the big clusters of customers we have. Maybe we have
474:07 - some low spenders. Maybe we have some high spenders, or maybe we have some millennials who spend a
474:12 - high amount. Maybe we have some older people who spend a lower amount. We don't know. And that's
474:19 - where we use a tool or a machine learning algorithm called clustering, which automatically splits
474:24 - our data into a bunch of different clusters. And we can decide how many clusters we want to create.
474:28 - And then we can study those clusters to figure out what makes them a cluster or what is the common
474:34 - property between them, right? All right. So once you've identified the type of problem you're
474:42 - solving, you next need to pick an appropriate evaluation metric. Also, depending on the kind of
474:51 - model that you will end up training, your model will also use a loss function or a cost function
474:56 - that it will optimize during the training process. For example, if you're trying to predict
475:02 - whether a tumor is cancerous or not, then the way you will evaluate the results of your model
475:10 - is probably by looking at the accuracy, which means if you give it a hundred inputs, you will
475:16 - want to maybe look at how many of them did it predict correctly based on the historical data,
475:22 - or maybe you might be interested in things like precision and recall. So you may, you may want
475:26 - that there shouldn't be too many false negatives where somebody who has cancer should not, we
475:32 - should not tell them that they do not have cancer, or maybe you want there not to be too many false
475:37 - positives where somebody who doesn't have cancer, you don't want to tell them that they have cancer.
475:42 - Right. So based on the exact scenario, you may have to use, you may have to figure out what
475:49 - evaluation metric you're going to use. So the evaluation metric, the important thing here is
475:54 - that they are used by humans to evaluate the model. And in fact, this is something that you will
475:58 - discuss with the other stakeholders, with the business team, and figure out and arrive on a
476:03 - valuation metric. You will promise them that I will, I will try to deliver a model that matches
476:09 - this evaluation metric. And they will agree that, okay, once you deliver a model that matches a
476:14 - certain evaluation metric, or meets a certain threshold for an evaluation metric that is
476:19 - pre-decided, then we will try out the model in our system. All right. So evaluation metrics are for
476:25 - humans, but evaluation metrics like accuracy, precision, recall are not understood by machine
476:31 - learning models. They typically need different kinds of evaluation metrics because they're
476:36 - requirements for machine learning models are around differentiability and continuous functions
476:41 - and things like that. So that's where loss functions come into picture. Machine learning
476:46 - models use loss functions, for example, for the breast cancer example, a machine learning model
476:51 - would use, would use a loss function called cross entropy. And that's a common loss function for
476:57 - classification problems. And it will try to optimize the cross entropy by changing its
477:02 - internal parameters. All right. So that's something to keep in mind. And here is a link that you can
477:10 - check out. This is a survey of the common loss functions and evaluation metrics. There are 11
477:15 - evaluation metrics and then some loss functions as well. So this talks about the difference between
477:22 - evaluation metrics and loss functions. And typically for regression tasks, for example,
477:27 - predicting sales, a continuous value, the most common evaluation metrics are root means squared
477:33 - error or root means squared logarithmic error, or mean absolute error, which is a variation of
477:38 - root means squared error, where you don't take squares or square roots. You just look at absolute
477:43 - values and the R squared score. And then you have evaluation metrics for classification tasks
477:50 - where you have accuracy, error rate, precision, recall, F one score,
477:55 - you have something called the MCC balanced accuracy, log loss, and then you have something
478:00 - called AUC, ROC. So you can check out all of these, what these mean. And the good thing is for all
478:06 - of these, you have functions in built into scikit-learn. So whenever you have some predictions
478:11 - and you have some targets, you simply put them both together into the function. And that is going
478:17 - to give you the value of the evaluation metric. Okay. So do check out this. Okay. So check out
478:24 - this tutorial on evaluation metrics and loss functions. Now, what is the appropriate loss
478:33 - function and evaluation metric for store sales prediction? This is a regression problem. And
478:39 - with regression problems, typically the loss function in most machine learning models is
478:46 - either root means squared error, RMSE or R squared. So one of these two, but it really
478:52 - depends on the kind of model that you're training. So we'll probably just say that we'll, we'll use
478:58 - root mean squared error as our evaluation metric as well, because it is something simple enough
479:02 - to understand. It simply says that on average, your model is off by a certain amount. And
479:10 - if you have too many outliers and you don't want to give too much weightage to outliers,
479:15 - then you can also consider mean absolute error. Okay. So that's another thing worth considering.
479:20 - Again, you will have to discuss the evaluation metric with the business, with the other
479:24 - stakeholders and figure out, do you care about outliers? Are outliers really something that
479:30 - we should try and solve for? Then yes. Then you use root mean squared error. Otherwise,
479:34 - maybe you can just use mean absolute error. If you don't worry too much about outliers,
479:38 - and that would be a good evaluation metric. Okay. Then what are the appropriate loss function
479:45 - and evaluation metric for breast cancer identification? So for breast cancer identification,
479:50 - the loss function typically in most classification models is cross entropy, or in tree based models,
479:57 - it is typically the Gini, the Gini score at every stage. And the evaluation metric is generally
480:06 - either accuracy or precision or recall, or it is going to be the F1 score against something that
480:11 - you would have to discuss with the other stakeholders. Okay. Now, if we actually check the
480:16 - Rossman store sales here, you will see here that there is this evaluation mentioned here. And it
480:24 - turns out that the submissions that you make to this competition are evaluated using the root
480:30 - mean square percentage error. So that's very interesting. Now it's no longer root mean
480:35 - squared error. It's R M S P E. And this is how it's calculated. So in root mean square error,
480:41 - we take the prediction and we take the target. So we take the target and the prediction. We take
480:48 - the difference between them. We take the square, and then we take the average of that and take a
480:53 - root. But in this case, we are interested in the percentage error. And we are not interested in
480:58 - the actual error, right? So this is something that we will have to maybe try and figure out.
481:03 - Maybe while we're evaluating our models, we will also define a root mean square percentage
481:08 - error function. Okay. So just keep an eye out for this because it seems like they're interested
481:14 - not in the absolute absolute value that you're off by. They're more interested in what is the
481:18 - percentage that you're off by. And are you off by 5% or 10% or 20% and that's what they really
481:25 - care about. Okay. On average. So yeah, so that was step two, identifying what kind of problem
481:36 - you're solving supervised, unsupervised regression classification, and then identifying the
481:40 - evaluation metric that the business cares about and agreeing on that evaluation metric with the
481:46 - business. One thing that you should also then try and find out is what is a good value of the
481:50 - evaluation metric that the other stakeholders would be happy with. For example, for Rossman,
481:56 - if you are getting a root mean square percentage error of 10% or lower, is that good enough? Or
482:04 - do they want something that is 5% or lower, or do they want something that is 1% or lower? What is
482:09 - the exact amount that they need? And this is something that the business will then calculate.
482:14 - Maybe they'll go back historically and see how, how much the estimates were off by maybe the
482:19 - estimates by store managers were off by 30% on average. So if you can build a system that gets
482:24 - that is off by 20%, then it's better than all the store managers and it does not require them to
482:30 - spend that time. So maybe 20% is good enough, right? So it depends case to case. Now, obviously for
482:35 - breast cancer prediction, we wouldn't want maybe a 60 or 70% accuracy. We want, we maybe would want
482:42 - closer to 98, 99% accuracy to avoid misclassification because it's a question of life and death there.
482:48 - So that's the kind of decision. So that's the kind of trade offs that you have to discuss and
482:54 - encounter in real machine learning projects. Okay. So now we are getting into the territory that
483:02 - we're familiar with, which is about downloading, cleaning, exploring data, and creating new features.

487:54 - do is just put in the data for store one. And then there are a bunch of rows for store one. This is
488:01 - not the only row because here you see you have 100 or you have over 1 million rows of data. So
488:07 - store one shows up multiple times. In fact, about a thousand times over three years, but here you
488:12 - have just one row for store one. So we want to take all of these and then replicate it for each of
488:17 - those rows, each of the thousand rows. And to do this, we can use the merge.
488:22 - Method of the data frame. So we say Ross DF, which contains the training data. So which contains
488:28 - all this information about a single store sales on a single day. And we merge into Ross DF store
488:36 - DF and how do we do it? We want to do a left outer joint. So which means that we want to make sure
488:44 - that we retain all the data from Ross DF. And maybe some stores don't show up in the Rossman data set
488:52 - in the training data set. Then we ignore those stores. So that's why we have left and we want to
488:57 - merge on the store column. So once we run that, you can see that we now have store day of week
489:04 - date, sales, customers, open promos, state holiday, school holiday, et cetera. And then we have the
489:10 - store type, assortment, competition distance. So this data got replicated for each row where the
489:17 - store number was one. Okay. So that's pandas data frame merge. If you are not familiar with this or
489:22 - not comfortable with it, just look up merging data frames on pandas. It is also part of the zero to
489:28 - pandas course that we have, but now we have a much better data set, right? And this is something that
489:34 - you will have to do. You will have, you will get maybe a three or four rows of data. So if you

491:32 - So we check some data types, and then we check if there are any null values. In this case,

491:42 - how to deal with these null values. If they are, one thing we could do is we could simply not use
491:48 - those columns. Or if we think they're important, maybe we may want to miss fill those null values
491:53 - because machine learning models cannot be trained with null values, or we can maybe do some kind of
491:59 - one heart encoding for categorical features and the null values will just become all zeros. So
492:06 - that's the kind of thing that you have to then look at each column carefully. And typically
492:10 - just this step may require some back and forth communication where you talk to the business and
492:17 - figure out if it is how important they think it is to track the certain input and what they can
492:25 - give you. Maybe they can give you the data. Maybe they have that data sitting elsewhere,
492:29 - or if you have to then guess what should you be putting in there? Should you be putting in the
492:33 - average or should you be putting in the median? And you can guess that by studying the distribution
492:39 - as well. If it's a normal distribution, the average should be fine. If it is an exponential
492:43 - distribution, the median should be good, or should you be putting in some kind of an unknown value
492:50 - for a category? So on a case by case basis, you need to argue and figure out what you need to do
492:56 - here. This is wrong. There are no values think. Yeah. And then you should also look at the ranges
493:06 - of data, especially the minimum and maximum ranges just to get a sense of whether the data is valid
493:11 - or not. For example, in this case, it seems like the data, all the ranges seem pretty reasonable
493:17 - in the sense that nothing seems off. There are no negative values here. So no negative sales.
493:22 - If you did have negative sales, then you would have to go back and figure out why there are
493:26 - negative sales reported. Maybe on that day, the returns for certain products were higher
493:34 - than the actual sales. So maybe there was a huge recall of a particular kind of product that you
493:42 - were selling because there was some issue or some side effect. It was happening. So everybody came
493:47 - to the store on that day and just returned a certain product and no other sales could be made.
493:53 - So maybe then you might want to exclude that because that is not representative of what happens
493:58 - on a, on the general day to day. So again, you, you need to use your insight as a data science
494:05 - practitioner, your, your skills are as a data science practitioner, but have to combine that
494:10 - with the actual knowledge of the business to get the right insight about how to deal with these
494:17 - situations. Then here we have a maximum value. So it seems like the maximum sales were about
494:22 - $40,000. So that already gives you that, okay, you're trying to make predictions in the range
494:26 - of zero to 40,000. Now zero is an interesting value. Why were there zero sales on a certain
494:32 - days? It could be because the store was not open on those days. So that's something we will have
494:37 - to try and deal with when the store is not open. You're the, the sales are zero. Do we want to
494:44 - handle that in our machine learning model or do we want to handle that as a special case?
494:49 - Because it seems like a waste of all that modeling power and time. When we know really
494:56 - that if open is set to zero, then sales should be zero. So that's the kind of thing that you
495:02 - have to think about as you go through these ranges, look for invalid values, look for
495:06 - anything that stands out and then go back and have a discussion about it.
495:13 - And also check for duplicate rows. Again, depending on how the data was collected,

495:22 - rows, you need to go back and discuss and figure out whether these duplicate rows are
495:27 - actually duplicates that should be removed, or they are valid data that we should keep around.

498:00 - the right split because if the model has to be used year round, it's ideal to have test data

498:36 - years of data to make predictions, right? So you have to figure out exactly how you will do this.
498:41 - A project isn't just done and finished at once. So you will keep improving your model over time.
498:46 - And if it's possible to train your model every two months, then maybe it's fine to make a user test
498:51 - set, which is just looking back by two months or something. Okay.
498:59 - All right. So now we have the dataset ready to go. And the next step is to do some exploratory data
499:07 - analysis and visualization. And by this time, you should know the objectives of the exploratory
499:12 - analysis. First, you want to study the distributions of the individual columns, uniform, whether they
499:17 - uniform, whether they're normal, whether they're exponential. Based on this, you may decide how
499:24 - to fill missing values. Based on this, you may decide if you want to apply some transformations.
499:29 - For example, if you see one column, which is exponential and it's correlation with the target
499:35 - column seems like an exponential curve. Maybe you can take the logarithm of that column and that
499:39 - will give you a better result. Then you want to detect some analysis anomalies or errors in the
499:46 - data. If you see any missing values, any incorrect values, any values that don't make sense by drawing
499:52 - the charts, you can fix those. Then you want to study the relationship of the target column with
499:57 - other columns. You want to see if there is a linear relationship, a nonlinear relationship, etc.
500:03 - And then you need to gather insights about the problem and about the dataset. And you need to
500:09 - then come up with ideas for pre-processing and feature engineering. So in a lot of cases,
500:13 - you will see that maybe if you combine two columns, you may get a good result or you may
500:20 - get a better result with the same kind of model. For example, if you have, if you're trying to
500:24 - predict the price of a house and you have the overall width and length of the house and let's
500:31 - say it's rectangular, the entire plot, then maybe using area as a column might be a better idea
500:40 - than using width, just width and height as separate columns, because area has a direct
500:46 - linear relationship with cost of the house, but weight and height may have a different
500:52 - kind of relationship. So these are the kinds of things that you have to think about. And this is
500:56 - called feature engineering, combining features or transforming features to create new features
501:02 - that make more sense. Right. Remember that your models are limited by how they are defined or
501:08 - how they, how the training happens. So if you're training a linear model, a linear model can never
501:13 - learn a quadratic relationship that a width multiplied by length has some linear relationship
501:21 - with cost. On the other hand, if you introduce a third column, which is area, then your linear
501:27 - model can suddenly start learning much richer relationships because now there's a linear
501:31 - relationship between area and the cost. Okay. So most of the time is actually split
501:38 - actually spent in feature engineering. And then once you have good set of features figured out,
501:42 - then model training becomes quite easy. So let's study the distribution on the sales column.
501:52 - Here's what the distribution of the sales column looks like. And this is the target. And already
501:57 - you can see that there is this huge chunk of zeros here, about 175,000 of these. So about,
502:04 - I would say one in seven, and that should give you a hint. It's probably that these are Sundays.
502:10 - Maybe the store is closed on Sundays. And that's why the stores sales on those days are zero.

502:27 - that. Okay. When the store is not open, then you simply return a zero. Otherwise you do
