517:55 - rows and a validation data frame, which contains 200,000 rows. Okay. Now I let you figure out how
518:02 - we achieve this in this line of code. You can probably create a new cell and try to sort out,
518:08 - try to work out each piece here. But what we're doing is we're sorting by date, selecting the
518:13 - first 75% of data for training and rest for validation. And here's what the data frame looks
518:19 - like now. So this is our training data frame. It contains store day of week, date, et cetera,
518:25 - et cetera, all of that. And validation data set will look exactly the same. What will be different
518:31 - is the date range that you have for the training and validation set. So the training set, it starts
518:37 - from 2013, January to 2014, December, it looks like, and the validation set starts from 2014,
518:45 - December, and goes on till 2015, July. And the test set starts right after that. Okay. Why are
518:53 - we doing this time-based split? Because we now understand that our model is going to be used in
519:00 - the future. So we want to show our model data that it hasn't seen in the past or data that, that
519:08 - comes into the future of the data that it has been trained on, right? So that's why you have the
519:13 - train. That's why you have the test set, which comes after the training period. Then you have
519:18 - the validation set, which also comes after the training period. So it is a better reflection of
519:22 - the test set. If you pick the validation set randomly, that might still work. That might still
519:27 - give you a good result, but the results or the metrics that you get on the validation set may
519:34 - not be a good reflection of the metrics that you get on the test set or the metrics that you get
519:38 - in the real world. So you want to make your validation set as close to the real world data
519:45 - that your model will face as possible. Okay. Now, of course, if it did not have dates, you could
519:50 - just pick a random segment of the data for validation. So these are the date ranges. You
519:58 - can see that the test set comes after the validation set. And remember, we already have a
520:03 - test set given to us separately. All right. So now we have our training test and validation data
520:12 - frames, and all of them have all these columns. Now we know the drill here. We need to get, we
520:18 - need to identify the input and target columns. So I'm just going to create a list of input
520:24 - columns, and I'm not going to use all the columns for your initial model. For your initial model,
520:31 - when you're just figuring out what kind of modeling approach you should use, or what would
520:36 - the rough accuracy or the rough baseline performance of your model look like, it's not worth spending
520:43 - too much time on just engineering and understanding every single column for your initial model. You
520:49 - can just pick a few columns and then just try things out. So I'm just going to pick about four
520:55 - plus five, nine columns here for my initial model. And I am going to put them into a list called
521:02 - input columns and the target column is sales. One thing I should be very careful of is to make sure
521:08 - that sales or the customer's column does not come up in input columns, because that would be an
521:14 - error. There's not something we have in the test set. Let's also separate out numeric and
521:20 - categorical columns. Now this is where it gets a little tricky here because stores ideally should
521:27 - be treated as categorical columns, one, one, one, five stores, all of them have a different property.
521:33 - So there's no natural order to stores. It's not that a store with a higher ID is going to have
521:38 - higher sales or a store with a lower ID is going to have higher sales. It's completely random,
521:43 - the numbering and the sales. So technically it is a categorical column, but the difficulty is
521:50 - creating one, one, five, treating it as a categorical column and then creating 1,115 columns of data
521:58 - is going to severely increase the size of the dataset. And also it's going to make the models
522:06 - a bit harder to train because of something called the curse of dimensionality, which means that if
522:12 - you have a lot of different features, which all are very closely correlated, then that makes it
522:21 - a lot easier for your models to overfit essentially, right? Because now, because now it has a lot more
522:31 - parameters to play with. So it can very easily overfit to the training data. And those models
522:37 - generally do not generalize very well. So that's not the exact definition of the curse of dimensionality,
522:43 - but that's the idea, the more features or the, especially when you get into thousands of columns
522:47 - or thousands of features, you are going to start facing issues. So we are going to treat store as
522:53 - a numerical column. And that is probably a problem. Probably there's an issue there, but we'll just
523:01 - see what happens, right? And that's why you can do some kind of feature engineering where maybe
523:05 - you can reorder the stores. Maybe you can compute the average sale per store, the average sale value.
523:12 - And based on that, give a new numbering to the stores and that numbering could be reflective of
523:20 - the average sales so that a higher number or a higher store number would mean a higher average
523:26 - sale, a lower store number would mean lower average sale, right? So that's something worth trying out,
523:30 - but we are just going to use it as a numerical column, linear models will struggle decision
523:35 - tree based models might be able to figure this out. Then we have day of the week. This is also,
523:43 - this is categorical. I think we can keep it categorical. We have day, month. So these are

533:48 - compare the mean squared error of train predictions with train targets, it and we said squared equals
533:54 - false. So that will give us the root mean squared error. So it turns out that the mean squared
534:00 - error is 3082. Okay. Now why is this important? Well, first thing you should try and see is how
534:08 - does this compare to the actual values? So it seems like the actual values can be in the range
534:13 - 2000 to 15,000, roughly 15 or 17,000, 3000 to 17,000. And this means squared error of about 3082
534:24 - is off by how much? So 2002 or 3000 to 15, 17,000, how much is that? 17 minus three is 14. So if
534:33 - you're off by 3000 out of a range of 14,000, then roughly, if you just predict the average all the
534:42 - time, you're only off by about 20% very roughly speaking. And you can do the route mean percentage
534:49 - square error and figure out some, if your sales predictions from all these stores, from all these
534:57 - sales managers is off by more than 20%, then that means the work that they're doing is actually
535:04 - counterproductive. The predictions that they're making are actually causing actively causing a
535:09 - loss. If you simply just use the average value as a prediction, you will probably have a better
535:15 - forecast, right? So that's one thing that you understand. The second thing you understand is
535:19 - that now any model we train, any fancy machine learning model we train should ideally have a
535:25 - lower loss than just predicting the average, right? Because here we're simply just predicting the
535:31 - average. There's no intelligence here. So this gives us, that's why you call this a baseline.
535:37 - This tells us that our model, any model that we train should be at least this good. It should be
535:42 - at least the RMSE should at least be less than 3000. If the RMSE is greater than 3000, then our
535:49 - model is completely useless. And maybe there is something we need to fix about it fundamentally.
535:56 - Okay. All right. So that out of the way, we can also check this for the validation set. So we

540:03 - coded strategy. It is very clearly explainable because you have coded it. Okay. Then after trying
540:10 - all of these things, that is when you should maybe try a baseline machine learning model. So maybe
540:16 - just pick the simplest possible model for regression problems. Linear regression is the
540:22 - simplest model for classification problems. Logistic regression is the simplest model. And
540:27 - often these models themselves will be good enough. And you can just end the project there. You don't
540:32 - have to even do any hyper parameter tuning, et cetera, maybe just a little bit of feature engineering.
540:38 - So let's see here. We're importing the linear regression model. And we just create a model
540:45 - here, instantiating it. Then we are calling fit. So when we call fit, what happens is the linear
540:50 - regression model assumes a linear relationship between the inputs and the targets. So the target
540:55 - which is sale is assumed to be some weight multiplied by the store number plus some weight
541:00 - multiplied by day of week, plus some weight multiplied by there was a promotion or not plus
541:04 - some weight multiplied by whether it was a public holiday or not, et cetera, et cetera. So there are
541:11 - about eight features. It will apply a weight to each of those eight features. I think there are
541:15 - 18 after one hot encoding. So it'll apply a weight to each of the 18 features and it will start out
541:21 - with random weights, but it will slowly improve the weights by this kind of a workflow where it will
541:27 - put some inputs through the model, get some predictions, compare the predictions with the
541:31 - targets using a loss function. So linear regression in scikit-learn actually uses the R squared loss
541:37 - function, which is a variation of the RMSE loss function. And it then applies an optimization
541:42 - method. In this case, it's called ordinary least squares to improve the weights of the model. So
541:48 - the, so the random guesses are slowly improved step by step iteratively till the model gets good
541:55 - enough. Okay. So that's what happens when we run lin reg dot fit. Now, once the model has been
542:01 - fitted, which means once good weights have been identified for each feature in the input, we can
542:07 - then use the model to make predictions. Now, keep in mind that the parameters of the weights inside
542:12 - the model will not be updated during prediction. So if you see the model now, lin reg, this is a
542:21 - linear regression model inside it. You will find a bunch of coefficients that have been, that will
542:27 - be applied to each feature. Yeah. And these coefficients correspond directly to the columns
542:36 - in X train. So remember X train. So 1.04 will be applied to store number minus one will be applied
542:45 - to day 6.49 will be multiplied with month 1.0 4, 7 will be multiplied by year. And all of these
542:51 - multiple, all of these weights will be applied and then that will be added together. And that will
542:57 - give you the predicted sale. Okay. So it's a very simple linear assumption. We know that it is
543:01 - already very weak because store number has no direct correlation with sale, at least not a linear
543:07 - relationship. So here are some predictions. So now we put in into linear regression, we put in X
543:15 - train. So now we just predicting now we're no longer fitting the weight supply. So we're not
543:20 - fitting the weights of the model are fixed. So we are just taking the inputs, applying the weights

544:51 - Now we get to the interesting part, which is where we now train interesting models
544:56 - and we tune hyper parameters. Okay. And this is where we have to then systematically explore a
545:05 - bunch of different modeling strategies. Now scikit-learn on its website offers this cheat sheet
545:11 - that you should check out to help you figure out which kind of models to use. And this doesn't
545:17 - include all the different models, but it roughly gives you an idea that scikit-learn is split into
545:22 - a bunch of classification models, a bunch of regression models, a bunch of clustering models,
545:27 - and a bunch of like dimensionality reduction models. So that's all scikit-learn contains.
545:32 - And then there are some other non-modeling related models as well. And here is where they say that
545:39 - you start and you check if you have more than 50 samples. And if you have less than 50 samples,
545:43 - then just get more data. No amount of modeling is going to help you. In this case, fortunately,
545:48 - we have over half a million. So next we ask the question, are we trying to predict a category or
545:55 - are we trying to predict the quantity? So if you are predicting a category, then we check if we
546:02 - have labeled data. So for the breast cancer example, this is the direction that we would head into.
546:07 - So we have, we do have labeled data. So that means this is a classification problem. We already know
546:12 - whether tumors are malignant or benign cancerous or non-cancerous. So we can now use a classification
546:20 - algorithm. And these are some of the classification algorithms. You have this SGD classifier. You have
546:25 - this K neighbors classifier. Then you have this ensemble. You obviously have random forest
546:31 - classifiers. You have a decision tree classifiers. Those are not listed here, but they're part of this.
546:36 - So these are some of them. These are all the models that are applicable to that particular problem,
546:42 - right? Almost all classification models will be applicable to that problem. Not all of them may
546:48 - perform well, but all of them will work. On the other hand, if you're predicting a quantity,
546:54 - like in this case, then we just check here. If we have less than a hundred thousand samples,
546:59 - then we should probably just use SGD regressor or one of those other regress regressions.
547:05 - Otherwise, if we know that some features should be important. So here they have this check. If
547:12 - you think that some features are going to be more important than other features, use lasso and
547:17 - elastic net. So the difference between SGD regressor, which is basically just linear with
547:22 - the gradient descent optimization technique. So it's just a different optimization technique. It
547:27 - works well for large data sets. So the difference between SGD regressor and elastic net and lasso
547:35 - and all these is somewhere within the loss function somewhere to prevent overfitting some things like
547:43 - that. And then, yeah, there are a couple of other options. So the, here, what they're trying to tell
547:50 - you is try the simplest model possible. And if the simplest model possible, if the simplest model
547:57 - does not work, then you can try maybe these ensemble regressors, which is random forest. And
548:05 - then they should have put in decision trees here as well somewhere. So if linear models work out
548:10 - fine, that's great. If you're not satisfied with linear models, then maybe you try some of these
548:15 - ensemble regressors, right? So that's the rough idea there. You start out with simpler models and
548:20 - go with, go to increasingly more complex models. So here's a general strategy. Find out which models
548:28 - are applicable to the problem you're solving. Now, obviously as a gay nearest neighbor's classifier
548:35 - is not going to be applicable to sales prediction because it's a classification model, but all of
548:40 - these would be applicable, train a basic version for each type of model that's applicable. Even if
548:46 - you know that the linear relationships are weak still make sense to just train a linear model just
548:52 - to see what result it gives you. You may be surprised. Don't assume anything. So you train a
548:58 - basic version for each type of model, then identify the modeling approaches that work well and tune
549:05 - their hyper parameters. So once you try a basic version of all of these models, then you will get
549:10 - a sense of which one is working well, and then you can start tuning some of the hyper parameters.
549:17 - And as you do this, use a spreadsheet to keep track of your experiment results. So here is one
549:23 - spreadsheet that we've put together for you. It's a simple format that you can follow. And this
549:28 - spreadsheet contains the spreadsheet contains two sheets. If you see at the bottom here, you have
549:36 - an idea sheet and you have an experiment sheet. So what you should do is you should list out all the
549:43 - ideas you want to try. Maybe I want to try a linear regression and a potential impact or a potential
549:50 - outcome, whatever ideas you have about the potential outcome. I think this is going to be pretty bad.
549:59 - Something that we've already seen. Then maybe you want to try out a ridge regression and you can
550:06 - read about ridge regression and then lasso regression. And maybe you can try out polynomial
550:13 - regression. So Ridge and lasso regression simply makes some changes to the loss function of linear
550:20 - regression. Polynomial regression means you're taking some, you're taking squares and cubes of
550:25 - certain features, which you think might be useful. Then maybe you want to try out a decision tree
550:32 - and maybe you want to try out random forests and maybe you also want to try out a gradient boosting.
550:37 - Maybe you want to try out something called support vector machines. Yeah. So just list out all the
550:43 - ideas you have. And it's a good idea to just list out what you think the outcome might be. So this
550:50 - you think should be better than linear regression because it contains regularization internally
550:59 - decision tree. Well, okay. Should offer good interpretation and things like that. So whatever
551:09 - outcome you're going, you're looking for from each model, it's a good idea to just project, try and
551:16 - predict which model might work well. And then once you actually train that model, you can list out
551:22 - your learnings here, and you can see if your prediction about whether a model will work well
551:27 - matches your actual learnings after training that model. And that is how you train your mind to
551:34 - think about picking the right machine learning model. There is no good answer. There is no
551:39 - series of rules that you can follow. It's just that you have to work through a bunch of different
551:44 - datasets and try different kinds of models. And for each kind of model, if you can just take a
551:50 - second to predict what outcome you want to see from that model and learn from the actual outcome
551:57 - that you see, you will start course correcting. So in some sense, you are doing, you're running a
552:01 - machine learning algorithm on your brain and you will get better at picking machine learning
552:05 - algorithms. All right. So this is one thing that you should have. This is the idea sheet. Then you
552:11 - have this experiment sheet. So in this experiment sheet, you should put all the experiments that

565:22 - between the data, between the inputs and the targets. It's going to help you regularize and
565:27 - generalize the motor better as well. Try and include more features, the more relevant features
565:32 - for predicting the target you can get the better the model gets. So this could be by getting
565:37 - additional data. This could be by feature engineering, by carefully thinking about which form
565:42 - of a certain feature is very useful. For example, going from date to day, month, and year is a huge
565:49 - leap. That is not something that a model can figure out on its own. Our models are actually pretty
565:54 - limited by the, by the way in which they are constructed. So we need to give them the right
565:59 - features. Then tuning the hyper parameters of the model can help. So remember hyper parameter
566:06 - tuning. This is how it works. As you change the certain hyper parameter, the models complexity
566:12 - in a particular dimension goes from low to high. As you increase the complexity of the model,
566:18 - initially the model gets more powerful. So it starts to learn more about the data and still
566:23 - keeps generalizing well, but after a certain time, it starts to memorize specific training examples.
566:29 - And that's the thing that you want to avoid, right? So you need to find that best fit. So
566:33 - that's where you need to tune hyper parameters so that they're not underfitted, but at the same
566:38 - time, they're also not overfitted because that increases your test error. And for more information
566:43 - about this, just go back and review the decision trees and random forest lecture, where we saw an
566:48 - example of how wearing the max depth leads to this kind of a curve between the training loss
566:54 - and the validation loss. Okay. All right. So this model has run now. So with 20 decision trees,
567:03 - you can see that we got it down to about 1, 3, 9, 6. So definitely a random forest regressor seems
567:08 - to be working quite well for this particular problem. And this is a number that we can share
567:14 - with business and then try to figure out if this is a reasonable value for prediction or not.
567:20 - Okay. So tuning hyper parameters is another thing you can try. One other thing you should try is
567:35 - if you've tried everything else, you've been tuning hyper parameters for a long time
567:39 - and you have no, and you've tried whatever feature engineering you could come up with.
567:43 - The next thing is to just look at specific examples of where the model is making incorrect
567:48 - or bad predictions. So you can make all the predictions from the model, and then you can
567:52 - look at individual predictions side by side with the targets and maybe just compute what the
567:57 - difference is or whether the prediction matched or did not match and find the ones where the
568:04 - predictions were bad and use that to get some insight, look at those training data points.
568:09 - And maybe you'll figure out that the model is missing a certain thing, or maybe you should
568:13 - give a certain weight to a certain class or things like that. So looking at specific examples one by
568:18 - one is always is a exceptionally good strategy because it's okay to look at numbers and numbers
568:26 - can just, the metric just goes up and down. You can't really get a learn a lot from it,
568:31 - but when you look at specific examples, you can apply your insight into the domain, into the
568:35 - problem and figure out how to improve the model. Then you can also do things like grid search for
568:42 - hyper parameter optimization. If you're tired of tuning parameters on your own, you can set up a
568:47 - mechanism to, for this to happen automatically. And there's also another technique called key
568:51 - fold cross validation, which we will cover in more detail the next time. And finally,
568:56 - one other thing you can do is you can combine the results from different types of models or train
569:02 - another model using the results of a bunch of different models. So this technique is called
569:06 - ensembling and the specific version of it is called stacking. So these are all more advanced
569:13 - areas of machine learning. Now with hyper parameter optimization, when you want to do it in an
569:19 - automated fashion, typically what you do is you identify that these three or four hyper parameters
569:24 - are the ones that you want to tune and you identify the ranges for those hyper parameters
569:29 - that you want to test out. And you can then put this into a grid search algorithm, which is then
569:35 - going to create models for each given set of hyper parameters. And then it's going to return
569:41 - the result to you and you can pick the best model out of them. So I've pointed to a tutorial here
569:45 - that you can try and follow, and we will apply hyper parameter tuning to one of the models we
569:52 - train in the future. Next, we have this technique called key fold cross validation. And this is what
570:00 - K fold cross validation looks like visually. So we have some training data and we have some test
570:06 - data. Now, instead of just picking one portion of the training data as the validation data,
570:12 - what we can do is we can split the training data into five folds or five. I mean, you think of it
570:17 - like a piece of paper and you fold it five times. So five equal portions. And then you train five
570:24 - different models for the first model. You use fold one as a validation set and fold two, three,
570:30 - four, five, as the training set for the second model, you use for two as the validation set and
570:36 - fold one, three, four, five as the training set for the third model, you use four three as a
570:40 - validation set and you get the idea. So you're training five different models on 80% of the data,
570:46 - but each time it's a different 80%. And then what you can do is you can make predictions using all
570:52 - five of those models and simply average those predictions out. Now the benefit of this is
570:57 - instead of setting aside a single validation set, you have used all of the training data while still
571:05 - doing validation, right? So you still have a validation score that you can look at that you
571:10 - can use for tuning hyper parameters, but you are training on the entire data that you have available.
571:16 - Okay. Now this is going to be, this is going to perform a little poorly for time series data or
571:23 - data ordered by time, because ideally we want to keep the validation data at the very end of the
571:29 - time period, but you could still try it. It doesn't hurt. It's just, it's giving the model more data
571:35 - to train with. So it's not bad. All right. So try cross validation against something that you can
571:40 - do using scikit-learn, and I have pointed to a tutorial here as well, and something that we will
571:45 - apply the next time. Next, you have this technique called ensembling and stacking. And by the way,
571:53 - for both of these for grid search, it may seem like a difficult thing to do, but it's because of the
571:58 - utilities that you have in scikit-learn. It's actually quite simple. It's just like three
572:02 - or four lines of code, and you can always look it up to similarly with K fold cross validation.
572:07 - It may seem difficult. Okay. How am I going to split the dataset into five different pieces?
572:11 - And then will I need some for loops and we'll have to write some functions, et cetera, et cetera.
572:16 - Well, all of that is generally taken care for you. You have this K fold class that you can include
572:22 - from scikit-learn, and it is just going to be three, four lines of code to perform all of this.
572:29 - It's actually easier to implement than to explain. Next, you have ensembling and stacking. So
572:39 - on something simply refers to combining the results of multiple models. And here is what
572:43 - ensembling looks like. Visually speaking, you have the data, you train five different models,
572:50 - and these could be different kinds of models. One could be a linear regression model. One could be
572:54 - SVM. One could be a random forest and one could be a gradient boosting machine. And then you take
573:01 - predictions from all of these models. Now, depending on classification or regression,
573:07 - you could do two different things. So with classification, then you just pick the majority
573:11 - and with regression, you would just take the average. So in a way, ensembling,
573:16 - and this is something that we've already covered is an extension of random forests. In random forest,
573:22 - we look at a 10 hundred or 500 different decision trees and then average their results.
573:29 - But in ensembling, when you're doing a manual ensembling, we take five or six different models
573:35 - and then we average their results. And all of these models are diverse. So some are linear
573:39 - models. Some are, some are tree based models. Some can be like SVM kernel based models.
573:46 - And the idea is each model can pick up some sort of a diverse or some sort of a unique way of
573:53 - relating the inputs to the targets. So when we average out their predictions,
573:58 - the results that we get may be better than what we may get from any individual model.
574:04 - That's not always the case, but that is the objective. And if you do it well,
574:09 - if you do it, right, this works quite well. One other thing you can do is you can also
574:13 - give weightages to each model. Maybe you know that this model works is, works well most of the time.
574:19 - So give it like an 80% weightage and give these five, 10 and five, 10 and 10% or five, 10 and five
574:26 - percent. So then you would, the actual result for regression would be 0.8 times the result of this
574:32 - plus 0.1 times the result of this plus 0.05 times the result of this plus 0.05 times the result of
574:38 - this site. So you can give weights to the different predictions and to the different models.
574:43 - So as an exercise, just try and ensemble the result of a random forest with a rich regressor.
574:49 - There's nothing you have to do. You train a random forest, get the predictions from the
574:52 - random forest train a rich regressor, get the predictions from the rich regressor,
574:56 - then just average the two predictions, which means that add them together and divide by two.
575:00 - Or if you want to apply weights, then maybe apply a weight of 0.8 to the random forest and 0.2 to
575:07 - the regression, add the predictions together and see if you can get a better score than either of
575:12 - the two models individually. Okay. And if you can do that, then you have, then think about why that
575:17 - is, how is it possible that two models when combined give a better score than a single model
575:25 - and how the errors average out and things like that. Then there's something called stacking,
575:31 - which is a more advanced version of ensembling where we train another model using the results
575:37 - from multiple models. Now, if you remember, I mentioned here, we need, we can give weights
575:41 - to the different models here. Model one can get a weight of 0.8 0.1 0.05 0.05. Well, how do you
575:47 - decide the weights? You want to pick the weights in such a way that the validation loss is minimized
575:55 - or the validation accuracy is maximized. So how about we just train a linear regression model on
576:03 - top of these. Ensembled results and figure out the optimal weights. So we can train a linear
576:11 - regression model, which takes the outputs of each of these models and figures out the best
576:19 - weights to apply to them to minimize the validation loss. And this is called stacking. It's a natural
576:25 - extension of ensembling again, not very difficult to implement. It's just when you think about it
576:31 - and think about how you might implement it, it might seem like a lot of code, but there are
576:35 - utilities to help you do this. And we will see a stacking in one of the models we train to. Okay.
576:43 - And this is now getting into really advanced territory, but you will see this done a lot in
576:48 - Kaggle competitions because if you see Kaggle competitions, if you see the leaderboard here,
576:53 - this is the score that we different people have. You can see that the differences in score are
576:58 - very small. You can see 0.10999 and 0.1098. So people are fighting for that third, fourth,
577:06 - or fifth decimal place. And that's where all of these advanced techniques help in production.
577:12 - Typically you don't want to run all of these models at once because it can get pretty slow.
577:16 - It can also get pretty resources intensive. So typically only ensemble, maybe two or three
577:22 - methods or two or three models, not more than that. And stacking also can go to multiple layers. You
577:27 - can have layers upon layers of stacking, but typically just one layer of stacking is what
577:32 - you see in the industry. Okay. So yeah, this is more of a survey of some of these advanced
577:38 - techniques, but I encourage you to try it out. And once you've done all this hyper parameter
577:45 - optimization, ensembling, stacking, et cetera. So now you will sort of realize what is the best
577:52 - you can do with the data that you have and the kind of models that you have, like you will hit
577:57 - a wall at some point. You will not get to a hundred percent validation accuracy, unfortunately,
578:02 - because that signal may simply not be there in the input to give you the target, right?
578:08 - But that's where you stop. And you can almost clearly see that point. Like we saw here that
578:15 - we got to 1300 with random forest. Maybe we try gradient boosting. Maybe you get to
578:19 - 1250 or something, but I think it's going to be very difficult to go beyond 1200, let's say,
578:25 - or 1150. Maybe we do a lot of feature engineering and maybe we may push it down to a thousand,
578:31 - but somewhere there, we are going to hit the limit. Now at this point is where we start
578:35 - interpreting the model and we prepare to present our findings. So what are we going to do then?
578:42 - Well, we have to first explain why our model returns a certain value.
578:45 - So we have to explain why the model returns a particular result. And most scikit-learn
578:53 - models offer some kind of a feature importance score for linear models. It is a coefficient
578:59 - for decision trees. It is this feature importance. Score. So if you check the columns of the training
579:09 - data frame, you have these columns. And if you check inside a random data frame, you
579:13 - will see an importance of each property. Like you have store day, month, and you have the
579:19 - importance of each of those features here. And then you can put that into a data frame here. So
579:23 - now we're just putting that into a data frame and you can now see these are the different features
579:27 - and these, this is their importance. And then you can plot it. So this is the kind of thing that you
579:33 - want to ultimately show in your presentation. In the presentation, you want to say that, hey,
579:38 - the store is the biggest factor in determining what the sales are going to be like. And then
579:44 - it seems like the promotion is the next most important factor. And then it seems like the day,
579:49 - the month, and the day of the week are important factors too. And then the store type, et cetera,
579:54 - have some bearing on that too. Okay. So maybe you may want to then get more features that describe a
580:01 - store. Maybe the area of the store is an important thing. Maybe you want to get more features that
580:07 - the area of the store is an important thing. Maybe the location of the store is an important thing.
580:11 - Maybe the number of people working at the store is an important thing because all of these could
580:17 - be indicators of how much business the store does. And all of this information is available today.
580:23 - So if you can grab that information, add those new features, then you will start making a better
580:29 - prediction. And that is how machine learning projects work. You don't just train a model and
580:35 - report a number and a metric or a loss and be done with it. You have to interpret and figure out
580:41 - what more information we need. How can we make it better? And it's an iterative process that you
580:46 - have to keep improving over and over. Okay. And this is the kind of chart that you will present
580:51 - to non-technical stakeholders to explain how the model arrives at its result. And if you wanted
580:58 - even greater explainability, then you can just use a single decision tree. Maybe the decision trees
581:03 - prediction is a little worse. It's off. It's maybe instead of 1300, it's at 1400, but the
581:09 - interpretability that you get out of it, maybe that might be more useful to one, convince people
581:15 - that your model is working. And second, make a case that they should gather some other information.
581:20 - Like let's say if they want to get the information about how many people work at every store or what
581:26 - is the footfall at every store that's there. Well, but like the area of every store, et cetera,
581:30 - they would have to put some resources into it. And that's where you have to make a case as a data
581:36 - scientist because everything costs something, right? So everything has a cost. And now one other
581:44 - thing you should do is you should start showing some individual predictions. So you should do it
581:49 - yourself and you should also show it in your presentation, in your presentation, the number,
581:53 - the training curve is not going to be impactful. What is going to be impactful is some specific
581:59 - examples. So here I've defined this predict input function, and inside this predicting function,
582:05 - you can see that I've encoded some logic that if I get a single input and that input is going to
582:10 - be a dictionary. Now, if the store is not open, I simply return zero. If it is on, if it is open,
582:18 - then we create a data frame, just like the training data frame or the test data frame. We
582:23 - compute the day we add all the pre-processing steps that we've done for our training and test data,
582:28 - which is to convert date to a daytime column, extract the day, month, year. Remember your model
582:34 - needs all this information. So any new data that comes in has to go through the same pre-processing
582:38 - steps. Then we impute missing values using the imputer that we have already trained. So we
582:45 - shouldn't lose track of that imputer. We should keep that same imputer around. And similarly,
582:52 - we shouldn't lose track of the scaler because we need to scale to the same ratio that we have
582:57 - used for the training set and then the encoder as well. You need to keep the encoder around and
583:01 - the name of encoded columns around. And after this, all of this pre-processing, you get this
583:05 - X input, which is just a single data frame with all the imputed encoded scaled data as numbers
583:14 - that can be passed into the model for getting a prediction. And you pass this one row of this
583:19 - data frame containing just one row of data into the model and you get back a prediction from the
583:24 - model. Okay. And here's a sample input and you can try playing around with the sample input. You can
583:30 - try changing the date here, and then you can just make a prediction with the sample input and show
583:37 - what this looks like. So it seems like the prediction here is 4 1 0 7. Now this is the kind
583:43 - of thing that you want to showcase on maybe even build a simple tool for people to play with. Like
583:48 - if you have somebody on the business side who wants to just play with your model, you can maybe set
583:55 - up a simple webpage for them using tools like the flask web framework. And in that page, they could
584:02 - just make, they could just enter all of these things. So they could just fill all this information
584:06 - into a form and they would click submit and that that information would then be sent into a machine
584:12 - learning model, and then you will return the value 4 1 0 7 0.65 out. And somebody who has,
584:20 - and maybe this could be shared with store managers as well. And what store managers can now do is
584:26 - put in these values and check if the value that comes out makes sense to them, makes sense for
584:32 - their store. And if a lot of store managers come back and say that, no, this value seems wrong to
584:37 - me, then maybe there is some problem. Maybe you're getting a good loss. Maybe you're getting a,
584:43 - maybe you're getting a good value for the evaluation metric, because that's what you optimize for.
584:47 - But in the real world, the model isn't really performing well, right? So don't underestimate
584:53 - the importance of these qualitative checks. One other thing that you will gather out of this is
584:58 - if you notice that a certain parameter as you're moving it up and down is affecting the output
585:04 - more than it should, then maybe your model has picked up some unintended correlation,
585:10 - which it shouldn't have. So that's where you can then go back and decide,
585:14 - do I really want to have this column or not? Because this column seems to be causing some
585:19 - correlation with the output, but I know from basic common sense or human insight or business insight
585:26 - that they shouldn't have a correlation. And that's where you need to work with business
585:31 - and you need to give them these tools to play with your model and interpret this model in their own
585:37 - head. Okay. So look at various examples from the training, validation, and test
585:44 - sets to decide if you're happy with the result of your model. And then you need to present your
585:49 - results. You need to present what you've done, whether it is a weekly presentation that you
585:53 - give, or it is a monthly presentation, or maybe once at the end of the, of the entire project,
585:59 - but ideally you should be communicating as frequently as possible. So you will need to
586:04 - then create a presentation for non-technical stakeholders, and you need to understand your
586:08 - audience, figure out what they care about most, probably what they care about most is
586:13 - how much maybe the metric is something that they care about, but they probably also want
586:17 - to understand how it works. So don't ignore that. Maybe first time you just want to present a
586:24 - decision tree, get their confidence that the decision tree works well, and then tell them that
586:29 - maybe a hundred decision trees, all of which are slightly different combined is are going to give
586:34 - a better result. And that's why you should be using a random forest and then avoid showing any
586:40 - code or any technical jargon. You definitely don't want to show code. You definitely also don't want
586:44 - to show too much technical jargon. You can mention that this is a technique we're using just for
586:48 - mentioning it, but don't talk about it for too long. The more important thing is to show
586:52 - visualizations and deliver insights in simple words. You should be able to, if you understand
586:58 - your model well enough, you should be able to explain in simple words, why you've chosen the
587:03 - kind of model that you've chosen, why you've engineered the kind of features that you've
587:07 - engineered and what the results of your model are. I mean, if you're saying that my model's
587:13 - cross-entropy is 0.23, that's not conveying anything useful. And that probably indicates
587:19 - that you have not understood how to interpret that value. But if you're saying on the other
587:24 - hand, that most of the time the model is correct, like 98% of the time the model is correct,
587:33 - but it has a slightly high false positive ratio. And that is something that maybe we may want to
587:41 - discuss. And then you can, if they don't know what false positive is, you can go into that
587:46 - and have more detailed conversations around that and maybe show them a visualization, maybe
587:50 - show them a heat map. A heat map is much easier to understand compared to numbers. Like if you're
587:55 - presenting correlations or if you're presenting feature importances, the numbers themselves
588:00 - don't really make sense. But when you present it as a bar chart, then anybody can make out that,
588:05 - ah, this is more important than that. And focus on the metrics that are relevant for the business.
588:11 - Don't use loss functions or use the metrics that have been agreed upon the metrics that
588:15 - they care about. Talk about feature importance. Talk about how to interpret the results,
588:20 - explain the strengths of the model and the limitations of the model. This is where
588:24 - you can draw specific examples and say that, Hey, this is the kind of example that it goes wrong
588:29 - with. And somebody might then come to you and say, okay, this is, there's an easy fix for this.
588:33 - How about you simply, I can get you some more data for this particular case. Will you be
588:37 - able to fix it, et cetera, or you may then decide with some discussion that this is a special case
588:43 - and we don't want to deal with the special case right now, or maybe we want to train a different
588:47 - model. All of that, all of that will come out of discussion. And finally also want to explain how
588:52 - the model can be improved over time, whether you need more data, whether you should be retraining
588:57 - the model every two months. And this is one of the limitations of the model that we just trained,
589:02 - right? I can be confident that for the months of August and September, it's probably going to work
589:08 - pretty well, but for other months, especially the Christmas season, I don't think the model is going
589:13 - to work really well because you didn't give me that test data, or I couldn't use that data for
589:18 - validation. So those are the kinds of things that you have to convey so that you are not setting
589:25 - the wrong expectations. And it seems like obvious things, but most machine learning models, and you
589:31 - can look this up like 80 or 90% of machine learning models that get deployed fail and they fail
589:36 - miserably because of either not having a clear communication about the requirements or the data
589:45 - scientist not picking a good validation set, which is reflective of the kind of data that the model
589:51 - will see in the real world, or just optimizing the wrong metric, optimizing just the loss while
589:58 - they should have been optimizing a certain business metric, right? So those are the kinds
590:03 - of things that you have to keep in mind. And that is what makes a good data scientist. Okay.

598:05 - to make it even harder for you. When you make, when you upload your CSV file, you are shown your
598:14 - rank on the public leaderboard, which is only calculated using 33% of the test data. And then
598:21 - when the competition ends, they will then show you the private leaderboard, which is calculated on
598:28 - the remaining 67% of the test data. And you see how much the, the extents to which they are going
598:34 - to prevent overfitting because they do not want you to overfit to the public leaderboard. They
598:39 - want your model to generalize and overfitting is a central problem in machine learning. So you
598:46 - make predictions on the test set, and then you make a, you upload your predictions based on that
598:52 - you get your public leaderboard score. Every day you can make four or five predictions. So you try
598:58 - to optimize your public leaderboard score, but you shouldn't overfit to the public leaderboard.
599:02 - So you should make sure that your model generalizes well enough. And at the end of the competition,
599:07 - the models that were best generalized and also the most powerful or well-trained show up at the top.
599:15 - And you will often see a discrepancy. You see SDN T they had the highest score on the, they are
599:20 - the best score on the public leaderboard, but on the private leaderboard, where are they? They
599:24 - felt six positions. So they overfitted to the public leaderboard, essentially. And this person

600:32 - is very intense and people are just fighting for the last decimal points. But if you're in the top

601:15 - Nobody can deny you that. And that's what we have for today. And you can make multiple submissions.

601:47 - put the test score here. So this is how you work through a Kaggle competition. You have a list of
601:52 - ideas that you want to try out and then you predict what those ideas will do. You also note down the
601:57 - learnings once you actually try out those ideas. And a lot of times your learnings will be different
602:02 - and then you keep track of your hyper parameters systematically. One last thing that people tend to
602:07 - do is at the very end of a Kaggle competition, when the red line is about to close, they will pick
602:12 - their five best models and then they will ensemble, which means they will average out the predictions
602:18 - or maybe they will stack, which means they will train another model on top of those predictions.
602:23 - And that's how they will then get to the top. And the good thing about Kaggle competitions is you
602:30 - can see what the winners have coded. So if you just go to the discussion section or the code
602:36 - section, you can see what feature engineering they've done. You can see what, how they've
602:40 - trained models. You can see how they've applied cross validation. You can see how they've applied
602:46 - what imputation techniques they've used. And there is no better way to learn than to learn
602:51 - from winners of Kaggle competitions. So get into the habit of reading code. If you can start
602:57 - reading and understanding code, and a lot of these have pretty good documentation around it as well.
603:01 - But if you can get into a habit of reading code, then there is so much you can learn. And
603:06 - this information isn't there anywhere else in the world or in no textbook, no course is going to
603:12 - have this information. The, what do you want to do is go to Kaggle competitions, go through the
603:17 - courts first attempted yourself, go through the discussions, go through the court section,
603:22 - see what people have tried to read their code, copy paste their code, modify it,
603:26 - try a few things on top of it. And that is how you're going to become an effective machine
603:31 - learning practitioner, right? And whatever you need to learn along the way, you can learn the
603:36 - theory as well. So an exercise for you to is to repeat the steps from this notebook on the best
603:42 - cancer identification dataset. That is not a competition. That is just a dataset, but still
603:47 - worth repeating all these steps. And you can just pick out some other Kaggle competitions and try
603:51 - to work through them. Look for competitions where people have trained random forest or decision
603:56 - trees, and you should be fine. One last piece we've not covered here is that you need to then hand
604:02 - over the model to the software developer. Once you're happy with the model, once everybody's on
604:06 - board, who can then put the model into production as a part of an existing software system. And
604:11 - then you need to monitor the results and then make improvements from time to time. Like every two,
604:16 - three months, you can train this model. This is something that you, here's another tutorial that
604:20 - you can check out. This requires knowledge of the flask framework and the Heroku platform. So
604:25 - not something that data scientists typically have to do because this is handed over to software
604:30 - developers, but still a good thing to just learn and try out. Okay. So that's how you work on a
604:38 - machine learning project. You understand the business requirements and the nature of the
604:42 - available data. You classify the problem as a supervised or unsupervised learning problem.
604:48 - And with regression or classification, you perform some data cleaning, you clean,
604:53 - explore, visualize the data, and you create new features. You perform some data preparation,
604:58 - where you create training, test validation sets, you perform imputation, categorical encoding,
605:03 - et cetera. You come up with some quick baseline models just to evaluate your future models.
605:11 - Then you train a bunch of different models that are applicable to your problem and pursue the
605:16 - ideas that are working well. You apply regularization, hyper parameter tuning, ensembling,
605:22 - stacking, K fold cross validation. And finally, you then interpret and present these models
605:31 - to the other stakeholders and work with them iteratively. And this is not a linear process.
605:37 - You can, you may have to go back and forth. Sometimes you may have to refine the business
605:41 - requirements. Sometimes you may have to change the type of problem. You can say that I can't
605:45 - predict exactly, but I can give you a few categories. Is that good enough for you?
605:49 - Sometimes you may want to perform some additional cleaning. Sometimes you may want to get more
605:54 - features in, so you go back and forth, but this is how you should set up a notebook.
605:58 - And then you should have the spreadsheet on the side in the spreadsheet, list out all your ideas,
606:03 - put your ideas into action, into the notebook, and then keep recording the results of your
606:08 - experiments and you will be an effective data scientist. The topic for today is gradient
606:15 - boosting machines or GBMs with XG boost. And here's what we're going to cover today. We're
606:20 - going to download a real world dataset from a Kaggle competition. We are going to perform
606:26 - feature engineering and prepare the dataset for training. We're going to train and interpret
606:31 - a gradient boosting model using the XG boost library. We're going to train with K fold cross
606:42 - validation. So it's a different kind of validation technique, and we will also ensemble the results
606:47 - once we do the K fold cross validation. We'll also look at how to configure the gradient
606:52 - boosting model and how to tune its hyper parameters. Gradient boosting is a very powerful
606:57 - technique. It's probably one of the most powerful classical machine learning algorithms.
607:02 - So pretty much any problem concerning with tabular data, you may find it useful to try
607:09 - out gradient boosting and it's based on a very simple, but elegant idea, which we will discuss
607:15 - as we come to the model training. So let's begin by installing the required libraries.
607:24 - Now here, I'm installing numpy pandas, matplotlib, seaborn, jovian open datasets, XG boost. This is
607:30 - the library we're using today and graph with, this is required to visualize the trees that are
607:35 - created with an XG boost and light GBM as well. If you want to use light GBM
607:42 - and one issue you may face from time to time is when a certain notebook runs on your computer,
607:48 - but does not run on Colab or if it runs on Colab, but does not run on your computer.
607:54 - Whenever you face such issues where the same code does not run in two different environments
607:58 - or maybe leads to an error in two different environments, you want to make sure that the
608:02 - version of the libraries that you have installed in the two environments are the same. So what I
608:07 - mean by that is if you do PIP list and run it, you should be able to see the versions of all the
608:15 - libraries you have installed. And there is another tool called grip. So you can, after PIP list, you
608:21 - can just type this pipe character type grip and let's say type XG boost. And that will just show
608:28 - you the version of XG boost that you have installed, which in this case is 1.4.2. If you do not have
608:33 - this grip, it's just going to show you a whole bunch of libraries, all of the libraries that you
608:37 - have installed, which may become too much. So that's why it's useful, especially on Colab to
608:42 - just add a grip here and check the version. And there are other ways to check versions too,
608:47 - but this is one that is standard across all packages installed because it uses the PIP package
608:52 - manager. So we are using XG boost 1.4.2. Okay. So we are going to take a practical and coding focused
609:05 - approach here. So we will learn gradient boosting by applying it to a real world dataset. And we
609:11 - are going to pick the dataset from a Kaggle competition. This Kaggle competition is called
609:16 - the Rossman store sales competition. And here is some description about it. Rossman is a company
609:26 - that operates over 3000 drugstores in seven European countries. This is a real company and
609:31 - this is all real data. And currently Rossman store managers are tasked with predicting their daily
609:36 - sales for up to six weeks in advance. Now store sales are influenced by many factors. For example,
609:43 - if there's a promotion running at the store, or if the entire company is running a promotion,
609:47 - if there is a competing store nearby, the school and state holidays, because that affects people's
609:54 - behavior, seasonality, and locality. Now with thousands of individual managers predicting sales
610:02 - based on their unique circumstances, the accuracy of the results can be quite varied. So you are
610:08 - provided the historical data for 1,115 Rossman stores. And the task is to forecast the sales
610:16 - column for the test set. And your task is to forecast the sales column for the test set. So
610:23 - we will just look at the training set and the test set, but this is what we want to predict. We have
610:27 - data of 1,115 stores and we want to predict the sales on every single day. Okay. And
610:38 - we are going to download the data from this Kaggle competition. Now we just go to the data tab and

623:42 - you can do. All right. So let's talk about pre-processing and a new and very important topic,
623:50 - feature engineering. So let's take a look at the available columns and see if we can create any new
623:58 - columns or apply any useful transformations. Now, one thing I'm already seeing here is that we have
624:04 - a date column and just the date value by itself may not be very useful because all the information
624:12 - in the training set belongs to the past, but all the dates in the test set occur after the dates
624:20 - in the training set. But what may be more and more useful from the date is maybe extracting some
624:26 - parts out of the date, things like the year, the month, the day of the month, maybe because a lot
624:34 - of school stores are monthly cycles. So they may have higher sales or lower sales towards the end
624:39 - or beginning of the month. People get their salaries at the beginning of the month. So they
624:43 - may spend more during the first couple of weeks. So the day of the month might be useful. The week
624:48 - of the year might also be useful, whether it is the first week of the year, a lot of people are
624:52 - making new purchases or the last week of the year, when it's a holiday season
624:56 - versus maybe somewhere in between where it's not as busy.
625:00 - So date is something that we may want to first convert it into a date time object right now.
625:06 - It is just object. And second, we may want to parse out information from the date. So that's
625:11 - what we are going to do. We are going to extract different parts of the date. And because we have
625:16 - to do this both on the training set and on the test set, and later we will also have to do it
625:22 - when we try to make predictions on single inputs. So this is where we're defining a split date
625:28 - function. So the split date function takes a data frame and first it converts the date column
625:33 - into the date time column here using PD dot two date time. Then it extracts out the year,
625:40 - the month, the day and the week of the year. And now we can call split date on merge TF and merge
625:48 - test TF both of these. So merge TF is simply the train dot CSV combined with the store dot CSV
625:53 - file and merge test TF is simply the test dot CSV combined with the store dot CSV file. And now we
626:00 - have a merge data frame, as you can verify here. And in this much data frame, you will now see
626:04 - these things year, month, day, and week of year. Note that we already have day of week. So we don't
626:11 - need to extract that. So we already know whether it's a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday,
626:15 - Friday, or Saturday or Sunday. And this is essentially what feature engineering is.
626:20 - A model may not be able to make a lot of sense out of a string to 2015 07 31, or even if you
626:26 - convert it to a number of some kind, but once you put it in this format, you are now helping your
626:31 - model, a model will be able to figure out a lot more because now it can pick up monthly patterns.
626:35 - Now it can pick up patterns that happen through the month. So the daily patterns, now it can pick
626:42 - up the weekly patterns over the year, and it can also pick up the pattern during the week. Okay.
626:48 - So all of these patterns will can now be picked up from our model. So that was one useful thing to
626:55 - do. The next thing to notice is that there is this, there is this column called open. This tells you
627:04 - whether the store is open on a certain date. And if the store is not open on a certain date, it's
627:10 - quite likely that there will not be any sales. So let's maybe verify that. If we just check from
627:17 - merge DF, just extract those rows where merge DF dot open is zero, which means where the store
627:23 - is closed and check the sales on those dates and see what all different values sales takes
627:29 - on those dates. So it turns out that the only value in the cases where the store is closed is zero.
627:35 - So there are 172,000 rows of data out of the million where the store is closed. And on all
627:42 - those days, the sales are zero. And you can verify this. If you remove value counts, you'll see
627:47 - that all these, all these sales are zero. And that's what we've done here just by putting
627:52 - in dot value counts as well. Okay. So now instead of trying to model this relationship using a
628:00 - machine learning model, it would be a lot easier to just hard code this in our predictions.
628:05 - I mean, it's our model has a limited capacity or a limited power, whatever kind of model we're
628:10 - training. And the fact that it has to figure out that when open is zero, then the sales are zero.
628:19 - That is just some additional work, which we can save the model. We can do a very simple
628:24 - hard coding here. We can just hard code this relationship in our predictions so that whenever
628:29 - we are making any predictions on the test set, for example, we can simply set the sales to zero
628:35 - if the store is closed. So that's what we can do for the test set. What do we do in the training
628:40 - set? So in the training set, I would argue that the best thing we can do right now is simply
628:44 - remove all these rows and just train a model, which works on data for when the store is open.

628:58 - it easier for the model to learn some of these other relationships, which are not as easy to guess.

634:01 - three, so seven minus three is four. So we had four more months. So this will say that there, the
634:05 - competition has been open for a hundred months. And of course we are doing that row by row for

634:16 - store opened in 2014 or in 2015. So we don't want to put in information about the future into any

638:43 - done. So the end result of all of this is that we are going to add a promo to open column. This
638:50 - tells you months since promo to was open at this car at the store. And we are going to add up is
638:56 - promo to month, which tells you if the promotion was started in the current month. And you can see

639:07 - And you can verify here, you have 2014 week 40, which means somewhere towards the end of 2014.
