639:21 - and this promo runs in January, April, July, and October. So that's why you see zero here.
639:25 - But if you had the matching month, then you would see a one here. For example, here, you can see that
639:31 - this date is February. So here we have, yeah. So here we have February listed in the promotion promo
639:38 - interval as well. So here we have a one. Okay. So now we don't need this column because we have this
639:45 - column is promo to month. And now we don't need this column or these two columns because we have
639:50 - this column promo to open and putting the specific computations aside. The idea here is that we did a
639:58 - joint, we took some store wide information, and then we use that store wide information in
640:04 - combination with the day-to-day or in combination with the present date for each column in the
640:09 - training for each row in the training set in combination with the present date to compute this
640:13 - new column, which gave us a richer information about the data. And this is probably 70 or 80% of
640:24 - machine learning, which is cleaning the data, getting the data into right into the right shape,
640:29 - combining different data sources, engineering new features based on insight, based on insights like
640:36 - this, that maybe we should keep track of how long a competitor has been open or maybe we should keep
640:40 - track of how long a promotion has been open, et cetera, et cetera. Okay. So this is not very easy
640:46 - to come up with. This is, I mean, I've just pulled it out of some of the best notebooks that I saw on
640:50 - the Kaggle competition, but, and these are not possibly not set certainly even the best features.
640:57 - So you may have to think about what other features you can create, but this is what is feature
641:01 - engineering, combining multiple columns, combining data frames and transforming things like breaking
641:08 - out date into things like your month, et cetera. Okay. So with that, we have now completed most of
641:16 - our feature engineering work. So if you now check merge TF, we should have a lot more columns. We
641:22 - have about 25 columns, some competition related columns, some promo related columns, and some
641:28 - date related columns as well. Okay. So let's move on. Now, once we've done this feature engineering,
641:35 - once we've done this exploration, and again, there is sort of an interplay here. It's not that you do
641:40 - feature engineering once and you're done, you do the feature engineering, then you do some more
641:44 - EDA, and then using that EDA, maybe you do some more feature engineering. Maybe you reject some of
641:48 - the features you created. Maybe you combine some of the features to get new features till you start
641:54 - seeing some kind of a pattern or some kind of a correlation. And it's not that it's once done and
642:00 - finished, you train a model. And if you see that the model is not good enough, maybe you need to go
642:04 - back and do more feature engineering. So although we are following the linear process, that is not
642:08 - how it will be typically. And this, this problem that we are solving over the course of three hours
642:14 - is actually something that people have actually spent two to three months solving for the duration
642:19 - of the Kaggle competition, right? So there's a lot of back and forth and nothing is ever just done
642:24 - or finished. But that said, moving on from feature engineering, let us now select the columns that
642:31 - we want to use for training. So here we are going to select, these are all the columns that we have
642:37 - now either used from either picked up from the dataset or created. And out of these, let's see
642:45 - which ones we are going to use as inputs. The store should be an input. We can keep that because the
642:50 - store numbers in the training set and the test set are the same. We are making predictions for
642:54 - the same stores. If we wanted to create a model, which could work on a new store, which is not seen
643:01 - in the training set, then we cannot use the store number. So keep that in mind. But in this case,
643:09 - it's the same 1,115 stores. So we can use the store number. Then we have day of week that is going to
643:14 - be useful for sure. We have date. We can drop date because we have extracted all important parts out
643:20 - of it. We have sales. This is something that should be the target column. So that this is what we've
643:27 - put in the target call. We have number of customers. This is not something that we can use because this
643:33 - information is not available in the test set. And of course, when you deploy the model, you want to
643:37 - make predictions for the next six weeks, you will not have the number of customers. Now, one thing
643:42 - you could do is you could train maybe a customer number of customer prediction model, a model that
643:47 - predicts number of customers, and then use the prediction of that model as an input to prediction
643:52 - of this model, et cetera, et cetera. But let's not go there yet. Right now, we are simply going to
643:58 - drop number of customers as an input column. Openness against something that we're not using. We've
644:04 - already gathered information from it, which is to drop all the stores, which were all the days,
644:09 - all the rows of data where the particular store was not open. And we are training a model only
644:14 - for the days where the store is open. So open is a useless column. It just contains the values. One
644:20 - now promo will be useful, whether the store is running a promotion or not is going to have an
644:25 - impact on the sales, the state holiday, school holiday, both of these are useful. So we're going
644:31 - to keep those within the input, input columns as well. The store type assortment, again, seems like
644:36 - a very useful thing. So we should keep them around. And by the way, these are categorical. And you
644:42 - can verify this by just looking at the unique values for these columns, the competition distance.
644:48 - Yes, this is useful. How far away a competing store is competition open. Now, remember these
644:53 - two, we have combined into competition open, which simply tells you how many months the competing
644:58 - store has been open for. So let's keep that. Then the date has been decomposed into day, month,
645:04 - and year. So we have those. Then we have a week of year. We have promo to both of these are useful,
645:12 - which week are we currently in and whether the store participates in promo to for how long the
645:17 - store has been participating in promo to. So this is the number of months and if promo to a new round
645:23 - of promo to kicks off in a current month. So all of this is useful information that we'll keep
645:30 - the things that we have now engineered away. We can remove like date, open since month,
645:36 - open since year, promo to seems week, et cetera. And the target is sales. So once again, I'm just
645:44 - going to get the input columns out here from the most data frame and create this data frame called
645:49 - inputs. And I'm just going to get the target column out. So now it's a single column and create a
645:54 - merge data, create a single series. So targets will be a series and inputs will be a data frame. And
646:00 - I'm also creating copies here because this is a very small data set. I don't have to worry too
646:05 - much about creating multiple copies, but if you're working with a really large dataset, maybe you
646:10 - shouldn't create a copy and you just have to modify the original data. So you can now check this is
646:18 - inputs. This contains just the input columns. And one thing that you should note here is
646:23 - there seems to be an E. So this seems to be a categorical column state holiday, where it has
646:29 - not just zero or one, but there are several types of holidays that it tracks, ABC and D and the store
646:35 - type assortment. These are also categorical columns with texts. So I'm sure we'll have to handle them
646:40 - separately and the rest of them look numeric. Although one could argue that maybe we should treat
646:46 - day of week as categorical because sales generally are not linearly correlated with the day of the
646:54 - week, like Monday to Sunday, there isn't a linear increase. So we should probably treat them as
646:58 - categorical one could argue the same for day, month, and year as well. But yeah, and this is where
647:07 - you will have to choose which of these do you want to treat numerically? And which of these do you
647:11 - want to treat categorically? Now, the good thing again is if you're using decision trees, decision
647:17 - trees can typically work with both types because decision trees can create these decisions. Like
647:23 - is store is day of the week, less than one. So to pick the day of the week, zero and the rest of
647:30 - the days of the week will go in another direction. So decision trees can actually pick out using
647:34 - binary decisions while the days like if Friday, Saturday, Monday are specific branches that
647:42 - decision trees can create, even if you don't create separate columns for each of these days. Okay. So
647:49 - yeah, but that's, that's, that's still a decision that you have to come up with. Should we treat
647:53 - some of these as categorical or some of these as numerical? So that's inputs. And let's take a
648:00 - look at targets as well. And that's targets here. So these are the things that we're trying to
648:07 - predict. This is the sales. And we're also going to generate test inputs simply from merge test
648:13 - TF. We're going to get the input columns and then create a copy. So now this will contain just all
648:19 - the test inputs. And at this point, hopefully the test inputs and train input should have the same
648:28 - number of columns. If they don't, then obviously you're not going to be able to train a model,
648:33 - which can make predictions on the test set. So when you get to this point where you've selected
648:37 - some input and a test column input columns, make sure that the test inputs and train inputs have
648:42 - the same number of columns, which in this case is 16. Okay. Then here is the, here is the somewhat
648:49 - subjective exercise of picking the numeric and categorical columns. Now there are some binary
648:55 - columns, which have zero one values. We don't really need to one heart encode them. They're
648:59 - already one heart encoded as zero one. So put them into numeric just to keep things simple to
649:06 - avoid this one heart encoding and introducing new columns. Now, with some of these things like
649:13 - month and day, these could be made categorical, but I chose to just keep them numeric and see what
649:18 - happens. You can try and convert them into categorical columns if you want and see if that
649:23 - has an effect. So the only things that I'm keeping categorical right now are the day of the week,
649:30 - because there are only seven of them. This, whether it's a state holiday. So there are these values,
649:35 - ABC, it's definitely not numeric store type and assortment. And both of these are also not numeric.
649:41 - Okay. So these, whatever are the textual columns, I am making them categorical and specifically one
649:47 - exception I've made here is day of week. And, but you can try and experiment with this in the
649:52 - future. Try and experiment with this and see if you get a different, see if you get a better result.
649:59 - Okay. So let's now impute the missing numerical data. And instead of doing an imputer, let's
650:05 - maybe just check where the numerical missing numerical data is. So it turns out that the only
650:11 - place where numeric data is missing is competition distance. And this is possibly because for
650:20 - competition stores, there is no nearby competing store. So in such cases, and the same is true for
650:25 - the test inputs as well. And there are no other columns where there are any missing data. So let's
650:30 - think about this for a moment. We need to put in a number here for competition distance. Otherwise,
650:35 - some of our models may not train and a missing value here for competition distance indicates
650:43 - that there is no competing store near this store. Now, if we put the value zero here, or if we put
650:50 - a very small value here, then that would be the opposite. That would mean the opposite. That means
650:56 - the competition is right next door. So we should probably not put the value zero here. What we
651:01 - might instead want to do is maybe just put a very large value here. Like if let's say, just instead
651:08 - of saying that there is no competition nearby, let's say that there's a competition is a hundred
651:12 - kilometers away or something like that. Just to sort of retain the meaning of the value that is
651:21 - inserted here. Zero would mean that the competition is next door. That's not what we want to suggest.
651:25 - We want to suggest that there is no competition nearby. The closest thing to that is to suggest
651:29 - that the competition is really far away. So here's the trick that I'm going to use.
651:34 - I am going to fill these empty values with the highest value for the competition distance column.
651:47 - So let's check max distance. So max distance is seven, five, eight, six, zero. That means
651:54 - about 75 kilometers away. So that seems reasonable. 75 kilometers. Maybe if, if I want,
652:00 - if I want, I can even double that number and make that one 50 kilometers away. So I'm just going to
652:04 - fill in that wherever competition distance has the value, none or NAN, I'm going to fill the value
652:12 - 75, 75, eight, six, zero times two. So I'm just going to say that the competition is 150 kilometers
652:18 - away, which basically has the same meaning as this store, not having any competition. Okay.
652:26 - So this is again, something that you will have to do very carefully when you are filling in missing
652:30 - values. It's not simply a matter of just using an imputer and putting in the averages or putting in
652:35 - the means or media. Sometimes you have to think about what it means to fill a certain value to
652:40 - fill the mean would, to fill the mean would change the meaning because then you would say that the
652:46 - competition is maybe like a few hundred meters away, but rather what we want to put in here is to say
652:51 - that competition is really far away or does not exist. Okay. So although we have seen these standard
652:57 - strategies for imputing values and scaling values, you will have to apply some thought to it when you
653:03 - apply it to real world problems. The standard strategies are fine. When you want to just quickly
653:07 - get to a machine learning model, but when you really want to improve the model, these are all
653:11 - things that you have to think carefully about. Okay. Let's then scale numeric values. I don't see
653:17 - any problem here. I think we can just scale them all to the zero to one range. That should be fine.
653:22 - So we are using a min max scaler to do that. And then let's encode some categorical columns as well.
653:28 - Now note that for categorical columns, we've mostly picked up columns, which have text data.
653:33 - So what will happen is we will take each of these unique categories and create a column for each of
653:39 - these categories and just put in the values one and zero, depending on whether the row contains
653:45 - the category for that column. Okay. So that's what we do using one hot encoder. Again, imputation,
653:53 - scaling and encoding one hot encoding is something that we've covered probably four times now and
653:59 - hopefully starting to sound boring and repetitive and routine, essentially. So just go through the
654:06 - previous tutorials. If you want to understand how these work.
654:10 - Now, one thing I want to point out is we have not created a validation set yet. And this is because
654:15 - we are going to use a different validation technique called key fold cross validation. We'll
654:19 - see that in just a moment, but that's all the data preparation that we need to do. And I encourage
654:26 - you to look through notebooks created by participants in the Kaggle competition. You can look through

655:13 - information is not available anywhere in any book or any course. So in fact, this entire notebook
655:19 - has been created just by looking at a bunch of different notebooks from the code tab of this
655:24 - competition, right? So do check that out. Let's do a quick recap before we move forward, just to
655:33 - revise what we did for future engineering. So we downloaded the dataset. We downloaded, we
655:42 - downloaded, we downloaded the dataset and that gave us a training CSV file, a test CSV file, and a
655:48 - store that CSV file with some metadata about stores. All right. So we had, we have a training
655:52 - set, and then we have a test set and a test set contains about 40,000 rows of data. And then we
655:58 - have the store dataset, which we merged into the training and test sets. So that's one thing that
656:02 - you will have to do often merge data from multiple sources or perform some kind of joints to augment
656:08 - the training data. Then we looked at the dates and we extracted information like the year month
656:14 - day and week of year from the date. And that gave us a merged data frame with these additional
656:21 - columns. Then we looked at whether the store was open or closed and realized that when the store
656:25 - is closed, the sales are zero. And we decided that this is not something we want to model. This is
656:30 - something we will hard code into our predictions. So we removed all the rows where the say a store
656:35 - was closed and the sales was zero. Next, we added some columns for the competition. So instead of
656:44 - having the month and year since the competition competing store opened, we just have the number
656:48 - of months since the competing store opened a single value, which will be more useful to the model.
656:55 - Similarly, we added a couple of columns, one called promo to open and is promo to month promo to open
657:00 - indicates for how long the store has been participating in promo to a company-wide promotion
657:05 - and promo to month to keep track of whether the current row has a month when the promotion starts
657:16 - at the current store. Then we identified the input and target columns, and then we created inputs
657:25 - and targets to data frames. Then we identified the numeric and categorical columns as well. And then
657:32 - we imputed the numeric columns. And this time we had to take a specific decision to put in a very
657:37 - large value for competition distance. Then we scaled the numeric values to the zero to one range
657:43 - and encoded the categorical columns, which were strategically chosen so that some of the categorical
657:48 - columns, which have numbers, we've kept them as numeric columns. So we don't want to change them.
657:55 - And finally, we've put together these two variables X, which contains our training plus
658:00 - validation set essentially. So which contains just the numeric data from the numeric columns and the
658:07 - encoded categorical columns, right? So that is what X is. It contains all the data that can be directly
658:13 - fed into a model. It is all numeric. It has no empty values. And similarly, we have X test, which
658:20 - is just all the inputs that will be used to make predictions for the test set. So that's our X and
658:27 - X texts and X and Y are common used to refer, commonly used to refer to inputs and targets in
658:31 - machine learning. That's why we using uppercase X and uppercase X test. All right. So we're finally
658:41 - ready to start training our gradient boosting model. And here's how a GBM model works. A GBM is
658:48 - short for gradient boosting machine. So first we're trying to predict the sale at every store. The
658:59 - first thing that the grading boosting model does is to predict simply the average value of the
659:04 - target column, compute the average value of the target column and use that as an initial prediction
659:11 - for every input. So the model completely ignores all the training data that it is given. It simply
659:16 - looks at the predictions or the, the target values, and it simply takes an average of the target
659:21 - values and it uses that as a prediction. Now, obviously that's not a good prediction. So
659:27 - whatever error function you're using, let's say mean squared error or whatever, the prediction is
659:33 - going to be pretty bad, but here is where it gets interesting. Now, once you have predicted, you
659:38 - once you made one set of predictions, which is the averages, then we go back into each row of
659:43 - training data and we calculate the difference of the predictions with the actual targets. So just
659:53 - to convey that let's maybe work through an example here. Let's say we have three things. We have
660:01 - month. Let's say we have month and then we have a day, day of month, and we have a competition
660:14 - distance. Let's call that CD competition distance. And then we have store number here. And then we
660:20 - have the sale. Okay. So we have a bunch of stores. So there is some information here for the store.
660:27 - And then the sale here, let's say the sale was 700. Then there is some information for a second
660:32 - store at a second date. And let's say the sale on this for this training row, the sale was 800.
660:38 - And we have another one. Let's say the sale here was a nine 70, et cetera, et cetera. And like,
660:45 - let's say eight 50 here. So these are some rows from the training data. So the first prediction
660:51 - that our model is going to make is simply the average of these numbers, average of 700, 800,
660:56 - 900, and eight 50. I believe this would be, let's say this is around eight 20. So it just predicts
661:02 - eight 20 for all of them. Okay. So just predicts eight 20 for all of them. Okay. So just predicts
661:14 - eight hundred and 20 for all of them. Now that's a bad, bad prediction. So let's call this P zero
661:20 - or prediction zero. Now using these P zero, it is going to compute the residuals. Now what is
661:25 - the residual? It is simply the difference between the prediction and the actual sale. Sorry. The
661:32 - sale. Yeah. Difference between this actual sale and the prediction. So in this case, the residual
661:36 - should be minus 80 or sorry, minus not minus 80. The residual should be 700 minus eight 20. So
661:49 - minus one 20 in this case, the residual should be 800 minus 20, 800 minus 20. That's minus 20. In
661:57 - this case, the residual is nine 70 minus eight 20. That is one 50. And in this case, the residual is
662:03 - eight 50 minus eight 20 excuse the poor handwriting and that's 30. Okay. So now this is what we know
662:11 - that in our current set of predictions, we are off by this much for each row. So here is what
662:17 - happens next. Now the model takes this input. So it takes all these inputs and instead of trying
662:24 - to predict the sale price, it builds a decision tree to predict this value. Okay. And then it
662:32 - takes this input and using this input, it tries to predict this value and so on. Okay. So a decision
662:39 - tree is created. So now we create a decision tree. Let's use this to just represent a decision
662:43 - tree. And it's not an unbounded decision tree. Typically this is bounded in terms of depth. So
662:48 - we create a decision tree and using this decision tree, we now try to predict how much we were off
662:54 - by when we made the first prediction. So when we made the first prediction, we were off by one
662:58 - 20 and now suppose our decision tree predicts here minus 80. It predicts here minus 30. It
663:04 - predicts here that we were off by that we were off by 70 and it predicts here that we were off
663:10 - by 40. Okay. So this is what our first decision tree predicted. Now using the first decision tree.
663:19 - Yeah. So now we have, we have this decision tree. Let's just call this D. So this is the
663:27 - prediction of the decision tree, which was an attempt to predict the residual. But of course
663:33 - this is itself not that perfect. So what do we do next? We compute the next set of residuals.
663:39 - So the next set of residuals would be, let me just write that here. The next set of residuals
663:43 - would be wanted to predict minus one 20, but I predicted 80. So I, I still have, I'm still
663:52 - off by minus 40. I wanted to predict minus 20, but I predicted minus 30. So that means I'm
663:57 - off by plus 10. I wanted to predict one 50, but I predicted 70. So I'm off by 80 and I'm off by
664:03 - minus 10. Right. So this way we continue. We keep getting residuals. So this is what this picture
664:09 - is representing here. First we use the average and that's obviously very bad. So the error is very
664:15 - high. Then we train a decision tree to compute the residuals or the, the errors that we, that we
664:22 - incurred when we were predicting the average. So that is these errors. We trained a decision tree
664:28 - to do that. Once again, we don't do a perfect job, but it is better. Right. If you see, if, if I
664:34 - simply add up the prediction from the original model, 820 plus minus 80. So the overall prediction
664:43 - from the model becomes the first prediction plus the prediction of the first decision tree. So
664:48 - 820 minus 80 becomes 740. So 740 is now a lot closer to 700. Similarly, 820 minus 30 is 790. So
665:01 - 790 is a lot closer to 800 than 820. Similarly, 820 plus the prediction of the first decision tree,
665:08 - 70 is about 890. So 890 is a lot closer to 970 than 820 alone. So almost all the prediction
665:17 - now become better because we have trained a decision tree to compute the residuals. Okay. So
665:23 - as soon as we, as soon as we create one decision tree, all our predictions become better. And how
665:28 - do we make the predictions? We simply add the original prediction plus the prediction, the
665:32 - predicted residual by the decision tree. But of course we still not perfect. We still will not
665:39 - have a perfect model. So then we train another decision tree to compute the residuals that were
665:45 - obtained after taking the result of the original guess and the first decision tree. So that second
665:52 - decision tree is trying to correct the errors made by the second decision tree made by the first
665:57 - decision tree. And that reduces the error further. Then we take train another decision tree and that
666:03 - attempts to correct the errors made by the third decision tree. Okay. So that's how gradient boosting
666:09 - works. And let's just go over this step by step and try to understand this again. Okay. So let's
666:15 - go over this step. So the average value of the target column is used as the initial prediction
666:22 - for every input. That's the starting point. Then we compute the residuals of the predictions with
666:28 - the targets. So we, we now identify how much we are off by what the error in our prediction is.
666:34 - Then we create a limited depth decision tree of limited depth to just predict the residuals for
666:40 - each input. Now we're not trying to predict the entire sales. And in some sense, it's a smaller,
666:45 - just trying to correct the errors of our initial guess. Then here's a step that is an additional
666:55 - step, which is called, which is called the learning rate. We take the predictions from the decision
666:59 - tree, and then we scale them using a parameter called the learning rate. So we don't directly
667:04 - add the prediction of the decision tree to the original prediction. We just scale it a little bit
667:08 - and we'll talk about that in a second. Then those scaled predictions from the decision tree are
667:14 - added to the previous predictions to obtain the new and improved predictions for that particular
667:19 - row. And then steps two to five are repeated to create new decision trees, each of which is
667:26 - trained to predict just the residuals from the previous prediction. Okay. So that's our GBM works.
667:32 - And let me talk about scaling now. So coming back here, we had, we had this data. So we had this
667:41 - input columns and the target that we were trying to predict was, what was it? Target was 700. And
667:52 - we predicted, we predicted the average. The average was eight 20. So this was our initial
667:57 - prediction P zero. Then we trained the decision tree. Then we computed the residual. So let's call
668:04 - that R zero and the residual is minus 80. And then we do it for all of these columns. We compute the
668:10 - residual. Then we train a decision tree D and D is trying to predict these residuals. So D is trying
668:16 - to use the inputs to predict the residuals. And again, D is going to be off by a little bit. So
668:21 - what is the number we used here? Let's say that D predicted minus 40. Now what we do is we actually
668:27 - have a training, a learning rate parameter. And this is called alpha. And let's say alpha set to
668:32 - 0.5. So instead of predicting 820 plus point plus minus 40 as the prediction from our model after
668:40 - creating one tree, we actually predict 820 plus alpha times or 0.5 times minus 40. Right. Which is
668:54 - a prediction. So the actual prediction that we are now making, and this prediction is the prediction
668:59 - from the original average plus the alpha, the learning rate times, the prediction from the
669:04 - decision tree. So eight 20 plus alpha alpha is 0.5 multiplied by 40. So minus 20, eight 20 plus minus
669:12 - 20, that is 800. Okay. So this is the prediction. And this prediction is coming from P one comes
669:19 - from our average plus our first decision tree. Okay. That's how P one comes in. Then once we have
669:27 - P one, we compute the residuals are one, which is how far away the first prediction is from the
669:34 - actual value that we're trying to predict. It is still off by minus 20. And then we compute that
669:39 - for all of them. Then we train a decision tree to use the inputs to compute this residual.
669:45 - So now we have D two and let's say it's predicts minus 10 here. The residual it's still not
669:52 - perfect because it's not a full decision tree. Then once again, we multiply this by alpha. So we go
669:58 - 0.5. So we go the initial average a plus alpha times the decision from decision tree one plus
670:04 - alpha times the decision from decision tree two. So once again, we multiply this by 0.5. So that
670:09 - means now we get to eight zero five as our P two, and then we compare eight zero five and we're
670:16 - still far away from P zero. We still far away from the target. So then we compute the next residual
670:22 - R two. So R two becomes five and that's how it proceeds. Okay. So ultimately the prediction of
670:28 - the model, the prediction of the model P for a particular input is the average a plus alpha times
670:38 - the prediction of decision tree one. And what was decision tree one trained on? It was trained to
670:43 - predict P minus a, essentially the residual from the original average plus alpha times decision
670:50 - tree two. And what was decision tree to train to do the decision tree to was trained to predict
670:56 - the difference between this and the actual target that we have. Right. And then we have alpha three
671:05 - and alpha three will have decision three and then so on. Okay. So you can configure alpha. This is
671:10 - called the learning rate and you can configure the number of iterations or the number of decision
671:14 - trees that you create. And that is called the number of iterations or the number of estimators.
671:20 - Okay. And that's all it is. That's all a decision trees, successive. That's all a gradient boosting
671:26 - model is successively changing, successively improving our predictions by training these
671:31 - small decision trees to correct the errors of the model that we have so far. Now, why do we have
671:38 - this alpha in place? Why don't we simply add the predictions from the, from the previously
671:42 - trained decision tree. So it turns out that alpha prevents overfitting. If we apply that scaling
671:47 - factor to the decision tree, that was just trained to predict the residuals. So we are
671:52 - intentionally creating some error there, which can be then filled in by the next decision tree
671:57 - and so on. And that helps prevent overfitting to the training set. So that's one thing. And then
672:04 - second, why is this called gradient boosting? It is called boosting because. Because boosting is
672:12 - the name of the general technique where you train a new model to correct the errors of, or to
672:19 - improve an existing model. So whenever you have this kind of a system, as opposed to bagging,
672:24 - which is what random forest to remember with random forests, each decision tree tries to make
672:30 - the entire prediction that is called bagging, bootstrapping, bagging, et cetera. But boosting
672:36 - means you are correcting or you're improving an existing model. So the second decision tree
672:41 - depends on how the first decision tree was created. The third decision tree depends on how
672:45 - the second decision tree was created and its predictions and so on. So that's boosting.
672:49 - Now, why is it called gradient boosting? Well, in some sense, this is similar to the gradient
672:55 - descent algorithm. And the objective here is to minimize the loss. So we have a certain loss,
673:01 - like means squared error or some kind of a loss function. And the objective is to create
673:06 - new decision trees to minimize that loss, right? So in some sense, we are doing iterative gradient
673:12 - descent. So that's the mathematical term for it. And that's why it's called gradient. So gradient
673:17 - boosting machine is simply a boosting technique, which tries to minimize the error by creating
673:26 - new estimators or new decision trees each time. And that's what it is. Okay. So try and describe
673:36 - in your own words, how a gradient boosting model machine differs from a random forest and do check
673:43 - out if you want to check out the mathematical explanation for this, do check that out as well.
673:47 - But I will warn you that when you look at the mathematical explanation, it is pretty hairy.
673:53 - There's a lot of equations. So unless you're comfortable with the math, I would not recommend
673:58 - it and that there are some graphs as well, but it doesn't really help. But yeah, do check it out.
674:04 - If you're interested in checking it out, but really the most intuitive explanation that I found is
674:09 - just the fact that gradient boosting machines correct, add more decision trees to correct the
674:14 - errors of the decisions we've made so far. Okay. I also like this tutorial series on this YouTube
674:22 - channel called stat quest that you can check out. This is a five part series, I believe the gradient
674:28 - boosting. Yeah. There are four or five parts. This also gets into the mathematics, but this also has
674:34 - a bunch of visual explanations. So you can use that to get a good sense of it. But as long as
674:41 - you're getting the basic idea that we are training more trees to correct errors from our previous
674:45 - trees, you should be fine. We're always using the, all the input features. Now to train a GBM,
674:52 - we can use the XGB rig, the XGB regressor class from XGB boost. There is also a gradient boosting
674:59 - machine in scikit-learn, but XGB boost is far more efficient and far more versatile. So from XGB
675:06 - boost, which is going to import XGB regressor. And let's check out what that looks like here.
675:12 - You can see all the parameters that it accepts, and you can now see that there is this number of
675:16 - estimators, which tells you how many trees you are going to create. And you can now experiment with
675:24 - this. You can try setting number of estimators to one and see how that changes. See how many trees
675:30 - get created and try changing into two, three, four, and see how many trees are created.
675:37 - And then there is this max depth. So you can configure how deep each tree goes. Why do we
675:43 - need a max depth? Well, think about it coming back here. If we trained an unbounded decision
675:50 - tree, then that unbounded decision tree would essentially exactly fit the residual. So it would
675:55 - completely overfit to the training set to predict the residual. And once again, that would be a
676:02 - problem. So all of these are regularizations, because if it overfits through the training set,
676:05 - then it's going to perform poorly on the validation side. So typically these trees are not very deep.
676:12 - Then you have this learning rate and this learning rate is basically just the alpha
676:17 - or it's called eta. I believe in XGB boost, it is simply the factor that is applied, the scaling
676:22 - down the damping factor that is applied to the residual prediction from each decision tree. Once
676:27 - again, this is used to avoid overfitting. Otherwise you may overfit to the training data.
676:32 - And then you have a bunch of other parameters. So I'm simply going to create an XGB regressor here.
676:38 - And once again, setting some random state and end jobs, random state is simply to ensure that
676:43 - the randomization is using this number 42 as a seed. So that each time we run model dot fit,
676:51 - or each time we run this piece of code, we get the same results. That's what random status for.
676:56 - And if you change this number, you will get different results, but each time you will get
677:00 - the same result when you put the number seven, for example, then you have end jobs. This is simply
677:07 - to configure the number of threads that it should use in the background. When you put in minus one
677:11 - here, it will use all the threads that are available on the machine that we're connected to.
677:16 - Then here is the number of estimators or the number of decision trees that we will create.
677:19 - So we start with the average train one decision tree to correct the errors,
677:23 - train a second decision tree to correct the errors of the first two combined and so on.
677:27 - We'll create 20 decision trees and each decision tree will have a maximum depth of four.
677:31 - So let's call model dot fit now. And this takes not too long to fit because it's a,
677:37 - what 20 decision trees, each with a maximum depth of four shouldn't take more than a few seconds.
677:42 - So it took about eight seconds and you can see some of the other parameters here as well.

678:02 - And now here's an exercise for you. Can you now describe in your own words,
678:07 - how a gradient boosting model fits this machine learning training workflow.
678:12 - We take some inputs, put them into the model. It makes a first guess, which is just the averages.
678:17 - We compute the loss, we compute the residuals, and then we train a decision tree to predict
678:23 - the residuals. Now we put in the inputs once again. Now we get, now we get the output as the
678:28 - average prediction, plus the prediction of the decision tree scaled down. Then we compute the
678:34 - residuals again, using the targets. And then we optimize by training another decision tree and so on.
678:40 - Okay. And we can now make predictions using the model. So right now, since we just have the training

687:44 - keep track of that specific version of the notebook so that you can replicate the experiment if
687:48 - required. Okay. Now notice that we didn't create a validation set before training our XGBoost model.
687:55 - This is because we want to use a different validation strategy this time. This is called
687:59 - K fold cross validation. So in K fold cross validation, we take our training data, which
688:05 - is separate from the test data. The test data is supposed to be used only at the very end,
688:10 - but we take a training data and we split that into many parts. So when you say K fold K can
688:16 - be configured, let's say case five. So we split it into five folds or five parts. It's like taking
688:21 - a piece of paper and folding it five times. And then each time we train five different models.
688:28 - And for each model, we use a different fold as the validation set. So we take split one and we
688:34 - train a model on split one, and here we use the first 20% as a validation set for split two.
688:40 - We use the second 20% as the validation set for split three. We use the third 20% as validation
688:45 - set and so on. And we use that for hyper parameter tuning. We use that for just experimenting
688:55 - between different modeling strategies. And the benefit of this is that we are not sacrificing
689:00 - on any of the data we are for training. We are using all the data for training, but at the same
689:05 - time, we still have a way to analyze how these models are doing by looking at the validation
689:11 - score for each of the splits. Okay. So that's what we'll implement. And K fold is quite useful for
689:16 - small data sets. It's not very useful for the really large data sets like this one, where we
689:22 - have millions of pros, a million rows, actually. And the other thing to keep in mind also is that
689:27 - K fold is that K fold may not be the optimal strategy here because our validation set should
689:35 - ideally reflect what kind of data the model will see in real life should ideally be closer to the
689:41 - test set and the test set occurs in the future after the training set. So ideally the validation
689:47 - set should be in the future of the training set. So we are breaking that. So we are breaking that
689:54 - requirement here. Also, so potentially the validation score that we get will not be as
690:00 - useful as we might get if we simply use the last one, right? So those are some things to consider.
690:07 - And we are doing it here primarily to demonstrate how to use K fold cross validation, but that
690:11 - definitely keep that in mind when you have time order data, maybe you just want to do
690:16 - just like split five, which is just take the last 20% by date and use that as a validation set
690:21 - Regardless, here we go with K fold cross validation. We say SK learn dot model selection import K fold.
690:28 - So we have this K fold utility that we're going to use. This is going to give us all these splits

690:40 - in the number of splits and then we can use, we can say K fold split and give it the data that we

696:35 - to know. Okay. All right. So that's how we use, we perform K fold cross validation. Next, let's
696:45 - talk about hyper parameter tuning and regularization. Now, just like any other machine learning model,
696:50 - there are several hyper parameters that we can adjust to change the capacity of the model and
696:54 - to reduce overfitting. And this is the typical model complexity versus error curve. When your
697:01 - model is very weak, let's say you're just training one decision tree, then obviously you're going to
697:07 - be, you're going to have a very high error. But as you start increasing the capacity of your model,
697:14 - your training error starts to decrease and it continues to decrease because your model looks at
697:18 - the training data. It has more parameters to learn information about the training data. So that
697:22 - continues to decrease over time, but at some point, your test error will start to increase.
697:27 - And this is where you have to manage the different hyper parameters and adjust them in such a way
697:32 - that you get to the best, best fit. You get to the minimum possible test error. And any further you
697:38 - go, the test error should start to increase. So that should be your goal with all the different
697:42 - hyper parameters that you train. Okay. And XGBoost has quite a few hyper parameters. You can
697:47 - check out the documentation here, and there's a detailed explanation about each of the hyper
697:52 - parameters. So once you have that intuitive picture in place, average followed by a decision
697:57 - tree to correct the residuals followed by another decision tree to correct the residuals. And how
698:02 - you, how we make predictions is simply adding up all the predictions, but with a learning rate
698:07 - applied, then you can check out all of these different parameters here. This is the learning
698:13 - rate. This is called the men's split loss, max depth, men, child, et cetera, et cetera. Okay.
698:20 - Everything to do with trees. So you could experiment with the hyper parameters with
698:27 - K fold cross validation, which means that every different hyper parameter you try, you could
698:33 - perform K fold cross validation for it and look at the result. And here is a helper function to
698:39 - help you do that. But because we don't have that kind of time, we want to do quick experiments.

700:08 - going to train the more you train, the lower the loss will get. So here right now we are looking

700:54 - this is going to take some time. So maybe we'll let this one run and we will just cancel this
701:00 - execution, but you will see this kind of a trend here. At some point you will see the best fit and
701:06 - then training error will continue to decrease, but the test error will start to increase potentially.
701:11 - So as an exercise, do experiment with different values of an estimators and then plot a graph,
701:17 - try and plot this kind of a graph of the training loss and the validation loss for the different
701:25 - strategies that you've tried. Yeah. For the different strategies that you've tried and see
701:32 - where you get the best fit. And it's not just about the best fit. Something, sometimes it's
701:36 - also about what is the additional benefit that you're getting. Let's say by moving to a hundred
701:41 - to 240 estimators, the validation RMSE reduces from 12 0 9 to 11 90. That's not a big increase.
701:48 - And the amount of time it takes to take a train 240 estimators is more than double the amount of
701:54 - time it takes to train a hundred estimators. So that's where you will have to decide. Is it worth
701:59 - the time to add the additional estimators? Now, if it's not, then you will have to decide what
702:05 - it is now. If it's not, then maybe you stop at a hundred 150, wherever you see that the change in
702:10 - validation RMSE started to flatten out. So you can stop somewhere here as well. That's not a
702:14 - problem in a lot of cases. It's not like it starts to increase immediately, but it starts to continue
702:19 - to decrease very slightly for a very long time. And at this point, it just doesn't make sense
702:24 - because you're creating this huge model, which is only slightly better than this much smaller model.
702:29 - Right. So start out small, increase the capacity of your model, and whenever it stops making sense
702:36 - to just increase the capacity further, either in terms of the time or because of overfitting,
702:41 - you can stop. Now, similarly here, we have max depth. So as you increase the maximum depth of
702:49 - each tree, the capacity of the tree increases, and it can capture more information. Let me maybe
702:55 - stop this right now. So that let me do this with a smaller number of estimators so that
703:00 - we can see the effect. Let's say estimators 10. Yeah. So max depth is simply the depth of each
703:13 - tree, the trees that we create to correct the residuals, what is the maximum depth you want
703:17 - to allow them to have. And you can see as we increase the max depth initially, the loss
703:24 - definitely goes down. Once again, experiment with different values of max depth. Now we can see that
703:42 - these are not overfitting just yet. We can see that these, these models are not overfitting
703:51 - right now. So you can probably still push the model. You can probably still keep increasing
703:56 - the max step till the point that you start to see some overfitting happening, which means
704:00 - the training error continues to decrease, but the test error actually starts to increase.
704:05 - So the kind of trend that you'll notice is let's say around max depth of 15, the test error
704:10 - flattens out, and then maybe around max depth of 18, the training error is still going down,
704:15 - but the test error has started to increase and at max depth of 20, the text, the test
704:20 - error actually starts to, or the validation error actually starts to go up by a significant amount.
704:27 - Right? So when you, whenever you notice this trend, maybe you come back and find the lowest point.
704:36 - And also just to clarify, overfitting is not a situation where the training error has to be zero.
704:41 - That's not the case. Overfitting specifically is described by this scenario where the training
704:46 - error is increasing is decreasing as you increase the model complexity, but at the same time,
704:52 - the test error is increasing. So the model is getting worse, even though it is getting better
704:56 - at the training data. Okay. Next up, we have the learning rate. The learning rate is the alpha that
705:02 - is applied to the predictions. So this is the alpha. Remember we take the initial average,
705:08 - then we apply an alpha to this factor to scale the prediction of the decision tree. And then
705:14 - we apply that to all further decision trees. So we set the learning rate to 0.01. That means
705:20 - it's going to give very less weightage to this prediction. It's going to hardly collect the
705:24 - residual maybe by 1%. So that makes it very hard for the model to even get good at the training
705:31 - set. So you will need a large number of estimators. So a very low learning rates, something like 0.1
705:38 - will lead to underfitting and a very high learning rate like 0.99 may lead to overfitting. It's not
705:45 - that it will, but it may lead to overfitting because you have other hyper parameters as well.
705:50 - Right. So one hyper parameter alone cannot cause overfitting, but because some other, there may
705:56 - be other regularizing parameters, but this is the direction roughly that it looks like low learning
706:01 - rate, low power, because you're really not giving your decision trees that much weight in their
706:07 - predictions. You're giving a much higher weight to the initial prediction, high learning rate.
706:12 - You're giving the decision trees a lot of power. So it's likely that they may start overfitting
706:18 - through the training set while the test set starts to get worse or the test error or validation error
706:24 - starts to get worse. So here's, you can see here when the learning rate is 0.01, the validation
706:32 - RMSE is $5,000 that's way off. That's like we're trying to predict values in the range 5,000 to
706:38 - 10,000. And if you're off by 5,000, that's pretty bad. And hopefully if we get somewhere here and
706:44 - start to get better, I don't think it's going to overfit just yet because we are just at 50
706:49 - estimators, but let's say we had 500 estimators or a thousand estimators, and we had given them each
706:55 - a max depth of maybe 10 or something, then you would definitely see that maybe beyond 0.7 or so.
707:02 - The models would start to overfit, but right now it's just because the number of estimators is so
707:07 - low that there's not enough power. Even if you set the learning rate to one, it may not overfit.
707:13 - There is a question can hyper parameter optimization be done while combining multiple
707:17 - hyper parameters? Yes, absolutely. It's like if I've put in an estimators 50 here, I could put
707:21 - in an estimators 20 and I could put in max depth of 10 and I could put in whatever I want here.
707:32 - So ultimately what test params is doing is creating a random forest and that random forest
707:38 - is then going to be trained on the data. And then we're going to evaluate it using the,
707:43 - by making predictions on the training and validation sets, computing the RMSE.
707:47 - So you can modify multiple hyper parameters at a time, but it's generally a good strategy to start
707:54 - with the most effective or the hyper parameters that is going to have the biggest effect. Let's
708:00 - say the number of estimators I would think that initially would have the highest effect and find
708:04 - a good value for the number of estimators. Like I would probably try and try multiples of two.
708:09 - I would go 50, 100, 200, 400. And at some point I would start to realize that maybe the benefit
708:16 - is not there of doubling again, or maybe it has started to overfit. So maybe I'll just again
708:21 - between, maybe find something between 200 and 400 that works best. Maybe try and plot a graph
708:26 - and figure out. So pick the biggest, most impactful hyper parameter first, try and optimize that.
708:32 - Then pick the next most impactful one. And how do you figure out which is the most impactful one?
708:37 - Well, typically if you just try two values of each hyper parameter, like very quickly,
708:42 - you can see how much effect each hyper parameter has initially. So when, if you, if the number of
708:46 - estimators is very low, like 10, then changing the learning rate by a lot is not going to cause
708:52 - overfitting a very quickly. So yeah, it is subjective, depends on the dataset, but it's a
708:58 - question of just experimenting a little bit, figuring out which hyper parameters you should
709:02 - optimize first for gradient boosting. That is typically number of estimators, max depth, learning
709:08 - rate, and by the time we get to learning rate 0.99, RMSE is looking pretty good. But as I said,
709:14 - you can try putting in 500 here and it'll take 10 times longer, but that will tell you if learning
709:20 - rate of 0.99 is always a good idea, especially at a high number of, at a, at a very high number of
709:27 - models, and I'm just going to run all of these cells so that we don't have to wait a long time.
709:34 - Okay. Next up, we have this argument called booster. Now I said that gradient boosting machines use
709:42 - decision trees, but instead of using decision trees, XGBoost can also train linear models for each
709:48 - iteration. So the idea is the same. The idea is pretty much the same that you initially guess the
709:56 - average as your prediction P zero, and then you compute the residual. Then instead of training a
710:01 - decision tree to compute the residual, maybe you train a linear regression model. So maybe you,
710:09 - you train a linear regression model that tries to fit the data, and then you compute the residuals
710:14 - from the linear regression model, right? And then you train another linear regression model to do
710:20 - it, and then you train another linear linear regression model to correct the residuals and so
710:24 - on. So everything remains the same. We just switch out the decision tree classifier, the decision
710:28 - tree regressor internally for the linear regression model. And even all of these things like the alpha
710:35 - and everything remains the same. So all the hyper parameters can remain the same. And if you think
710:39 - that there are more linear relationships within the data, then you can just test out linear
710:45 - relationships as well. And seems pretty fine to me. Not, not too bad. 2727 is the
710:51 - output here, the validation RMSE. So that's not bad at all. So maybe you can try experimenting
710:57 - with some other hyper parameters, experiment with the linear and the tree based model and figure
711:02 - out which one works best. Now, what will happen over time is as you train dozens of models or
711:08 - maybe hundreds of models, you will start to get a feel for how all of these hyper parameters interact
711:14 - with each other and which kind of hyper parameters are better suited, which for which kind of

726:07 - And you will see a significant speed up if you use a GPU, sometimes even 10 to a hundred times
726:12 - faster. And GPUs are GPUs or graphic processing units are very efficient at performing matrix
726:20 - computations, which is the kind of computations that XGBoost requires. Okay.
726:26 - And now here, we have not done cross validation. So one thing we could do is we could also do
726:31 - K fold cross validation that would give us five models, and then we could average out the results
726:36 - of those five models. Or another thing that you could do is you could train five models with five
726:41 - different hyper, five different sets of fiber parameters, and then average the results of those
726:45 - models. Yet another thing you could do is you could train the best possible random forest model,
726:50 - the best possible gradient boosting model, the best possible deep learning model, the best possible
726:56 - SVM support vector machine kind of model, and then average all of their results. And one other thing
727:03 - you can do there is instead of just blindly averaging all the results, maybe apply weights
727:08 - to the results of each of the models, give each model a certain weight and optimize the weights.
727:16 - Now, one way you can optimize the weights is by hand tuning each weight. But the other way you
727:20 - can do that is you can do something called stacking, which is train a linear regression model
727:24 - on top of those weights to figure out the best weights to apply to each model, right? How much
727:31 - should, how much weight should be given to the XGB boost regressor? How much we should be given
727:34 - to the random forest, et cetera, et cetera. And those are all the techniques that people apply
727:40 - to get to the top, like the first hundred or 200 submissions would all have several models, as you
727:47 - can see here, that you can even form teams on Kaggle. So on Kaggle, you'll find that these five
727:51 - people would each have trained maybe five models and they would each have worked independently
727:56 - trained five models. And then the team would essentially mean ensembling the results of each
728:02 - of those five models by each of those five people. So you give your results and this person gives
728:07 - their results and this person gives their results and so on. And then they average the results and
728:12 - they simply submit that. And that itself gives them a huge boost because the more different kinds
728:20 - of models, the more different kinds of ideas that you combine, the more the effects of ensembling
728:26 - work or the wisdom of crowd kicks in or the errors cancel out. Okay. So that's making a Kaggle

738:31 - pre-processing steps onto this in simple input before you can make a prediction. So that's all
738:38 - for today. We learned about gradient boosting and gradient boosting is a very simple idea where we
738:44 - first predict the average as a prediction. And then we find the errors that our prediction has made
738:49 - and we train a decision tree to correct the errors. And then we make new predictions using the
738:54 - initial prediction and the predictions of the decision tree scaled down by a learning rate.
738:59 - And that gives us new errors. And then we try to correct those errors with the second decision
739:03 - tree and so on. So we looked at how to download a real world dataset from a Kaggle competition.
739:08 - And we looked at how to perform features with the first decision tree. So we looked at how to
739:12 - perform feature engineering and prepare a dataset for training. This is a very important part. And
739:17 - this is something that you will have to learn with practice by looking at what other people are
739:21 - doing. We looked at training and interpreting a gradient boosting model using XG boost. There's
739:28 - also another library called light GBM, which works exactly the same way, but it has certain
739:34 - optimizations that might be useful for larger datasets. And some of the ways in which it
739:39 - operates, some of the internal implementations are different. Ultimately, both XGB boost and light
739:45 - GBM are implementations of several papers in the space of a tree based learning algorithms
739:52 - and gradient boosting. So check out what the differences are. Then you also have we saw,
740:01 - we also saw how to perform K fold cross validation and how to combine the results of the K folds.
740:07 - We also learned how to configure a gradient boosting model and how to tune hyper parameters
740:13 - of the model, which is essentially by going up and down and figuring out where we are getting the
740:18 - best fit and going with the most impactful hyper parameter first, and then slowly going through
740:24 - all the other parameters. Okay. And that's what machine learning engineers or data scientists
740:32 - and ML practitioners do all day, create new features, tune hyper parameters, and think of ways
740:38 - to just improve the data for the machine learning model. And maybe get the machine learning model
740:43 - to train a bit faster as well. Here are some resources you should check out. There is definitely
740:50 - a lot more about gradient boosting that we've not covered here, but this should serve as a good
740:54 - introduction. The topic for today is unsupervised learning using scikit learn.

743:31 - Now unsupervised machine learning refers to the category of machine learning techniques where
743:36 - models are trained on a dataset without any labels, unlike supervised learning. And you might
743:44 - wonder what exactly are we training for? If there are no labels, if we just have a bunch of data.
743:50 - So unsupervised learning is generally used to discover patterns in data and to reduce high
743:56 - dimensional data to fewer dimensions. And here is how it fits in into the overall machine learning
744:02 - landscape. Of course, you have computer sciences or where artificial intelligence, machine learning
744:08 - and everything that we're doing comes under, but within computer science, you have artificial
744:13 - intelligence, where you have, sometimes you have rule-based systems. Sometimes you have machine
744:16 - learning models, where models are learning things, learning patterns and learning relationships.
744:24 - Now again, machine learning is comprised of unsupervised learning and supervised learning.
744:29 - Supervised learning is where you have labels for your data and unsupervised learning is where you
744:33 - do not have labels. Now, there are also a couple of other categories or overlaps called semi
744:39 - supervised learning and self supervised learning. So we'll not get into that right now, but I
744:43 - encourage you to check this out. And then there is one branch of machine learning deep learning,
744:48 - which we have not talked about in the last few years. And then there is one branch of machine
744:54 - learning in this course, but we have another course on it called deep learning with PyTorch
744:59 - zero two GANs. So I encourage you to check that out sometime later, which kind of cuts across
745:05 - all of these categories. And it's just a new paradigm or a new way of doing machine learning.
745:12 - So encourage checking it out as well. It kind of, it's a sort of a wide reaching approach
745:18 - that applies to various different kinds of problems. And here's what we are studying in
745:27 - this course. We are looking at classical machine learning algorithms as opposed to deep learning.
745:32 - And the reason we're doing that is because a lot of the data that we work with today
745:36 - is tabular data, like 95% of the data that companies deal with this tabular data,
745:42 - Excel sheets, database tables, CSV files, et cetera. And the best known algorithms
745:51 - for tabular data at this point, especially algorithms that can be interpreted and controlled
745:57 - well are classical machine learning algorithms. And we've looked at supervised learning algorithms
746:02 - already things like classification, where we've looked at again, linear regression. We've looked
746:08 - at logistic regression. We've looked at a decision tree classification, gradient boosting based
746:13 - classification and regression, where we try to predict a number. So classification is where we
746:18 - divide observations into different classes and, and predict those classes for new observations.
746:26 - Regression is where we try to predict the continuous value. And today we're looking at
746:30 - unsupervised learning where there is no label for any data and you either try and cluster the data,
746:36 - which is create similar stacks of data, or you try and reduce the dimensionality of,
746:42 - reduce the dimensions of the data. Or sometimes you try and find associations between different
746:48 - data points and use that for doing things like recommendations. And scikit-learn offers this
746:56 - cheat sheet for you to decide which model to pick for a given problem. Now, most of the time you
747:02 - will, if you've done a little bit of machine learning, you will automatically know what
747:06 - models to pick. So this is a very simple or very obvious kind of a tree, but it's still good to
747:12 - see these are the four categories of algorithms available in scikit-learn. So if you are predicting
747:18 - a category and you have some label data, that is when you use classification. But on the other
747:24 - hand, if you're trying to predict a category and you do not have label data, that is when you use
747:29 - clustering, right? So that's one difference between classification and clustering. That's
747:34 - a common confusion in clustering. There are no labels for us to look at. We just want to
747:39 - group whatever data points we have into different clusters. And of course, if you're predicting a
747:44 - quantity, you should be using regression. And if you're just looking at data, if you just want to
747:51 - visualize data or reduce its size, that's when you look at principal component analysis and
747:57 - embedding and things like that. Okay. So let's talk about clustering. Now,
748:07 - as I've said a couple of times already, clustering is the process of grouping objects from a dataset
748:13 - such that the objects in the same group are more similar in some sense
748:19 - to each other than to those in other groups. So that's the definition,
748:24 - the Wikipedia definition for you and scikit-learn offers several clustering algorithms. And in fact,
748:29 - it has an entire section on clustering algorithms that you should check out.
748:36 - So it talks a little bit about the different clustering methods. You can see there are about
748:41 - 10 or more than 10 clustering methods. And it tells you about the use cases for different
748:47 - clustering methods. It tells you about the scalability, how well these methods scale to
748:52 - different kinds of different sizes of data sets and different number of clusters and
748:57 - the parameters that they take. And all of these are fairly different in how they're implemented,
749:03 - but the goal is ultimately the same. The goal is to take some data. For example, here, let's say
749:09 - we just had a bunch of points here where here, this example plots incomes and debt. So this
749:15 - is a scatter plot between incomes of various people and the amount of debt that they have
749:22 - at the moment. So each point, each point represents one person. So these people are people who have
749:28 - high income, but low debt. And these people are people who have low income and low debt.
749:33 - And these people are people who have low income and very high debt, right? So clearly there are
749:38 - three clusters of people here. And typically these clusters don't come predefined. So you
749:42 - would simply have income and debt information. And what you might want to do is identify which
749:48 - cluster a particular person belongs to, or even figure out what the clusters should look like.
749:54 - So that's what clustering is. And that's what we'll try and do today. Given all these points,
750:00 - we will try and figure out what, how many clusters there are in the data and which clusters do each
750:06 - of the points belong to. And potentially if there is a new data point that comes in, which cluster
750:10 - will that data point belong to? Okay. So that's what we'll talk about. Now, why are we interested
750:16 - in clustering in the first place? Here are some real world applications of clustering.
750:21 - One is of course, customer segmentation. Now, suppose you are an insurance company and you're
750:26 - looking at, or you're a bank and you're looking at applications for loans. Then this kind of a
750:33 - cluster analysis is something that you may want to do this plot incomes and debt and see where the
750:37 - person lies, which cluster the line. And you may have a different set of operating rules
750:42 - for high income, low debt people, low income, low debt, and high low income, high debt people.
750:48 - And then you may just want to just to simplify decision-making instead of each time having to
750:52 - look at both variables, you can simply feed the variables into a computer algorithm, get back
750:57 - a category for them and use that category to make decisions for them. Right.
751:04 - So often the classes in several classification problems are obtained in the first place through
751:12 - clustering processes, especially when you're looking at things like low risk, medium risk,
751:17 - high risk, et cetera. Then product recommendation is another important application of clustering
751:28 - where if you can identify clusters of people who like a particular product, then you can recommend
751:35 - that same product to people who have similar behaviors. Feature engineering is yet another
751:44 - application. What you could do is you could perform some clustering on your data, and then
751:49 - you could actually take the cluster number and add it to your data, your training data as a
751:53 - categorical column, and it's possible that adding that categorical column may improve the
751:58 - training of a decision tree or a gradient boosting tree. Then you have anomaly or fraud
752:07 - detection. Now, of course, if you have, if you plot again, let's say you have a bunch of credit
752:14 - card transactions and then you cluster credit card transactions, you will notice that fraudulent
752:19 - transactions stand out. Maybe there are certain credit cards that make a lot of transactions.
752:23 - So they don't fall within the regular cluster. They fall within the anomalous cluster. And that
752:28 - can be used to then detect that for this kind of a fraudulent behavior, what is the activity? How
752:33 - do you deal with the, how do you deal with the problem? Right. Another use of clustering called
752:39 - hierarchical clustering specifically is what taxonomy creation. Now you know that there are
752:44 - several hierarchical divisions in biology between first you have, of course, the animals and plants
752:52 - and then between plants, you have a bunch of different families and then in each family, a bunch
752:58 - of different species and so on. Right. So that kind of a hierarchy is created using clustering
753:03 - where you take a bunch of different attributes, like what kind of reproduce reproduction of
753:08 - particular animal has, and whether they, what kind of teeth they have, what kind of weight they have,
753:14 - where do they live and things like that. And use that to create clusters and create families of
753:19 - related animals. And then related families get grouped into related kingdoms and so on.
753:28 - So those are some applications of clustering and we will use the Iris flower dataset to study
