756:11 - how do you train a computer to figure out these clusters, given just these four measurements,
756:18 - sepal length, sepal width, petal length and petal width. Okay. So as I've said, we are going to
756:24 - attempt to cluster observations using numeric columns in the data. So I'm going to pull out a
756:29 - list of numeric columns and just take the data from the numeric columns into this variable X.
756:34 - And X is typically used to represent the input into a machine learning algorithm. Okay. So
756:40 - there's just this X and there's no Y here. So the first clustering algorithm we'll talk about is
756:46 - key means clustering. And the key means clustering algorithm attempts to classify objects into a
756:53 - predetermined number of clusters. So you have to decide the K in K means is the number of clusters
756:59 - that you wanted the data to have. So in this case, let's say we have some intuition that maybe by
757:05 - looking at some scatter plots, we feel like maybe there are two, maybe there are three clusters. So
757:10 - we can give an input number of clusters to the K means algorithm, and then it will do something
757:16 - and it'll take this data. Let's say we give the input of K S three. It's going to then figure out
757:25 - it's going to then figure out three central points for each cluster. So here is the central point for
757:30 - cluster number one, here is the central point for cluster number two, and here is the center point for
757:35 - cluster number three. And then each of these central points are also called centroids. And then each
757:41 - object or each observation in the data set is going to be classified as belonging to the cluster
757:48 - represented by the closest center point. Okay. So that's why you can see that all these belong to
757:53 - this cluster. All these are set to belong to this cluster and all these are set to belong to this
757:57 - cluster. And of course, now, if you go out and make a new observation, maybe you get another
758:03 - flower, measure it, staple petal and all, and put in this, put in the observations here. And if the
758:09 - flower lies somewhere here, then it will belong to the cluster of the center center that it is
758:15 - closest to. Okay. So that's the K means algorithm. Now the question you may have is how exactly are
758:21 - the centers determined? So let's talk about that. And maybe let's take an example. Let's take maybe
758:28 - a one dimensional example initially, and then we will expand that to two dimensions and go from
758:34 - there. So let me draw a line here. And let's say this line represents the petal length. Okay. And
758:45 - I'm just going to take petal lengths from, let's say zero to five. All the values seem to have petal
758:52 - lengths between zero to five. And let me take about 12 flowers. Let me, let's not consider all 150.
758:58 - And let's say you have these four flowers. They have a fairly low petal length. Okay. Very close
759:07 - to one, maybe. And then you have another four flowers. They have a medium petal length, and then
759:15 - you have yet another four flowers. They have a high petal length. Okay. Now, visually, just by
759:23 - looking at, but by looking at just the petal length, you can kind of cluster. You can kind of
759:29 - visually say that, okay, this is one cluster and this is one cluster. And this is one cluster.
759:33 - Right now, the challenge is how do you train a computer to figure out these clusters? So here's
759:38 - what we are going to do first. We determine in K means algorithm. What is the value of K? So let's
759:45 - say I said the value of K to three. Okay. For some reason, I have some intuition that maybe the
759:49 - value of K is three. And we'll talk about how to pick the right value of K later. Then what we do
759:55 - is we pick three random points. So let's pick three random points. Maybe I pick this one. That's a
760:03 - random point. Sure. I pick this one. Okay. That's a random point. And then I pick this. All right.
760:08 - That's a random point. So now we are going to treat these three random points as the centers of
760:15 - our clusters. So now this becomes the center of cluster one. This becomes the center of cluster
760:20 - two, and this becomes a center of cluster three. Okay. Great. So here's what we've done so far.
760:28 - Pick K random objects as the initial cluster centers. And then the next step is to classify
760:34 - each object into the cluster whose center is closest to that, to that object. So now let's start.
760:41 - Let's try and classify this point or this flower. Now, which, which cluster is this flower closest
760:48 - to, well, you can clearly see that it is closest to the center of its closest to center one. So
760:53 - this becomes one and then check the next one. And this is also closest to one. So this also gets
761:00 - assigned the cluster one, and this also gets assigned the cluster one. This also gets assigned
761:04 - the cluster one. I would say that even this is closer to one than two. So this also gets assigned
761:09 - the question cluster one. And of course, this point is already in cluster one. Then you have this one
761:14 - cluster two, and this also, this gets assigned cluster two. This one, I would say is closer to
761:20 - three. So this gets assigned to cluster three, and this is cluster three, and this is cluster three
761:24 - as well. Okay. Okay. So now we have a clustering, but definitely this clustering is not that great.
761:31 - You can clearly see that these two should rather belong to the class two. So here is where we do
761:36 - the next interesting thing. Once we have determined the cluster. So like this is cluster one. And
761:43 - then this is cluster two, and then this is cluster three. We then for each cluster of classified
761:52 - objects, compute the centroid or simply the mean. The centroid is nothing but the mean right now.
761:57 - We're looking at one dimension so that the centroid is simply the mean. And we'll talk about two
762:01 - dimensions, but here's what we do then. We basically take all these values. So this is like,
762:07 - this is about a 0.7. This is about one. This is about 1.2, et cetera, et cetera. And then we take
762:12 - that average. So if you take the average of all these values and let me draw another line here.
762:19 - So if we take the average of all these values, the average of all these values would be
762:23 - somewhere around here, right. And then we take the average of all these values in the cluster
762:30 - two, and that would be somewhere around here. And then we take the average of all these values and
762:35 - that would be somewhere around here. Now, here's the interesting thing. Once we've taken the
762:40 - averages, we make these the new centers of the cluster.
762:44 - So this becomes the center for cluster one, this becomes a center for cluster two.
762:48 - This becomes a center for cluster three.
762:50 - Okay.
762:51 - And now you can see things are already starting to look better.
762:58 - Let's just put back these points here.
763:04 - Okay.
763:04 - So now what, what we've done is we have taken each cluster that we created using
763:08 - randomly big points, and we took the averages of those clusters and said, these
763:12 - are the new cluster centers.
763:15 - Now using these new cluster centers, we reclassify the points.
763:19 - Okay.
763:20 - So that's what we're doing.
763:21 - We are now going to reclassify each object using the centroids as the cluster centers.
763:27 - So now this point is given the class one.
763:31 - This point goes to class one, and this one goes to class one.
763:34 - This one goes to class one too.
763:36 - Now this one goes to class two, class two, class two, and class two, and you have
763:39 - class three, class three, class three, and class three.
763:43 - Okay.
763:44 - And that's it.
763:45 - So just like that.
763:46 - Now we have ended up with cluster one, cluster two, cluster three.
763:54 - Okay.
763:55 - So that is exactly how K means works.
763:57 - But one last issue here, suppose the points that we had picked out in our
764:03 - random selection initially were very bad points.
764:06 - Let's say they were somewhere here.
764:08 - Let's say we had picked this, this, and this as the points, what would happen then?
764:13 - Well, what would happen is all of these would belong to the first cluster, and
764:17 - this would be the second cluster.
764:18 - And this would be the third cluster and the average would lie somewhere here.
764:22 - So your first cluster would be here and the second and third would be here.
764:27 - So you would still end up, even after performing the entire average and
764:31 - reclassifying the points, you would still end up with this huge cluster.
764:34 - Maybe this, maybe these might get excluded.
764:37 - Maybe these might go into two, but you would still get both of these
764:40 - sections into one big cluster, right?
764:42 - So K means does not always work perfectly, right?
764:46 - It depends on that random selection.
764:49 - So that's where what we do is we repeat these steps, steps one to six, a few more
764:53 - times to pick the cluster centers with the lowest total variance.
764:57 - And we'll talk about that last piece again.
764:59 - So here's what we do just to recap, pick K random objects as the initial
765:03 - cluster centers, like this one, this one, and this one classify each object into the
765:09 - cluster whose center is the closest to the point.
765:12 - So now we've classified each object based on the randomly picked clusters.
765:19 - Then compute the centroid or the mean for each set of clusters.
765:23 - So here are the central layer here and here, the central layer here, the central layer.
765:27 - Then use the centroids as the new cluster centers and re-classify all the points.
765:34 - Okay.
765:35 - Then, so you do that and you keep track of those centroids and then you do the whole
765:40 - process again, K random objects, classify, compute the centroid reclassify, keep that
765:47 - option around and keep doing that over and over and over multiple times.
765:52 - And let's say you do it about 10 times or 20 times and I'll do that again.
765:55 - 10 times or 20 times, and out of the 20, you simply pick the one where you got the
766:00 - best lowest total variance.
766:03 - So what do we mean by the total variance?
766:06 - Well, here's how you can compare two sets of clusters, right?
766:09 - So, and I'm not going to draw the points anymore, but let's say you have one set
766:16 - of clusters that looks like this and you have one set of clusters again through
766:21 - K means that looks like this.
766:24 - Okay.
766:24 - So what you do is you compute the variance.
766:26 - Now you have a bunch of points in this cluster, right?
766:29 - So these points are nothing but values on the line.
766:32 - Remember this is better length.
766:34 - So whenever you have points, you can compute the variance.
766:36 - A variance is simply the measure of spread, how much spread is there in this data?
766:41 - And then you compute the variance of these points, the points that you have here, and
766:44 - you compute the variance of these points and add up these values.
766:47 - Okay.
766:49 - So here, this is like a relatively low variance, right?
766:51 - This is, let's say this variance is 0.7.
766:54 - This variance is 0.2 and this variance is 0.5.

767:11 - The variance here is about 0.1, let's say, right?
767:14 - So the total variance here in this case is about 2.6 and the total variance
767:18 - here 0.7 plus 0.2 plus 0.5 is going to be about 1.4.
767:23 - Okay.
767:24 - And the variance is simply the square of the standard deviation.
767:27 - If you remember from basic statistics, right?
767:31 - So what do we mean when we have a low total variance?
767:34 - When we have a low total variance, what we are essentially expressing is that all the
767:38 - points in every cluster are very close together.
767:41 - And when we have a high total variance, what we are expressing there is that there are
767:45 - points in a certain cluster or in certain clusters that are very far away from each other.
767:50 - So as we try all of these random experiments, we simply pick the cluster centers, which
767:55 - minimize the total variance and with enough random experiments, you can almost be sure
768:02 - that you will get to a point which is very close to the optimal solution.
768:07 - Okay.
You may not get the best possible division.
768:10 - And sometimes even when you run K means multiple times, you may get different
768:14 - cluster divisions, depending on the kind of data, but once you run it enough time, you
768:19 - will get to a pretty good place.
768:21 - Uh, and that's basically the, that's basically how K means algorithm works.

778:26 - Okay.
778:29 - And I mentioned to you about the goodness of the fit.
778:32 - So the total variance of these three clusters, what do we do is we take the variance of all these points and we take the variance of all these points and variance of all these points across all four dimensions.
778:45 - And then we average out the variance.
778:48 - And then we add up, we average out the variance across all dimensions and then we add up the variances for the individual clusters.
778:54 - So the total variances of all the individual clusters is called the inertia.
779:03 - So remember variance tells you the amount of spread of the data.
779:08 - So the less the spread within the clusters, the better is the goodness of the fit.
779:17 - Right.

780:55 - Now in most real world scenarios, there is no predetermined number of clusters.

781:13 - And for each, each value of K, which is the number of clusters, train the model and compute the inertia of the model, the total overall variance, and then plot the inertia.

782:31 - shape. So in a lot of cases, what you will end up with is a graph that looks like this here, you have the value of K, the number of clusters here, you have the inertia, and this is what the graph will typically look like.
782:48 - So you want to pick either this point or this point as the number of clusters.
782:53 - Okay.
782:53 - So I can't really say that you need three clusters of five clusters, but you draw this graph, and then based on this, you figure out where the elbow point is.
783:06 - So that's a K means algorithm.
783:08 - And if you remember the algorithm, one thing we said was that we want to randomly test a lot of these things each time.
783:16 - So remember we said that you pick K points and then you use them as cluster centers, classify all the points, compute the centroids, then reclassify all the points, and then repeat that process randomly many times that may not be a good idea because if you are working with a really large data set, because it can get really, really slow.
783:36 - So that's where you have a variation of K means called the mini batch K means algorithm. Now, in the mini batch K means algorithm, instead of taking all the points, instead of classifying all the points, you pick just a fixed number of points and the fixed number is called the mini batch size.
783:55 - So you just pick a fixed number of points, compute their centroids and compute the cluster centers for those, let's say those hundred points. And then you pick a next hundred points and for those next hundred points, you start by using the previous centroids, rather than using the, rather than using a random K points, you start by using the previous K centroids, okay?
784:20 - So there's a small change that you apply here, that each time you pick about a hundred or 200 or 300 points, whatever is the batch size, and use that to update the centroids or upgrade the cluster centers from the previous batch.
784:33 - And again, this is the point where you can now go through and read about mini batch K means clustering and figure out how that is different from the traditional K means clustering that we've just done.
784:47 - Okay. So here's a dataset.
784:49 - This is, this is called a mall's customer dataset, where you have information about a bunch of customers who visited a mall and you can try performing K means clustering by downloading this dataset and then using the K means class from scikit-learn.
785:04 - And then maybe you can also study the segments.
785:06 - Once you have these cluster segments, use them as a new column in the data and then do some more analysis.
785:11 - Maybe look for each cluster, study whether, what the spends look like, study what the age group looks like and things like that.
785:19 - Okay. So do check this out and you can also try and compare K means clustering with mini batch K means clustering using this dataset.
785:29 - One other thing you may try out is you can also configure how many random picks you want.
785:36 - The K means algorithm to take. So by default, we say up to 300 iterations, like maximum iterations is simply the number of times this whole experiment should be repeated of trying to find a good cluster centers and you can set maximum iterations to any value you want.
785:56 - So see what kind of impact that has on the quality of clusters.
786:01 - Okay.
786:01 - All right. So that's the key means clustering algorithm. So let's talk about a couple more clustering algorithms, very quickly, very briefly, the next one, again, a very common one is called DB scan, which is short for density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise.
786:20 - So that's a mouthful, but it's actually not that complicated a technique. It's again, fairly straightforward. If once you understand the basic steps involved, and it uses the density of points in a region to form clusters.
786:35 - So it has two main parameters. It has a parameter called epsilon, which we'll see in a moment, what that means. And another parameter called min samples and using these parameters, epsilon and min samples, it classifies each point as a core point, a reachable point, or a noise point or outlier.
786:56 - Okay. So let's try and understand how DB scan works by looking at this example for a moment. Now, forget all this, all these circles and all these arrows and everything. And even all the colors, just imagine you have these points, you have this point, maybe let's try and replicate this.
787:16 - So you have a point here, here, here. Okay. Not really. Okay.
787:46 - Okay. So these are the points we have. And here is how came me. Here's how DB scan works. First, you set an epsilon. Let's say we send we, and of course, all of this is on a coordinate plane. Let's say we're still talking about petal length.
788:13 - And petal width in two dimensions. Let's say we said epsilon to 0.5. And let's say we said min samples to four. Okay. Now, look at this point.
788:29 - And this point is, let's just consider this point and you can start at any point, take this point and around this point, draw a circle with the radius epsilon. So let me just, I think this would be about 0.5.
788:42 - So let me just draw the circle here with the radius epsilon. Okay. So we draw a circle with the radius epsilon around the point. Then we check if in that circle, you have at least four points.
789:00 - So if you have at least four points in the circle, which we do one, two, three, and four, including the point itself, as you can see here, one, two, three, and four around the point.
789:08 - So if you have at least four points, then we say that this is a core point. So this is a core point. So let me just put it in dark. All the core points. I'm going to make them dark.
789:23 - So now we've classified a core point and then everything else that is connected to the core point is now part of the same cluster. Okay.
789:32 - So these three points are part of the same cluster, then let's go to this point and across this point, let's also draw the circle of size epsilon.
789:42 - And this is what it looks like. And now once again, you have one, two, three, and four. So then this point is also a core point. Okay.
789:51 - So this point is a core point. And then this point is within 0.5 of the core point. So this is now, this point now belongs to the same cluster.
789:57 - Okay. Then let's do this one again. If you draw a circle around this one, you will notice that four points lie here. So this is also a core point.
790:07 - So these are all part of the same cluster. And then this one also turns out to be a core point. You can verify it will have four points around it.
790:15 - And this will be connected to this. And this will also be a core point. It will have all these inside. This will also be core point.
790:21 - So this like this, you continue creating connecting core points and there will be some points now, which will not be core like this point right here.
790:30 - This is not a core point. This is a point which is connected to a core point. It is, it lies within the circle of a core point, but it by itself, like if I just draw the circle around this point, it does not contain the mean sample values.
790:45 - So this is called an edge point. Yeah. So this is called, sorry, this is called a reachable point.
790:55 - So this is kind of the edge of the cluster, right? This is not a core point. This is not connected to three other points in that circle, but it is still part of an existing cluster.
791:04 - And similarly, this one is well, like if you draw the circle around this, the circle would look something like this.
791:09 - So this is not a core point, but this is still a connected edge point. So this way, we have now identified this one cluster of points.
791:18 - Okay. And we're done with all these. And let's say there is another cluster of points here where you have like these four core points.
791:29 - This is all connected to each other. And then these are connected to this.
791:34 - So you have two edge points here in this cluster as well. And then you have four core points in this cluster.
791:38 - So this becomes another cluster right here. This point, however, it is neither core, nor is it an edge point.
791:49 - It does not have four things around it or three things around it close by, and it is not connected to a core point.
791:56 - So this is called an outlier. Okay. And it's, or sometimes it's also called the noise point.
792:04 - So that's what these triangles and these colors and these lines represent.
792:08 - You have core points, which are all, which have within their epsilon radius, min sample numbers of observations.
792:15 - You have these noise point noise points, which are not connected with any points.
792:19 - And then you have these edge points or reachable points, which are connected to core points, but themselves are not core.
792:27 - So that's what these DB scan does. And again, the way to implement or use DB scan is simply to import from a scale under cluster DB scan.
792:36 - And you can see here in the signature, you can configure epsilon, you can configure min samples and you can configure how the distance is calculated.
792:44 - And by default, it is Euclidean. I was showing you in two dimensions, but because we have four dimensions, so in four dimensions, it's going to take the square root of four dimensions.
792:55 - The square root of first dimension difference squared plus second dimension difference squared plus third dimension difference squared, plus so on the extension of Pythagoras theorem.
793:05 - And then you can also specify how to go about, and you can also specify some other things.
793:11 - So I'll let you look up the remaining arguments here, but that's a basic idea.
793:16 - And then you do a DB scan for the model.
793:20 - So then you, you instantiate the DB scan model with the epsilon and with the min samples, and then you fit it to the data.
793:28 - Now, here's one thing in DB scan, there is no prediction step because remember the definition of a core point depends on certain points being there in the dataset.
793:39 - So in K means you try and figure out the center of a cluster, but in DB scan, there is no center of a cluster.
793:46 - The cluster is defined by the connections between points. So you cannot use DB scan to classify new inputs, to classify new observations.
793:55 - DB scans simply assigns labels to all the existing observations.
793:59 - So you can just check model dot labels, and it will automatically just tell you that for the inputs that were given, when we perform the DB scan algorithm on all of them, because all of them need to be considered to perform all of them.
794:15 - To perform the DB scan algorithm, the DB scan clustering, these are the labels that got assigned.
794:23 - So this, all of these got assigned zero and then all of these got assigned one.
794:28 - And then you can also check which ones are core points and which ones are, which ones are epsilon.
794:35 - So in our epsilon, which ones are reachable points and which ones are noise points.
794:42 - I think you can do something like this.
794:46 - Yeah, we can probably just, so a good way to check all the attributes on all the properties that you have on a particular model, all the methods you have is by using DIR.
794:56 - So yeah, I think you have these core sample indices. So this will tell you the core sample indices.
795:08 - And you can see here that these are all the core points. So not every point yet here, it seems like most points are core points.
795:18 - And maybe we can try changing the epsilon value. Maybe we can reduce the epsilon or increase the epsilon.
795:23 - And that will maybe tell us that not all points are core points.
795:28 - So let me do a scatter plot here.
795:30 - And now I'm using the sample length, the petal length, and instead of the, as a hue, I'm using the model dot labels.
795:36 - So you can see that only two classes were detected here, zero and one.
795:43 - And maybe if we change the value of epsilon, maybe if we change the value of min samples, that number might change.
795:49 - So that's an exercise for you try changing the value of epsilon, which is the circle,
795:55 - the size of the circle that is drawn around each point and try changing the value of min samples,
796:00 - which decides when something is treated as a core point and try wild ranges,
796:05 - maybe try close to zero, maybe try close to like a hundred.
796:08 - Epsilon does not have to be between zero or one. It can be very large.
796:12 - And similarly for min samples, maybe try value one, maybe try value hundred experiment
796:17 - and try and figure out how each of these hyper parameters affect the clustering.
796:23 - Okay. And see if you can get to the desired clustering, which is
796:26 - ideally cluster these points according to the species that the flowers belong to. Okay.
796:32 - So that's the DB scan algorithm.
796:34 - And the natural question you may have is when should you use DB scan and when should you use
796:39 - key means? So here's the main difference between DB scan and key means key means uses the concept
796:47 - of a cluster center, and it uses distance from a cluster center to define the cluster DB scan.
796:54 - On the other hand, uses a nearness between the points themselves to create a cluster.
797:00 - So here is an example of key means where if you have data like this, again, let's say this is X
797:05 - axis and Y axis. Now, visually, you can clearly tell that this is the right clustering, you know,
797:11 - the outer points, these are all connected. It seems to be one cluster and the inner points
797:16 - on collected on all connected seem to be another cluster, but DB scan can do this because it is
797:22 - concerned with the nearness between points. But key means actually cannot identify these two
797:27 - clusters, because if you said this as a cluster center, then any cluster that includes this point
797:36 - would also need to include all of these points because these points are closer to the center than
797:41 - this point, right? So there's no way you can create a cluster using key means of these, of these outer
797:46 - rings. On the other hand, this is what K means clustering would look like. Maybe you'll end up
797:51 - with one centroid here and one centroid here. So half the points will go here and half the points
797:55 - will go here. Here is another example. You have these two horseshoe shapes and this again,
798:03 - DB scan is able to detect them, but K means is not on the other. And then there are a few more
798:09 - examples for you to check out. Now, one other thing about DB scan and K means is that in K means
798:15 - you can specify how many clusters you want, but in DB scan, it will figure out on its own and you
798:21 - can only change the values of epsilon and min samples to maybe try and indirectly affect the
798:26 - number of clusters that get created. So that's the DB scan algorithm. So just keep in mind whenever
798:32 - you want to detect these patterns, which are more concerned with the nearness of the points
798:38 - themselves, DB scan may make more sense, but if you want a distance based clustering technique,
798:45 - then you use K means. One more thing is you can classify new points into clusters using K means,
798:52 - but you cannot use DB scan to classify new points. You would have to run the entire scan again,
798:56 - because it's possible that by the introduction of a new point, two clusters may join together or
799:03 - change in some fashion. Okay. So,
799:05 - one last clustering technique I want to talk about is hierarchical clustering. And as the name
799:11 - suggests, it creates a hierarchy or a tree of clusters and not just a bunch of different
799:18 - clusters. So what does that mean? That means that as you can see in this, as you can see here in
799:27 - this animation, we have a bunch of points. And first we take the two closest points and we
799:36 - combine those two closest points into a cluster. Then we say we combine the next two closest
799:44 - points, which in this case turns out to be cluster, the cluster point, and then another point and
799:49 - combine this, combine them. And then in this way, we combine the two closest points. And then
799:55 - in this way, we create this tree of clusters. So at the bottom of the tree are these individual
800:00 - points. And above you have these cluster of two points. And sometimes above these, you have
800:05 - clusters of three or four points. And above these, you have clusters of cluster of cluster of
800:10 - points and things like that. And this is the kind of thing that can typically be used to generate
800:15 - a taxonomy, for example, like if you have observations about many different animals, many
800:23 - different types of animals, you have a bunch of observations and you start performing clustering.
800:28 - You may realize that there are very few, very close relationships between humans and chimpanzees.
800:34 - And then between humans, chimpanzees, and bonobos, there is another relationship. So that is what is
800:39 - captured by this point. And then of course, between these, between this family and between,
800:47 - let's say mammals, there is a relationship that is captured by this. And then here on the other
800:52 - hand, you have a relationship between plants. And finally, at the top, you have like a single
800:57 - cluster. Okay. And this is how hierarchical clustering works. You first mark each point in
801:06 - the dataset as a cluster by itself. Like all of these points, P zero to P five are clusters in
801:12 - the dataset. Then you pick the two closest cluster centers, like here, you can see you pick the two
801:19 - closest ones and treat them as a single cluster. You pick the two closest cluster centers without
801:28 - a parent and combine them into a new cluster. Now the new cluster is the parent cluster of the two
801:35 - clusters and its center is the mean of all the points in the cluster. Then you repeat the step
801:42 - two, which is you pick the two closest cluster centers in the dataset without a parent. So this
801:47 - time you could be combining a cluster center from a cluster and a leaf. And that could then become
801:54 - their parent cluster. And then you pick the two closest and you keep picking the closest cluster
801:59 - centers each time that do not already have a parent. And that's how you get to the top level.
802:03 - Okay. And this structure that you end up with is often called a dendogram. So yeah, that's what
802:11 - this will look like. And these are all the cluster points, the cluster centers here. Now for each
802:20 - type of clustering, I've also included a video that you can watch for a detailed visual explanation.
802:25 - If you're willing to just get deeper and maybe follow along on your own and scikit-learn allows
802:31 - you to implement hierarchical clustering. So you can try and implement it for the iris dataset.
802:36 - So let you figure it out. Okay. So we've looked at three types of clustering. Now we have looked
802:41 - at K means clustering. We have looked at DB scan, and then we've looked at hierarchical clustering.
802:48 - There are several other clustering algorithms in scikit-learn. So you can check them out too.
802:53 - Here you have about 10 or so clustering algorithms, so you can check out all of them. Okay.
803:04 - So with that, we will close our discussion on clustering by no means exhaustive, but I hope
803:09 - you've gotten a sense of what clustering is, how couple of common clustering algorithms work and
803:17 - how to use them. Let's talk about dimensionality reduction in machine learning problems. We often
803:25 - encounter datasets with a very large number of dimensions. And by dimensions, we mean the number
803:29 - of features, a number of columns. Sometimes they may go into dozens. Sometimes they may go into
803:36 - hundreds, and especially when you're dealing with sensor data, for example, like let's say you're
803:42 - trying to train a machine learning algorithm, which based on the, based on the data of an
803:47 - actual flight, like a flight that started from a certain point and ended at a certain point.
803:52 - Now flights have hundreds of sensors or sometimes thousands of sensors, like same kinds of sensors
803:57 - at every step or different places on the flight. And if you look, if you just collect the information
804:02 - from all of these sensors, you will end up with thousands of columns. And that may be a very
804:10 - inefficient thing to analyze and a very inefficient thing to even train machine learning models on
804:15 - because more columns means more data, which means more processing, which requires more resources
804:21 - and more time. And it may just significantly slow down what you're trying to do. So one thing we
804:26 - typically have learned in the past is to just pick a few useful columns and throw out the
804:31 - rest of the columns so that we can quickly train a model. But what if you didn't have to throw
804:36 - away most of the information? What if you could reduce the number of dimensions from let's say
804:41 - a hundred to five without losing a lot of information? What if you could do that? And
804:52 - that is what dimensionality reduction and manifold learning are all about. So what are the
804:57 - applications of dimensionality reduction reducing the size of data without the loss of information?
805:03 - So let's say you have a certain dataset here, which has, let's say 200 columns. Okay. What if
805:16 - you could reduce those 200 columns of data to just five columns without losing information as
805:27 - much information, right? What if it, this could still retain 95% of the information. And we'll
805:33 - talk about what we are saying, what we mean by information retention, but what if you could do
805:38 - that then, then you can clearly see already that this, anything that you do on this model or on
805:45 - this dataset is going to be 40 times faster. So are you willing to trade maybe 5% of the information
805:51 - for 40 times the speed? Probably. Yes. Right. So that's one reason to do dimensionality reduction.
805:59 - And that will then allow you to train machine learning models efficiently. But yet another
806:04 - very important application of dimensionality reduction is visualizing high dimensional data
806:11 - in two or three dimensions. Now, of course, as humans, we can only visualize in three dimensions,
806:16 - but even three dimensions can get a little bit tricky. Like 3d scatter plots are very hard to
806:20 - read. So we are really the most comfortable, at least right now, while looking at screens,
806:26 - we are most comfortable looking at data in two dimensions. So even right now with the iris
806:31 - dataset, we've seen the problem that we have four dimensions, but we can only really visualize two
806:36 - dimensions at a time. All right. So visualizing high dimensional data in two to three dimensions
806:41 - is also an application of dimensionality reduction. So let's talk about, let's talk about, let's talk
806:47 - about a couple of techniques for dimensionality reduction. The first one is principle component
806:52 - analysis. Principle component analysis is a dimensionality reduction technique that uses
806:58 - linear projections. And we talk about what linear projections mean of data.
807:03 - To reduce dimensions, while still attempting to maximize the variance of the data in the projection.
807:11 - So that's what this is about. It's about projecting data. And this is what PCL looks like while still
807:19 - maintaining as much of the variance as possible. So let's say you have this data. Let's say X1
807:24 - represents petal length and X2 represents petal width. And then you have all these points ignore
807:29 - the line for a moment. Now, instead of having X1 and X2, if we could simply draw this line, and if
807:37 - we could just draw this line, and then maybe on this line, we could set this as a zero point. And
807:43 - then we could simply draw these project these points onto the line. So just see how far away
807:47 - they are from the zero point. Let's say we said this as a zero point. And then we simply give this
807:52 - point, the value minus one, this point would be minus 1.8. This point wouldn't be minus 2.2.
807:57 - Minus 1.8. This point wouldn't be minus two. This point would be minus 2.7. And this point would be
808:03 - maybe 0.1. This would be 0.3. This would be one. This would be two. This would be 2.3, 2.4. Okay.
808:10 - So now we have gone from taking this data in two dimensions to this data in one dimension. Okay.
808:16 - So how do we do that? Let's take a look. So let's say we have some data. Let me look at
808:23 - petal length and petal width, just two dimensions right now. So we have 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4,
808:34 - and so on. And for each one, we have some petal length, petal width, petal length, petal width,
808:38 - petal length, petal width, and so on. Now we take that and we plot it here.
808:43 - So we plot these points here. Maybe it looks a bit like this.
808:58 - Okay. There are more points here. So this is what it looks like. Now what we would rather want to
809:05 - see is maybe we just want to see one value, right? And we, we don't know what this is called. Let's
809:11 - just call this PC one. Okay. We just want to see one value. So for one, two, three, four, five,
809:17 - we just want to see one value here instead of these two columns of data. And if we can do go
809:21 - from two columns to one column, then we should be able to go from three columns to one column
809:25 - or three columns, two columns or 200 columns to five columns. So the idea remains the same.
809:31 - So how do we do that? Well, the first thing we do is we shift our axes a little bit
809:37 - to center these points. So what do I mean by shifting the axes? Well, we take this
809:43 - x-axis and we, the y-axis, and then we move it here somewhere here.
809:49 - What exactly is meant by moving the axis? Well, in the new axis, you will notice that the x values
809:56 - of these points have changed. So we are calculating the X, the mean X coordinate of all these points
810:03 - and simply subtracting the mean from all these points. Similarly, we take the X-axis and move
810:09 - it around and moving the X-axis means subtracting the mean of the Y coordinate. Okay. So what we
810:15 - do for each point is we take the point P and we subtract from it the average. So let's say
810:26 - P has an X and a Y and the mean also has an X and a Y. So the X subtracts from the average
810:32 - X, the Y subtracts from the average Y. So that is going to center the points. Okay. Some of the
810:38 - points will now have negative values. Some of the points will now have positive values. Then we
810:43 - try out a candidate line. So we try a candidate line. Okay. This looks like a candidate line
810:52 - on which to project. And then we project all of these points on the candidate line. So we project
810:58 - project, project, project, project, project, project. Okay. So now we have projected all of these on
811:05 - the candidate line. Now, once we've projected things on the candidate line, let me for a moment,
811:13 - just get rid of the X and Y coordinates. Now that we know that they're centered, let me just move
811:17 - them away. Yeah. So now that we have all these projections and we know that this is a zero point,
811:23 - this is a zero point, we can see that. Okay. This is the, this point can now be represented by this
811:30 - point that's perpendicular. And this point can now be represented by this point. And this point
811:35 - can now be represented by this one. So for each one, if this is zero and this is one, and this is
811:39 - two, and this is three on this new line, we can now represent each point using a single number,
811:44 - which is it's the distance of its projection from the zero point on this projected line.
811:50 - Okay. So we can now start filling in these values. So the distance of 0.1 distance of 0.2
811:56 - distance of 0.3 and distance of 0.4. So we start filling in these values. Okay. All right. So now
812:02 - we already have this, we have now already reduced from two coordinates to one coordinate, but we
812:08 - want it to retain as much of the information or as much of the variety from these two coordinates
812:14 - as possible. So this is where what we try and do is we try and maximize D one square plus D two
812:23 - square plus D three square plus so on. Okay. So D one square plus D two square, but D three square
812:31 - is basically the, now, if you like, keep in mind that we have subtracted the mean, and then now we
812:37 - are squaring the distances and things like that. So it ultimately turns out to be the variance sigma.
812:42 - So what we want to do is we want to try different options for this line. So let's say we want to
812:46 - take the same line. Okay. It's going to be hard to select this line, but we want to take the same
812:55 - line and we want to rotate this line. So you want to rotate this line and each time as we rotate,
813:02 - all the D's will change because all the perpendiculars will change. And we pick the line, the rotated
813:08 - line for which the sum of squares of the D's, the sum of squares of all these values is the highest.
813:15 - All right. So just to maybe clean this up a little bit, what we're trying to say is once we have the
813:24 - centered points, you can see here, if I pick this line, all of the projections are very close to zero.
813:33 - So if all of the projections are very close to zero, then that means most of the information
813:38 - is lost because all the values, all the D1, D2, D3, D4, all of them are very close to zero.
813:44 - On the other hand, on the other hand, if we pick a line that goes like this,
813:56 - you can see that the projections are quite far away. So we are capturing the spread of the data
814:01 - very nicely for a nice fitting line. And we are not capturing the spread of the data very nicely
814:05 - for an ill-fitting line. So that's what PCA tries and figures out. Okay. So it figures out one,
814:11 - and this is from going from two dimensions to one dimension. Here is an example of going from
814:17 - three dimensions to two dimensions. So now here we have feature one, feature two, feature three,
814:21 - ignore the word gene here, and then you have points. So what we try and do is we first find
814:26 - PC one, we find a line along which we can project all the points, the best possible line, which
814:31 - maintains the highest variance. Then PC two is a line which is perpendicular to the first line.
814:38 - Now, remember we're in three dimensions here. So there are, there are an infinite number of lines
814:43 - that are perpendicular to the first line PC one. So again, we pick the line which maximizes the
814:49 - variance of the points when the points are projected on PC two. So for three dimensions,
814:56 - you can have PC one, PC two. And then when you go to four dimensions, you can have PC one,
815:01 - PC two, PC three. When you go to five dimensions, you can have PC one, PC two, PC three, PC four.
815:06 - And then what you can do is like, if you have 200 dimensions, you can just choose the five
815:11 - most relevant axes of variance, right? And remember each of these are highest variants,
815:18 - preserving possible lines. So let's say you have 200 dimensions. You can do a principle component
815:25 - analysis and you can reduce them down to the five dimensions along which the variance of the data is
815:30 - preserved as much as possible. So that's principle component analysis for you. And once again,
815:38 - how do you do principle component analysis in scikit learn? Let's say we take this dataset
815:43 - again, and we are just going to pick the numerical data. No species for now. So we just look at these
815:50 - numerical columns. We simply import from SK learned or decomposition. We import the PCA
815:57 - model, and then we create the PCA model. We provided the number of target dimensions we want
816:04 - and the number of target dimensions in this case is two. And then we call fit. So we say PC dot
816:09 - fit, and we give it the data. And so we are going here from four dimensions, sepal length,
816:16 - sepal width, petal length, pet petal width to two dimensions. And what are those two dimensions?
816:23 - Well, at this point, we can't really interpret them as physical dimensions. I mean, it's not
816:28 - like we've picked sepal length and sepal width. No, it's, it's like we've picked two possible
816:34 - linear combinations. And remember, because lines and projections are involved, so everything is
816:39 - still linear. So we've picked two possible linear combinations of these four features,
816:44 - which are independent, which means that the lines along which we have projected are perpendicular.
816:50 - So we have picked two poss a two, two linear combinations of these four variables to
816:57 - independent linear combinations. And it is a projections on those lines that we are left with.
817:04 - Okay. So what just happened when you called fit? So those two things got
817:10 - calculated. So what got calculated is the lines. Now PCA internally knows what are the lines,
817:17 - the line number one, line number two, and you can look at the internal, like you can look at what
817:22 - those line number one, line number two are. Like if you do DIR PCA, you can look at some information
817:27 - about the lines. I think it would be a part of comp. Yeah, I think it would be a part of get
817:38 - params probably. I'm not sure. Okay. No. Yeah. Sorry. These are the components, right? So these are
817:52 - the components. So this tells you the, this basically, these four numbers convey the direction
818:00 - of the first line. This is the direction of the four, like these four numbers together conveyed
818:04 - and these four numbers convey the direction of the second line in four dimensional space.
818:09 - And you can verify that these two lines are perpendicular. Like if you did a dot product,
818:14 - then you will find that the dot product is zero. But now that we have the components,
818:18 - we can project these points on these lines by doing PCA dot transform. So now if we give PCA
818:25 - dot transform this data and this data, which has four dimensions, Iris DF numeric calls,
818:31 - it is going to give us transform data in two dimensions. You see here, now you have this
818:38 - transform data in two dimensions. This is the data projected on line number one, which has this
818:44 - direction, and this is the data, which is projected onto line number two, which has this
818:50 - direction. So if you know a little bit of linear algebra, these are both unit vectors in the
818:57 - direction of the lines that have been picked. In any case, now we've gone from this to this.
819:08 - And let's check it out. Let's maybe now plot. So now when we do a scatter plot, you can see now
819:15 - now when we do a scatter plot and I'm a plotting this data and I'm plotting this data, we can now
819:22 - finally visualize in two dimensions. Of course, not perfectly. There's still some, something is
819:27 - lost for sure, but we can still visualize data from all four dimensions, or we can visualize
819:35 - information from all four dimensions. So if we really want to study the clusters, right now,
819:39 - I've plotted the species, but we could just as well have plotted the clusters that were detected.
819:43 - So let's maybe look at the DB scan clusters. I think it was a model dot labels.
819:55 - Yeah. So these are the DB scan clusters. So now we can better visualize the clusters that we
820:02 - generate from clustering. So that's one other thing. That's one other, that's one good thing
820:09 - with dimensionality reduction. It can let you visualize the results of clustering and maybe
820:13 - evaluate the results of clustering better. You take a high dimensional data and then you perform
820:18 - clustering on it, and then you take maybe a principal component of it. And then you use that
820:25 - to visualize the clusters. Now, of course, principal component is, has some limitations.
820:33 - The first limitation is that it uses these linear projections, which may not always achieve a very
820:40 - good separation of, of the data. Like obviously one thing that we noted here was if you have this
820:48 - kind of a line, then information gets lost because most of the projections fall in the same place.
820:53 - Here's one problem that I can tell you with principal component analysis. Like if you have
820:58 - a bunch of points here, and you have a bunch of points here, all of them will project exactly
821:09 - the same value, right? So there is some information that does get lost. And then suppose these points
821:14 - belong to a different class. And then these points belong to a different class. So as soon as you do
821:19 - PCA, and then you are trying to maybe train a classification machine learning algorithm,
821:23 - you are going to lose some information, right? So there are some limitations with PCA, but for the
821:28 - most part, it works out pretty well. So I would use PCA whenever you have like hundreds of features
821:34 - on maybe thousands of features, and you need to reduce them to a few features. And as an exercise,
821:39 - I encourage you to apply principal component analysis to a large high dimensional dataset,
821:44 - maybe take the house prices, Kaggle competition dataset, and try and reduce the numerical columns
821:50 - from like 50 or whatever to less than five, and then train a machine learning model using the low
821:57 - dimensional results. And then what do you want to observe is the changes in the loss and training
822:02 - time for different number of target dimensions. Okay. And that's where we come back to this.
822:09 - If you could trade 200 columns for 50 columns for maybe a 5% loss in variance. Now we know what
822:15 - information means by information. We're saying variance. If you could trade 200 columns for
822:19 - five columns for a 5% loss in variance, that would give you a 40 X speedup. And maybe that speedup
822:26 - could be a make or break for your analysis, because now you can actually analyze 40 times
822:32 - more data in the same time. Right? So when you have really large datasets, PCA is definitely
822:37 - a very useful thing to do. Now, there's this Jupiter notebook you can check out. This goes
822:44 - into a lot more depth about principal component analysis. The way this works is that you can
822:49 - see that the way this is done is using a technique called singular value decomposition or SVD. Yeah.
822:56 - So there's a bunch of linear algebra involved there, but the intuition or the process that
823:00 - is followed is exactly the same. You find a line, you rotate the line till the point that you get
823:06 - the minimum, sorry, the maximum variance. And then you find the next line, which is perpendicular
823:11 - to this line and still guarantees the maximum possible variance. And you keep going from there.
823:16 - So let's talk about another dimensionality reduction technique. And this is called the
823:23 - T distributed stochastic neighbor embedding technique, or T SNE or T snee for short. And
823:30 - this belongs to a class of algorithms called manifold learning. And manifold learning is
823:36 - an approach to perform nonlinear dimensionality reduction of PCA is linear. And then there are
823:43 - more like PCA, there's something called ICA, LD, et cetera. They are all linear in the sense
823:49 - that they all come through some sort of linear algebra or matrix multiplications, but there
823:55 - are some limitations sometimes with linear methods. So you can use some of these nonlinear
824:01 - methods for dimensionality reduction. And they're typically based on this idea that the
824:08 - dimension, the dimensionality of many datasets is only artificially high, that there are,
824:14 - that most of these datasets, which have a hundred, 200, or 500 columns can really be
824:20 - captured quite easily with four or five columns. And we just have to try and figure out in
824:25 - some way what those, how to come up with those four and five, four or five columns of data,
824:31 - whether through like some formula being applied to all the columns or whether through like
824:36 - it's kind of feature engineering, except that the computer is trying to figure out these
824:40 - features for you based on certain rules that have been trained into these different kinds
824:45 - of models. So you have a bunch of different manifold learning techniques in scikit learn.
824:53 - And you can see here, this is the original dataset. So it is plotted in 3d. So this is
824:57 - the original datasets and they've, they've just colored the points maybe to give you
825:01 - a sense of which point goes where. And this 3d dataset, when you apply these different
825:07 - feature engineering or these different manifold learning techniques collapses to this kind
825:12 - of a graph in 2d. So you can see here that this basically is able to separate out red
825:20 - from red, from yellow, from green, from blue, which would be very difficult for PCA to do.
825:25 - Like if you try to draw two lines and drop projections, you would, it will be very difficult
825:29 - for you to get a separation like this, but ISO map is able to do that. Here is T-SNE.
825:34 - You can see with T-SNE as well. It is able to separate out to read it with from the yellow,
825:39 - from the green, from the blue. And these are all different kinds of separations that you
825:44 - get. Now T-SNE specifically is, T-SNE specifically is used to visualize high, very high dimensional
825:56 - data in one, two or three dimensions. So it is for the purpose of visualization. And very
826:03 - roughly speaking, this is how it works. We're not going to get into the detailed working
826:09 - of T-SNE because it's a little more involved. It'll take a little more time to talk about
826:13 - it in a lot of detail, but here's how it works. Now, suppose you have again, these clusters
826:18 - of date of data of points. Let's say this is petal length and this is petal width.
826:25 - What would happen normally if you were directly going to, if you just directly projected them
826:29 - onto this line, is that all of these blues would then overlap with a bunch of oranges
826:34 - and those would overlap with a bunch of reds. What T-SNE tries to do is first project them
826:42 - on a line and then move the points around and it moves the point points around using
826:52 - a kind of a near miss rule. So every point that is there that is projected down on the
826:57 - line is moved closer to the points that are closer to it in the real dataset, in the,
827:04 - in the original dataset. And it is, it moves away from the points that it is far away from
827:09 - in the original dataset. Okay. Now I know that's not very, it's not a very concrete
827:14 - way of putting it, but here's what it means as you project this line, this point down,
827:20 - it will end up here, the blue point. As you project this point down, it will end up here,
827:24 - the orange point. Now what T-SNE will do is T-SNE will realize that the blue point here
827:29 - should be closer to other blue points and should be farther away from orange points
827:33 - because that's how it is in the real dataset. So it's going to move the point. It's going
827:38 - to move the point closer to the blue points and it's going to move the orange points closer
827:41 - to orange points. Okay. So the closeness in the actual data is reflected as closeness
827:49 - in the reduced dimension in the dimensionality, reduced dimension, reduced data. Okay. So
828:00 - just keep that in mind. And if you have that intuition, you will be able to figure out
828:04 - when you need T-SNE, when you need to maintain the closeness, no matter how much you reduce
828:10 - the number of dimensions by T-SNE is useful. And here is a visual representation of T-SNE
828:16 - applied to the MNIST dataset. And the MNIST dataset contains 60,000 images of hundred
828:23 - and digits. So it contains 20 28 pixel by 28 pixel images of the hundred and digits
828:28 - zero to nine and 28 by 28 pixel. Each pixel remember is simply represents a color intensity
828:37 - like red, green, blue, or in this case, they are gray. So just represents like how gray
828:42 - that particular pixel is. Each pixel is a number. So that means each image is represented
828:47 - by 784 numbers, 28 times 28. So we can take those 784 dimensions and we can perform. We
828:57 - can use T-SNE to reduce that data to two dimensions and then plot it. And when we plotted, this
829:03 - is what we get. T-SNE is able to very neatly separate out all the images of the number
829:08 - zero from all the images of the number one from all the images of the number two, three,
829:12 - four, five, and so on. Okay. So there is, I encourage you to check out this video. And
829:18 - then there's also a tutorial that I've linked below on. Yeah, sorry. There's a tutorial
829:24 - here. You can check this out on how to actually create this graph. It will take you maybe
829:28 - an hour or so to create this graph to download the dataset and maybe look at some samples
829:32 - and create this graph. But what we're trying to get at here is that T-SNE is very powerful
829:40 - for visualizing data. So whenever you have high dimensional data, use T-SNE to visualize
829:45 - data. Now, T-SNE does not work very well. If you have a lot of dimensions, like maybe
829:51 - even 784, it's not ideal to directly reduce it to two dimensions. So typically what ends
829:57 - up happening is you first have maybe let's say 784 dimensions. You would take those 784
830:06 - dimensions and you would perform PCA principal component analysis and reduce it to about
830:10 - 50 dimensions. And then you would take those 50 dimensions and reduce it to two dimensions
830:15 - using T-SNE for visualization. Now these two dimensions, the one, the data that you get
830:22 - by T-SNE is not that useful for doing machine learning or even for doing data analysis.
830:28 - It is useful for visualization because you can see which points are closer together in
830:37 - the original data. That's what it is trying to tell you. Okay. So that's why you'll see
830:41 - T-SNE used as a visualization technique in a lot of different machine learning algorithms.
830:48 - And how do you perform T-SNE exactly the same way as the other as PCA? So you just import
830:55 - the T-SNE class, and then you set the number of components or the number of dimensions
831:00 - that you want. And we want to take this four dimensional data and we want to transform
831:09 - it to two dimensions. Now again, with T-SNE it, there's no predict or there's no transform.
831:16 - There's no fit and transform step. Both of them are combined into a fit transform because
831:20 - closeness of the points is very important. So in some sense, you, you don't use T-SNE
831:26 - on new data. You only use T-SNE on the data that you already have. So that's why we are
831:30 - doing a fit transform here. And that gives us the transform data. This is the transform
831:37 - data here. So we've gone from four dimensions to two dimensions. And then when we plot it,
831:45 - you can now see that T-SNE has really separated out the points here. So you, you have one
831:52 - class here, and then you have these two classes here. So these points, it may hold true that
831:57 - these points were actually quite near to each other in the original dataset. And that is
832:02 - why they are near to each other here. And these points are far away from each other
832:05 - in the original dataset. So that's why they're far away from each other here. Okay. Yep.
832:12 - So the takeaway is PCA is good when you're doing machine learning and T-SNE is good when
832:18 - you want to visualize the results. So try and use T-SNE to visualize the M and IST handwritten
832:24 - digits dataset. I have linked to the dataset here. Okay. So with that, we complete our
832:31 - discussion of unsupervised learning, at least two aspects of it clustering and dimensionality
832:38 - reduction. Again, there are many more ways to perform clustering in scikit-learn. There
832:43 - are many more ways to perform dimensionality reduction, and all of them have different
832:48 - use cases, but in general, you mostly would just start out by using K means clustering
832:53 - and by using PCA for doing dimensionality reduction. And then in a lot of cases, maybe
833:00 - a better clustering algorithm or a better dimensionality algorithm will give you a slight
833:04 - boost, but you should be fine with just using the most basic to begin with in a lot of cases

855:31 - using this training data and then use that model to make predictions of the fair amount
855:38 - for the test data. And that's why the test data does not have predictions. Now, once

855:56 - submission file. There is a key. So you will notice that these keys correspond exactly
856:02 - row by row to the test dataset. And here is supposed to be the prediction of your model.
856:07 - Now this sample submission file just contains 11.35, the same answer for every test row,
856:12 - but this is supposed to be the prediction for your model prediction generated by your
856:18 - model for the test set. And you need to create such a file and then you need to download
856:23 - this file. So I'm going to download it right here onto my desktop. And then you can come
856:32 - to this competition page and click on late submission. And you can upload this file here
856:40 - containing the sample submission, which is the key for each row in the test set and your
856:45 - prediction. And then you can make a submission once this is uploaded, of course. And once
856:56 - you make a submission, your submission is going to be scored. So the score for the submission
857:02 - is 9.4. Now, what does the score mean? You can check the overview tab and go into the
857:09 - evaluation section to understand what the score means. So this score is the root mean
857:14 - squared error. So the root means squared error is simply a way of measuring how far away
857:19 - your predictions are from the actual values. So you can't, you are not given the actual
857:25 - fair amounts for the test data, but Kaggle has them. And when you submit your submission,
857:30 - when you submit the submission or CSV file, the predictions are compared to the actual
857:35 - values, which are hidden from you. And the difference is calculated. Those differences
857:40 - are squared up, add it together. And then you take an average of the square differences,
857:45 - and then you take a square root of the average difference of the average square difference.
857:50 - And that's called a root mean squared error on average. It tells you how far away your
857:56 - predictions are from the actual value. So for example, in our case, our recent submission
858:04 - had a root mean squared error of 9.4, which means our predictions are on average off by
858:09 - $9.4. Okay. And we'll see whether that's good or bad in some time, but we definitely want
858:16 - to do more than that. And now one thing you can do is check your submission against the
858:21 - leaderboard to see where you land. Seems like people have gotten to a pretty good point
858:25 - where they, they're able to predict the taxi fare within $2.8. And we're at $9.74, which
858:31 - is pretty high if you ask me, because most taxi rides cost $10 or $10 to $15 maybe. So
858:38 - if you're off by nine, your prediction is practically useless. Okay. But that makes
858:43 - sense because right now we've just put a fixed prediction. We've basically submitted the
858:49 - sample file. So that's how Kaggle works. And one tip I have for you here
858:59 - is that you should write down these observations. So anytime you have an insight about the dataset,
859:03 - you should write it down, document it so that it's there for you later, if you need to come
859:10 - back to it. And again, Jupiter is a great way to do that. Okay. So that's how we downloaded
859:19 - the, so that's what we did. We downloaded the data from Kaggle using open datasets.

860:18 - and then load the test set. So here's one tip when you're working with large datasets,
860:25 - always start with a small sample to experiment and iterate faster. Now loading the entire
860:30 - dataset into pandas is going to be really slow and not just that any operation that
860:35 - you do afterwards is going to be slow. So just to set up my notebook properly, I'm going
860:40 - to first work with the sample and then maybe come back and work with the entire dataset.

866:48 - should skip the row. Otherwise we should keep the row. So that's what our skip row function
866:52 - does. Okay. All it does is for 1% of the rows, it is going to randomly return true or return

878:09 - plotting any charts, then do some feature engineering, try and create some interesting
878:14 - features. Then train a model and then repeat to improve your model. Instead of trying to
878:21 - do all your EDA for maybe a week and then doing a lot of feature engineering for a month
878:26 - and then trying to train your model and discovering that most of what you did was useless. Just
878:32 - use an iterative approach, try and train a model every day or every other day. Okay.

878:50 - the data. We've looked at the data. Let's prepare the dataset for training. So the first
878:55 - thing we'll do is split training and validation sets. Then we will deal with the missing values.
878:59 - There are no missing values here, but in case there were, we, this is how we deal with them.
879:04 - And then we will extract out some inputs and outputs for training as well. Okay. So we
879:11 - will set aside 20% of the training data as the validation set. So we have 550,000 rows
879:17 - out of those 20% will be set aside as a validation set. And this validation set will be used
879:22 - to evaluate the models we train on the training data. So the models are trained on the training
879:30 - data, which is the 80%. And then the evaluation is done. So we calculate the root mean squared
879:35 - error on the validation set, which is a 20% for which we know the targets, unlike the
879:40 - test set for which we don't know the targets. And what that will do is the validation set
879:46 - will allow us to estimate how the model is going to perform on the test set and consequently
879:54 - in the real world. Okay. So here's the next step. Your validation set should be as similar
880:00 - to the test set or real world data as possible. And the way you know, that is when you find
880:05 - the root mean squared error on the validation set. And you can do that because you can get
880:08 - predictions from your model and you have the actual targets for the validation set and
880:12 - you can compare those and calculate the root mean squared error. So the way you know, that
880:17 - the validation set is close enough to the test set is when the evaluation metric of
880:21 - the model on the validation and test set is very close. Okay. And if the root mean squared
880:27 - error on the validation set is like $2, but when you submit it to Kaggle, the root mean
880:31 - squared error is $9, then your validation set is completely useless. And you're basically
880:37 - shooting in the dark because you're trying to train different models to do better on
880:41 - the validation set, but the validation set has no relationship to the test set score.
880:46 - So make sure that your validation set and test sets have similar or very close scores
880:51 - and an increase in the score on the validation set reflects as an increase on the test set.
880:56 - Otherwise you may need to reconsider how your validation set is created. Now, one thing
881:00 - here is that we can, because the test set and training set have the same date ranges,
881:05 - right? The test set lies between a Jan 2009 to June, 2015. And the training set also

894:08 - is the root mean squared error for the training set, which means that on average, the predictions

894:22 - value that the model should be predicting by nine, which is pretty bad because the values

894:34 - about 12. So if you're, if they're trying to predict values in the range of, let's say
894:40 - 10 to 20 and you're off by nine. So that's a pretty bad model, right? And that's expected

894:50 - hopefully be better than this kind of a model, right? Should we hopefully be, have a lower

911:57 - and then learn machine learning along the way. Okay. Let's move on to feature engineering
912:03 - now. We're halfway through. So hopefully we'll be able to train a few models, feature engineering
912:10 - means taking the columns of data that you have and performing operations on them to
912:17 - create new columns, which might help train better models because machine learning models
912:24 - are fairly dumb. They have, there is a certain structure they have. They assume a certain
912:28 - relationship between inputs and outputs. Like linear regression assumes that the output
912:32 - is a linear is a weighted sum of the inputs. And that may not hold true in the current
912:38 - form, which is latitudes and longitudes, but suppose we were able to somehow calculate
912:42 - the distance between the pickup and drop off point, then there will definitely be some
912:46 - sort of a linear relationship between the distance to be covered and the fair, right?
912:55 - So by creating good features, you are going to make, you're going to train much better
913:01 - models because you are now applied human insight to provide features that are conducive to
913:06 - solving the problem in the structure that the model assumes. Now the tip here is to
913:14 - take an iterative approach to feature engineering. Don't go overboard. Don't spend weeks creating
913:19 - features. Just add some features, one or two, train a new model, evaluate it, keep the features
913:26 - if they help, otherwise drop them, then repeat with new features. So here are some features
913:32 - that we are going to create, and I am not taking an iterative approach here in the interest
913:37 - of time. I'm just going to create a bunch of features right away. First is to extract
913:42 - parts of the date. We have totally ignored the date so far because we didn't know how
913:47 - to put it into a linear regression model, but we can extract things like year, month,

914:18 - weekdays and weekends. There should be a difference during the week and across hour of the day.

924:43 - involves some human insight, because no machine learning model will be able to figure out
924:49 - at least not the simple models that we are training. We'll be able to figure out that
924:53 - a certain location is very important by itself, but we can able, we can figure that out quite
924:59 - easily given the context we have. So involving human insight or involving external data.
925:04 - So here we have picked up the latitude and longitude values for JFK, LG, et cetera. And
925:09 - this is essentially, this is what is called external data. Again, this, this data will
925:15 - never automatically become available to the machine learning model. So creative feature
925:19 - engineering is often a lot more effective in training good models than excessive hyperparameter
925:26 - tuning. Like you're doing a lot of grid searches and like training a model for a long time
925:30 - for multiple hours or overnight or over multiple days with tens of gigabytes and like hundreds
925:39 - of columns. So keep in mind that just one or two good features improve the model's performance
925:45 - drastically. So focus on finding what those one or two good features are, and they can
925:50 - one, they can improve the model's performance far more than any amount of hyperparameter
925:55 - tuning. And the way you get these features is by doing your exploratory data analysis
925:59 - by understanding the problem statement better by reading out reading up discussions by discussing
926:05 - it with people. And also keep in mind that adding too many features is just going to
926:10 - slow down your training and you're not going to be able to figure out what is the useful
926:13 - thing to use. That's why iterating is very important. So here are the latitudes and longitudes
926:19 - or longitudes and latitudes for JFK, LCA, a Newark, the Mac museum and the world trade

951:29 - the training data to match that of the test data, aren't we reducing the generalization
951:33 - of the model? For instance, we won't be able to use the same model for a future dataset
951:37 - that might not have the same range as a past test set. Absolutely. And that is why having
951:42 - a good test set matters, right? So your test set should be as close to what your model
951:50 - is going to do in the real world as possible, because otherwise the test set is useless.
951:54 - Now, if we are going to use the model in the real world for something other than what is
951:59 - already present in the test set, or the kind of data, the kind of ranges that are present
952:03 - in the test set, then our predictions on the test set are not very indicative, right? So
952:08 - our accuracy of the model is not very indicative. So even if you're getting 90% accuracy on
952:13 - the test set, then in the real world, the model can just be 30% accurate. And this happens
952:18 - all the time. Probably 80% of machine learning models face this issue. So what I would suggest
952:23 - instead is to create the test set in a way that can capture the entire range of values
952:28 - that the model can encounter in the real world, even if that means coming up with some estimates.
